editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: To his ever Honoured Uncle, Mr. WILLIAM CROP, Chief Chirurgion in Norfolk.
div.p:
THE many great Favours and daily continued Courteies which I have received from you, may well challenge and command a double Expreion of Thanks and Acknowledgment: and as you have ever tudied how to interweave your continual Bounty with the happy aitance of your great Art and Skill, each of thee heightning both my Advance and Profit; hould I not publickly repay you the Tribute of all imaginable thankful Acknowledgment, my hopes of ever doing well may oon icken, and like Liquors poured from one Veel to another, as readily loe their gut, and grow lat and dull. And although in thee publick Addrees I may appear impertin • nt to offer my Mite to you, whoe Skill in Art is large, and whoe Knowledge in Univeral Learning is great; yet have I preumed to helter this Tumefying Brat under your Wing, and commit it to your Patronage, not as being worthy your Acceptance, but that it may receive a kind Value and a candid Repute by your Acceptation; whoe Approbation hereof will be tamp enough to make it pas current amongt
the Generous Sons of Art. That there may be Faults in its Conduct, I am not altogether ignorant; but thee Lapes look'd on with an amicable view, will but appear as Moles in a fair Face. Sir, be you pleaed to give it your Bleing, and it hall venture the Cenure or Carping of others. All I hall further adde is, that when Greatnes and Judgment hall be hrivelled to nothing, or at bet into a cold remembrance, your Generous Charity as well as your great Learning will remain after you as living Monuments to after Ages. Sir, if you will pleae to pardon this Interruption with its Imperfections, and accept the Devotion wherewith they are offered, it will be the greatet Honour done

div.head: To the Ingenious and Judicious Reader.
div.p:
SInce I have ventured the hazard of offering the few Grains of my Knowledge and Care to be put into the Scale of your Cenure, and to be tried by the Standard of your Judgment; and although I am ufficiently concious I may want omewhat of weight or meaure: yet had I rather be cenured for committing uch an error, than be condemned for omitting o neceary a duty; Man not being framed to erve himelf alone, he that formed him made him alo a Brother to many, and this duty be oweth to them all; he being made much like the Princes Coin, the which after having once received his tamp proves current through his Dominions. This Tract well deerves the tudy and practice of a young Chirurgion, who ought to read it oberly, and practie it constantly. Whoever therefore is bred in this Chirurgick School, or brought up in the Nurery of Healing, let him endeavour to preerve knowledge in his lips, as well as judgment to guide his hand. I have here acted the part of a faithful Chirurgion, who ometimes mut be admitted and allowed to make the mart the forerunner of his cure, and may be accounted excuable, though he eemeth to be hard hearted in not regarding the lamentable mo •• s, and moving groans of his afflicted Patient, not paring his Probe untill he have ounded the bottom of the Abces. This is a ubject indeed, which is not to be touched by every common Pen, every • ip
whereof in ome caes may dilocate the Dicoure, and caue a Solution of Continuity in the Matter. The Tract is not like a gay Tulip, clothed and tinged with variety of Colours, fair and goodly for view, but void of mell and all apparent vertue: neither doth it look like a piece of Tapetry, which appears bet at farthet; its Leaves are not lined, covered, or filled with the thin Blooms of Aiery Froth, or fetch'd from the Humours of an Emperical Romance, but rather gathered, furnihed, and delineated, with the digeted wholeom Fruits of Learning, Example, and Hitory, mot lively reembling the delicate and weet Roe, the which beides its vertues of Perfuming the Air, proveth no les Medicinal than Fragrant. And now to you great Maters of Art, Brave Souls, whoe Merits are above your Names, whoe Vertues are no Shadows, and whoe Noble Spirits can oar far above the common reach of Mankind, who can as well pity the Wantonnes of one part of the world, who with a varnih and guilded Frame can plume their Impudence with the various coloured Feathers of Ignorance and Boldnes; as reward the other part with the jut dues and perquiites belonging to them; whoe Hands are too white and clean to receive or give any black Dirt. It's you I may and intend to make my Judges, who can ooner pardon a thouand Errors than others find one. I quetion not but the Brightnes of my Subject may have dazled my eyes, and my Expreions may fall low and flat, yet ince the Lading is well betowed in our Vesel, having received your gentle
Winds to breathe on it, I quetion not its well ailing, and may be kept off from the Shelves and Rocks of others, who make it their buines to pas an unhappy Cenure, although not capable to pas Examination themelves. By ome it may be objected, that this my Care and Pains may look like Flowers pluck'd from others Gardens. The Bees admirable Work is not to be dicommended or thought the wore of, nor the Honey the meaner, for its ucking or extracting the ame from the weet Flowers of any mans Ground. I here have been more plentiful in Authorities, becaue very few of our younger Brethren have a will to read many or great Volumes, whilet greater Masters have les time or leiure. To you alo who are of the lower Form in Practice, this Tract doth chiefly belong, it being as a guide to direct you in your whole coure of treating Tumours both general and particular, from head to foot; my requet to you is, if you find any thing worthy Collection or your Inpection, accept it with an amicable Hand; and if you give it the time of a Survey, play not the part of a Waterman, who Dum aliud proponit, aliud upponit. Let every man tudy his Art quietly and peaceably, that he may profes it openly and confidently, then may be expect it to have it guarded with the Lion and Crown, and encouraged by Royal Charters and Princely Privileges. I hope this Tract will meet with a Gentlemans Charity, whoe Soul is drawn out to his Fingers ends, who can pardon an imperfect Draught, and where he meets with too deep Shadows, can with
a light Hand and finer Pencil leen its darknes. It may be well reckoned amongst Vulgar Errors in our days, wherein the Mits of Ignorance are very plentiful, the Evening of Knowledge appearing but through a mall hole, and the dark Clouds of Folly obtructing our Light of Reaon; and hence is it that the Light which we enjoy is o variouly refracted by the glittering Vices of our times, and looks much disfigured by the Glaes of Humour and Fancy. If this may anwer expectation, I am happy; if it be diliked by uch who rather do meaure another mans actions by number, than by either order or weight, I am not troubled, knowing it to be a common failing of ome to be tempetuous in Temper, and troubleom either in Judgment or Deire, as to hate any thing they cannot themelves perform, or yield or lend a good look to another mans Labours, becaue they were not chritned by their Name, be they never o lawful, good, advantageous, or honourable: To thee and uch others I offer this as a Concluion; let us all study to be quiet and peaceable, and to do our own buines for publick and private good, to work with our own hands uch things as may gain afair repute and good name here, and a happy reward from Heaven hereafter; then hall our preent actions mell like the Roe, and Eternal Blis hall crown our end. And as I have in this Tract tudied to be profitable to thee, o let thy endeavours be to help others.

closer.dateline: From my Houe in Norwich, Nov. ult. 1677.

div.head: To the Author Mr. JOHN BROWN.
div.p: SInce you were pleaed to honour me with a ight of your Chirurgical Endeavours in this Work, I mut in justice return you my Thanks and Commendations due unto it: for though the ame Subject hath been handled by others, yet have you made o good a Collection out of Approved Authors, and o well dipoed and et down the Nature and Cure of Tumours, together with appoite Hitorical Obervations, that the ame may become of very good ue, epecially unto younger Chirurgious, unto whom you chiefly deigned it: and therefore I wih you happy ucces herein, and alo in all future Endeavours, unto which Art and Indutry hall enable you.

closer.signed: Your Loving Friend and Servant, THO. BROWN.

div.head: To Mr. John Brown Chirurgion of Norwich, on his Treatie of Tumours.
div.p: YO have taken great pains in thee your Collections, which having exemplified with o many very pertinent Obervations, I do encourage you in the Printing of them: they will be of great ue and intruction to all uch as have not had the opportunity of conulting the many learned Authors quoted by you, which most imployed in Armes and Sea-ervice cannot be accommodated with. Sir, I am

closer.signed: Your Affectionate Servant, KNIGHT, Reg. Chir. Principal

div.head: To his Ingenious Friend Mr. John Brown, upon his Treatie of Preternatural Tumours.
div.p: HAving with great delight perued your Indurious Dicoure and careful Studies in this your Treatie of Preternatural Tumours, I mut in gratitude and civility return you my just Acknowledgment due unto it. How lively you have examined their Caues, Signs, Preages, and Cures, no Son of Art but will acknowledge with thankfulnes: and with what admirable Hitorical Obervations you have adorned your Book, I need not to acquaint the Reader. All that I hall and in justice ought to adde, your Care and Ingenuity hewn herein may challenge a kind Opinion from the wort of thoe, who may pretend any digut againt your Sedulous Endeavours; which is the perfect Vote of him who is,

closer.signed: Your aured Friend and Servant, ROB. DANIEL.

div.head: To his Worthy Friend Mr. John Brown, Chirurgion in Ordinary to the Kings mot Excellent Majety, on this his Learned and Elaborate Treatie of Chirurgery.

lg.l: WElcome (my Friend) upon this mundane tage;
Learn'd Artits very carce are, and the Age
Abounds with Dolts, which doth its ills enrage.
We wanted one that would our Griefs declare,
And proper Medicines for them prepare;
And (thank our happy Stars) we have them here.
If Agues or Cut Fingers formerly
(Being cur'd) could raie men to a Deity;
What's then thy due, that cur'st each Malady?
Cheap in thoe cloudy times were Deities,
And little skill would purchae uch a Prize;
But Phyick now doth look with Argus Eyes.
Yet thy great Soul is uch, thou cant appear
Before the Preidents and Cenors Chair:
Thy Work being perfect, what hat thou to fear?
Were fam'd Hippocrates alive to write
Thoe Books, which firt gave Greece her Phyick ight,
He from this Work would humbly borrow light.
For having this learn'd Book men need no more;
Of ueful things it is a bounteous tore,
And doth provide a Salve for every Sore.
Thanks then (dear Friend) for this thy worthy pains;
Cure but all Worms too in Fanatick brains,
And Immortality hall be thy Gains.

closer.signed: JOHN GADBURY, Student in Phyick and Atrology.

div.head: The Names of the Authors concerned in this Tract of Tumours.
AN INTRODUCTION TO CHIRURGERY.
div.p:
AMONGST all the liberall Arts which the wie Creator hath made and betowed on mankind, there is none extant that carry more excellency and dignity than this of healing: Conidering either its Origin or Antiquity, its plendor of Invention, its honour and excellency, nobility and vertue, its ubject and learning, benefit and neceity, contancy and firmnes, with its liberality and charity. As touching its Origin and Antiquity:Its Origin and Antiquity. It came into the world almot in the ame day with man, for oon after his Birth was this ought out as both reaon and hitory makes good, it being generally our lots either ooner or later to make ue hereof: for as oon as we leave our mothers womb we grow ubject to receive the vapors of a putrid air
and winds, and do thereby exprome dieaes and icknees, as well as upon a further growth we hare in others ariing from meats and drinks. Can we either live well or act any thing to purpoe without health? Are there not many enter this mundane eene with icknes, and make as peedy exit without this help of medicine? Are not our actions taken from the Soul, produced from its effective caue, and perfected by the body as its Intrument? And ince it is reaonable to think that we can neither live nor move or yet arrive at a well being without this Jem of Healing, ought we not alo to conjecture, that it was neceary from the firt? Man was not made like an I per e I, to tand by himelf, and hear the warbling notes and pleaant muick of the pretty Bird, or ee how the ground out of a grain of corn yields its increae. No, this reaonable oul bred out of a higher park was here planted alo to labour: Non otiandum in via, ed laborandum in vinea. And here alo may we opinionize healing and medicine were invented before other Arts, they being both of greater neceity and ue: and this reaon teacheth. And if this may not pleae, Holy writ and acred Hitory will hew us a great deal of its Antiquity
and Origination.Its Origination hown in a great part by Holy writ. Amongt the people of God were alwaies Phyitians, as we may ee out of Moes, Solomon and o forth. Do we not read of Joeph ordering his father to be embalmed, and how that he was embalmed by Phyitians? Gen. 50. May we not find cabs, ores, and bliters in Exodus 9? May we not read of • aying and wounding in Exod. 21? Have we not the Leproy and its marks, the plague and its pots in Levilicus 13? and its method of cure by applying the blood of Sparrows, Cedar and Hy •• op, cap. 14? In Numb. 35. we read of murders and layings, contuions and wounds. In Deuteronomy 23. no man hurt with a Rupture mut bear any publick office. In Jud. 9. we may read of a woman, which with a peice of miltone wounded Ab • melech in the head, and brake his brain-pan; and <>
Kings 1. Jeroho • m's hand was o withered, that he could not get it pulled in again; and Aa in the 39the year of his Reign was o dieaed in his feet, that he ought to Phyitians. Chron. 2. Thee Holy authorities may be enough to how its Antiquity: the thing howeth it elf evidently that people before this time were not onely troubled with inward dieaes, but alo perplexed with outward troubles. Moes drew the Iraelites out of Aegypt above
3000 years ago; & if any will enquire, he may find there were Chirurgions; and not thee only, but Phyitians alo, before which time they were in great eteem and admiration; and this was for certain that there was little or no ditinction between Phyick and Chirurgery. About 500 years (as Avenzoar oberves) before his time amongt the Arabians were they joined together. I peak of the time where this art of healing flourihed amongt the Greeks;As to its honour and Excellency. for the Aegyptians had it much earlier, as Herodotus writes. The wie man in Eccleiaticus aies, God made both Phyitians and medicine; and wie Solomon makes mention of Phyitians healing inward dieaes, and of the earth being furnihed with plants and herbs for curing outward ores and hurts. Did not our wie Creator frame both the Phyitians and plants for the good and benefit of mankind? Did not our Bleed Saviour make the blind ee, the lame walk, and the deaf hear? It is noted that an Angel of the Lord taught Tobias to cure his father's eies with the gall of a fih. Have not Kings, Princes and Potentates tudied, exercied and imbraced this Art, ome for pleaure, others for ornament or contemplation, whilt ome others make a more deep inquiry into it
for neceity of life? Amongt the Senevans Cham had a wife whoe name was Rhea, out of whom was bred Oiris, who for his knowledg in this Art was eteemed as a God, and adored and worhipped as a Deity. Jachenus amongt the Aegyptians for inventing a way to purify the Air was renowned as a mighty one, and by them had a Temple erected, in which he was interred. Mercurius Trimegitus a little after Moes in the time of Johua appeared in Phyick with great glory. Homer writes that Podalyrius and Machaon ons of Aeculapius went into the Trojane war and exercied this faculty; hence may we learn of what great eteem value and reverence this Art was in former times: But to look nearer home, have we not very oft times een it kept, preerved, protected, and propagated in the Royal palaces and and Princely families of Kings and Potentates? Plutarch tells us, that Alexander the great was not only a Scholar to Aritotle, but was alo a very great admirer of this Art. King Mithridates hath given to the world to his perpetual ame a Signal token of his diligence and tudy in this Art by his Antidote Chritned by his own name. May we not read of many Reverend perons who buied themelves
in tudying the knowledg of herbs thus Chirou the Centaur accounted mot excellent in his time for curing of wounds gave Century its name; and hence came our Art to take its derivation, held by ome. Gentian came from Gentianus King of the Illyricks. Avicen not unknown to any mater of Art, came out of the Lineage of the Perian Kings. Arthemeia had its name from the Queen Arthemeia. May we not well with admiration ee the Almightie provedence working trange effects by the hands of our Sacred King of bleed memory, and the French King in curing Scrophulaes? Have we not een Rebellious tumours, which corned and trampled on medicine, forced to yeild to his touch? Running ores all in their leakages, the weak made trong, and thoe members brought into good order which had formerly bin riled and ditorted, by the Sons of the mot high, imprinted as badges and true tokens of their being the only true heirs of the Imperial Crown? And as thee are the great maters of our health, ought we not to endeavour and to defend them, and pray that they may lat with us in England o long as the Sun and Moon hall continue? Fernelins telleth us there is nothing can be better hown or drawn to
the life in Phyick than by example;Its learning and vertue. for hereby may we, nay can we not be o readily deceived, the foundations hereof for the mot part coniting of Judgment and Experience: for as reading makes a full man, conference a ready man, and writing an exact man; o alo doth Experience give us the liveliet character of a knowing man. In all thee ome ages have been more happy than others. Amongt the Aegyptians this Art of healing was very carefully treaured up, thee like generous ouls born for publick good by great care and tudy have left to the world examples of their love and tudies: and as the firt amongt thee was Aeculapius, who have writ to poterity: yea before ever writing or printing was, this Art was o much in eteem, that by the indutry of man were their remedies marked out with Hyereglyphick igns; out from thee came thoe rare volumns of Hippocrates; and he that hareth this way to find advance in his skill and judgement, may be well aid to walk in the darknes of ignorance, and fed with the Chymaerical fallacies of fooleries and flatteries. Galen's books have been of great profit to mankind; may we not count our elves much obliged to him for his two books De Articulis & Fracturis?
Since thee have Heraclides, Diocles, Caritius, Praxagoras, Chryippus, Eraitratus and Hierophilus, been eteemed great Maters of Art; after thee are Aclepiades, Albucais, Paulus, Aeginetta, Eratus, Johannes Fernelius, Gabriel Fallopius, as o many riing Suns in their Art, by whoe replendency have many obcured things been brought to light. Are not in our times thee following in great etimate and ervice to us, and with us for ripening our knowledg, helping our inufficiencies, and aiting our practices, as Hierouymus, Fabritius de Aqua pendente, Cornelius Celus, Fabritius Hildanus, Johannes Vigo, Ambroeus Parraeus, Tagaultius Berbettus, Crook, Read, Woodhull, Low, Baniter, Vigerius and the like? what therefore ought more to be had in eteem or worth, reverence or honour, than that Art which teacheth to keep and preerve the life of man in afety health and vigour by its learning and vertue? for may we not with eae ee, as through a Chrital, that what ever is contained in this Orb is ubject to a medicinal contemplation? Man, the heavenly coal blown up by the divine parks of Almighty widome,Its Subject. is the ubject of healing: it's this rational oul and compleat body whereon it exercieth it elf.

He that is the mot admirable of all other Animals viible, and commands all others, and ubjects them to him, is controuled by icknes, and therefore tands in need hereof: and this may well raie a Chirurgion into admiration, not of himelf (with pride and arrogancy) but of the Almighty widome with fear and reverence, how that for his contemplation are all Terrene things made and framed; how that to him is given the Judgement of knowing the vertues and vices of herbs and plants, to keep and preerve pure the admirable harmony of man, comparable with the Sun in its glory, with the Moon in its moiture, with the Earth in its vegetables. And come we to view his three venters, we may ee his upper room, his animal parts, furnihed with intellective faculties, his oul arraied with an animal ene.Mans upper parts. From this fountain cometh our knowledg of our Maker, our Honour and obedience to our King, our ubjection to his Laws, our prudence for exerciing the ame, and our harmony for politick ocieties. Here dwells our Councel; and it is by this prerogative that Jutice is executed on the criminal, and Equity extended to the jut. Here dwelleth our cience, art, trength, perfection, knowledg, and reaon. Here is placed natures cheif
magazine. It is here that < in non-Latin alphabet > , as it were the ouls eye, the commanding mitris of morality: man hath this admirable work pun of ine threads of veins and arteries. Its outward wall reembles the element of earth, its next covering made of permatick fibres imitates water, that ine web pun by the Almighty hand which covers the brain, paints out air; the body of the brain it elf repreents ire. This fountain ends forth many rivulets into the back part of the brain by its trunks, circuits, and plexures. Strange and admirable are its fabricks, as wonderful its net, hence comes the ilver Chord the wie man peaks of. Its outward cap very prettily reembles a fair Wood clutered with young trees. The alt tears, which trickle from his eies, carry a lively reemblance of Dew; vapours obcuring his ight reemble clouds and mits; the noie of the ears winds and torms, frothy pittles carry the lively protraict of Snow, as well as coagulated or conglobated legm the repreentative of hail. A Coriza in the noe carries the imilitude of rain: neezing reembles thunder, and the rednes of the eies lightning. Is not the un een in the native heat of the brain, as well as the moon in its watery element? Jupiter
in its temper, as well as Saturn in its melancholly? Mars in its choller, as Venus in its flegm? hath not this upper houe the eies for its windows, the ears for its ide doors, the notrils for its cavingers, the mouth and tongue to bepeak and provide for its wants, and to tell its neceities, and the grinders here alo placed for matication? Is it not by its nerves that we lift up our eye to our maker? Juit & erectos ad ydera tollere vultus; by its ide doors doth not come in our hearing, which is our bet intrument for dicovering of freinds from enemies? are not its mammillary procees ordained for conveighing its pirits and tempering its heat? is not our tongue lift up and down by its nerves? Os ublime dedit homini, caelumque tueri. When we have conidered all thee, how admirably they are framed, what various functions they perform, how necearily they were contructed, and with what art annexed, may we not with old Zoroater cry out
< in non-Latin alphabet > ; Draw but the Curtain and you may oon ee a Metamorphois, the Seene changed, and thee rare parts impaired by icknees and dieaes; for ince Adam took the Apple from his wife, his children and uceours have been very capable of being
deprived of thee happinees:The cene changed. for come we more nearly to conider him as relative to our preent dicoure, we hall find a uddain change; in his infancy we may find inects daily to grow in his outward cap; in his youth cabs and ulcers; when having arrived at riper years it is oft times with Artheromaes Stealomaes, and Melicerides, its Pericrane filled with Hydrocephalical Tumours, its outward wall is oft times battered and fractured, cleft and divided by fiures, bruied by Contuions, wounded by penetrating and not penetrating wounds, its Dura mater is made to flee from the skull, although o trongly tyed and rarely wrought into it, by fractures and incied wounds. Is not its princely palace pulled down inwardly by Apoplexies, haken with Palies, threatned by Epilepies, burnt up by fevers and inlamations, tormed by winds, overflown by inundations, conumed by gangrenes and phacelus's? are not its windows hut up by Cataracts, and darkned by uffuions? its ide doors aailed by tormes, and windy ruffling noies? its muicall Organick pipes hut up by colds and deafnes? Comes not hence, as from the main Ocean, thoe many trunks and channels which bring in our gouts, Dropies and Cramps? Is not its
excretory paages topt up by Polypus and Ozaenaes? are not the grinders forced to leave going, and the Jaw put out of order by fractures and dilocations? when this light extinguiheth, are not all things made into darknes? doth not our reaon become obcured, our wit equetred, our Judgment affrighted, our memory lot, our undertanding clouded, our enes banihed, our tongue tied up, our tat gone, our ilver chord hirvelled, our grinders ceae, our hands contracted, our Columns and Pedetals brought low, and in a moment come to nothing?The middle Region. In the middle Region you have natures mot curious cabinet wrought with various Roomes, wherein are lockt up the vital Treaury, the wheels and Intruments, whereby the watch of our life is alwaies kept in motion from our firt hour to our lat minuit. Here dwels the kingly heart the great mater of courage, and warrior, exerciing its nectarean faculties by giving life and vigor by its vivifying and quickning heat: and as the Sun in its Caeletial Sphere yeilds luture and beauty by its motion and light; o alo is our heat, light, life and motion upheld propagated and preerved by the heat and motion of the heart. This part is called < in non-Latin alphabet > from a word which ignifies to leap; its called
Cor à Currendo, it being ever in motion; it hath Lungs allowed it for tempering its heat, and fanning its fervency: here's alo a Diaphragma ditinguihing or eparating the intruments of nourihment from thoe of life, being as a mucle mot different from all others: Its Sides and Ribs are guarded with a Pleura inward, bred of permatick fibres; this erves for keeping the lungs from being intangled with the ribs: beides thee is a Mediastinum, framed as a partition wall or thick hedg dividing this trunk in the middle, this keeps the heart up from falling. Thus may you ee how erviceable every part is for performing its office and ervice to the heart as its Prince; and at the firt view we might well conjecture, that this might be framed with afety, being the only and main Engin of life.The courage abated, and this Sun Eccliped. But this alo uffers its gloomines, and takes hares with all its parts of icknees and dieaes. How oft have we een this Prince of life, which betowed its vigorous influences to the body, as the Sun doth to Plants, to be eccliped by a cloudy legmatick excreceny? this watch furred and run into diolution by Dropy, Worms, and inects? Is there not een Tartarous tones as well as coagulated legm, the one endeavouring to diolve this princely pallace, whilt
the other top its channels to uffocation? do not wounds and Apotems uddenly happening here as peedily put out this candle of life? Is not this princely palace oft parcht by Fevers, urrounded with Agues, tormed with Cardiacal Syncopes, waht away with the inundations of trange Dropies, poyoned with malign fevers, obtructed by flegm? are not its flabellums burnt up by inflammation, conumed by Athmaes and Empyemaes, rotted by ulcers, turned into wah-pools by Dropies? is not here a lung oft times converted into purulent matter, and an Athma into a Squiney? are not our ides pricked with a pleuriy, troubled with a Peripneumony? Thee and many others take up their Quarters here: and although Phyick and Chirurgery have the two ubtantial leggs of experience and Reaon to defend them, yet the great knowledge hereof mut come from that great Doctor, who hath Heaven for his chair, and the Earth for his foot-toole. Thus have I carried you through the fortunes and misfortunes of his middle Region.The third Region. We arrive now to his lower and 3d room, his natural part: and here have we mot exactly repreented the Liver, with its interwoven ditributions of the vena porta, and vena cava, with the veica fellea,
and its everal capillary veels, with its meatus citicus, its porus biliarius, and ductus communis, framed from the eparation of the gall or bilious humor from the blood, and conveying it into the intetines; and here alo may we ee the Almighty dipoing variety of Organs for diverity of ues; and for its outward guard you may ee it furnihed with a flehy Armour made of mucles; under it the two Spermatick coats of the Peritonaeum, the enwrapping and keeping warm the parts within; thee being laid bare, may we meet with a criped kell with its curled veins covering the bottom of the tomack and keeping it warm; under this lies the trange Series of Intetines, trangely wheeled about, contrived with much Art, and framed with variety of circles, here lodged for ending forth with more expedition the excrements from the body: to ee uch a length of intetines contracted about uch a mall meentery, as it appears in its natural ight, may well challenge the greatet of admiration, how finely checquered with white & purple veins, ordered for conveighing its chyle and keeping it warm by its blood already made and elaborated; here is alo a Pancreas tied to the guts, as a pillow to prop and keep up the veines arteries and
nerves, as well as a juice to help forward expulion; here alo is placed the pleen, ordered to help forward concoction, furnihed with arteries for drawing away its mot feculent blood, to ventilate the natural heat of the pleen, and to invite a vital faculty to it; here alo are planted the kidneys, ordered for expulion and avoiding of exerementitious wheyih matter, the which being altogether unprofitable for nourihment is ent from thence by the ureters into the bladder, and by the good laws of nature is here alo placed the bladder, ordered as a Receptacle of this urine, the which for a time it retaineth, and being therewith overloaded doth exonerate it elf thereof. Thus have I hown you through all the Rooms of Nature's lower Region, where you have een how every part is imploied whilt it enjoies its true function; but thee alo are robbed of their excellencies, taken off from their offices, deprived of their faculties and laid open to the enemy, by dieaes, troubles,Nature made unnatural to it elf by dieaes. wounds and Tumours, Stones and Dropies: thus may we ee the Peritoneal permatick ibres extended by Dropies; the Kell burnt up and parched in long and tedious ditempers, ditorted and diaffected by intammations and Ruptures; the Intetines blown
up and welled with Collicks, pured up and convolved by Iliacks, torn and lacerated with Herniaes, wounded and pierced with fitulaes; the Liver the magazine of blood inflamed, its trunks and channels obtructed by varices and melanchollick feces, hindred in its actions and motions by Tumours; the pleen uffer cirrhous tumours, and obtructed with excrementitious blood; the kidneys fretted with gravel, inflamed by pain, tormented with tones and ulcers, cloed up by obtructions and Trychiacis, its pipes topped by flegm, tones or gravel; the bladder uffer reolution, and that which was made the receptacle of urine oft times proving the receptacle of tones and gravel, perplexed with Ichuries and Dyuries, piings of blood, preternatural tumours, abcees, Ulcers, Caruncles and the like. Thus have I given you a hort urvey of the inward parts, their beauty plendor and formes, to which alo are added their various icknees pains and dieaes; and may we expect in reaon that the outward Coffin or Chet may fare better and be more free from dieaes than thee? No ure; where the Jewels are lodged, there generally are held the ecurity: for as poor man is ubject to outward torms and winds, o may we
as readily find him as capable to receive the impres and tamp of dieaes: In his face we may oft times ee a uffued eie, a hare lip, a polypued noe; in his neck and throat trumous and crophulated tumours; in his mouth and throat Cancers and Anginaes; his houlders ditorted; his mucles cut, prickt, or wounded, his nerves contracted or lacerated; his veins and arteries ancurimated and variced; his bones luxated and fractured, and the whole ometimes gangrenated and phacelated; his hands, the proper Intruments of his livelihood, corrupted with Chiragra and other Tumours; his writ dilocated; his very ingers ends terrified with Parony chiaes and Hyperarcocal excrecencies. May we not oft times ee the brets, that firt give us uck or nutriment, uffer the torments and unhappy aailing unruly diquiet of Cancers, Strumaes, Worms, Stones, Clefts, and the like? Is not the Penis, the proper intrument of generation, accompanied with Phymois, beet with Ulcers, Caruncles, venereous and malign ulcers, whilt ometimes it is een to have an imperforated Glans. The Scrotum is very oft times een loaded with pains and troubles, tumeied by Ruptures, and made capable of inflammation and gangtene; the Hips
greived with Scyaticks and running pains, petered with venereal aches and dilocations; the mucles of the thigh oft wounded, tumeied inflamed, lacerated, ulcerated, and abceed, as well as its bone fractured; the knee wel'd with oedematous Tumours; the leg hortned by amputation, occaioned inwardly by a deluxion of humours, or outwardly by ome external caues, cauing gangrene, Sphacelus, or the like. Do not they and the foot alo by joint conent take hare of hydropical tumours, corbutick ulcers, gouts, and other pains? and when we have well conidered thee, may we not own with Job, man hath not a part free from ditemperiety? In its contancy and firmnes it is to be preferred before any other Art under the Sun:Its Contancy and firmnes. for as it came oon after him into the world, o it never leaves him to his dying minuit; nay it continues longer for he being dead, it erves to help his ucceeding generation. The truth of this daily experience makes good: for although our life be but vita brevis, yet our art is Ars Longa; and although it may be ubject to change, yet this is to be better born with, being like man with whom it is concerned: but this is more contant, life is no life without health; and is not this our daily friend
afforded us by our wie Creator for promoting and perfecting the ame? It is by this Art of healing we have our daies lengthned, by cutting off ditempers, eradicating their caues, and extripating their effects; and indeed what is health ele, than the keeping of the whole body perfect and intire? And this may then mot properly be aid o to be, when all its actions are freed from the chains of impediments and pains; for this great happines of health is onely that affection of the body, which from the firt do make every of its actions anwer its nature. This made Democritus write, that he would have every man tudy the Art of healing; becaue as it is honet, o alo it is profitable and ueful for life:Its fruit neceity and profit. Which brings me to the next branch of it, which howeth its fruit neceity and profit. This is a feild very large, conidering either its order, condition, age or ex, wanting no fruit; it is this alone that produceth health, by divine permiion, a more excellent thing than which this great world cannot boat of; to live is to be buried alive without it. No man therefore ought to be held in a greater etimate in a Common weal, than he that keeps the people thereof in health. This made
•• omer the Prince of the great Poets prefer one
Phyician well furnihed with vertues and knowledg in his Art before many of other men. It is here alone guided by nature, that can ee ditempers, and natch them out before they take root, dicharge uch as are adherent, detroy them in the bud, hinder them in their growth, repres their vehemency, mitigate their pains, extinguih their fervour; that can retore the emiputrid to health, recreate the afflicted, refreh the troubled, trengthen the languihing, and bring the half dead to a whole life. But hould thee fail, yet we have this to defend us before the great Doctor of our Souls; if to the utmot of our endeavous and judgments, and thee trengthened by care and tudy, we ue and apply the bet of medicines our bet knowledg can guide us to, we have dicharged our parts, and let us leave the ucces to that God, who can work beyond the waies of man, whoe ecrets are pat finding out. And this part I will conclude with this maxim, That this Art is by o much the more excellent and to be had in eteem, by how much it is neceary, ueful and profitable. Of its liberality and Charity our great Mater hath left a lively example,Its liberality and Charity. who had no repect to perons when he went and exercied this Art of healing. And although
in Kings and Potentates it may receive Princely rewards, and amongt Lords and Knights fair gratuities; yet alo mut it be furnihed with the graces of Charity and Humility, thinking no corn to help the meanet; this being its rule, Quod tibi fieri non vis, alteri ne feceris; it being a maxim in natural Morality as well as Philoophy: And as Riches may puron to honour, and both to the obtaining of fame and credit; o let charity and concience command your diligence and care in the managing the ame for the poor, for they are Gods creatures framed in the ame mold; and although they be not furnihed with the ame plenty of outward gifts, yet may they ore top the rich Mier or covetous Churle in vertues and other excellencies. And let this be your comfort, that the great Pay-mater, who keeps in his Regiter-book all thy good actions, will not be wanting to add tore to your tock, knowledg to your Art, ucces to your practice, and crown your cures with credit; and when death his Bayliff hall with his Habeas Corpus ummon thee to the great Audit of the world, the Angels will Joy in thy happines, and eternal blis will Crown thee hereafter. Thus have I given you an account of the Antiquity and Origination of Chirurgery,
its honour and excellency, its learning and nobility, its ubject, its contancy and firmnes, its fruit, neceity and profit, its liberality and charity. We come next to know what Chirurgery is, and of what parts it depends.

That we may arrive at the eential knowledg of Chirurgery,What Chirurgery is. we ought firt to conider what it is, what is its ubject matter, for what end it was made and ordered, and what order ought to be kept in it. As to the firt, Cornelius Celus calls that Chirurgery, which cures by the hand, being the mot evident part of Phyick, to which is adjoined both Diet and Pharmacy: Or, if you pleae, it is a branch of the Curative part of Medicine, which teacheth how to retore health by manual operation and medicine. Ambroe Parry telleth us, it is an Art which informeth with reaon how we may cure, prevent and mitigate dieaes by the help of the hand: but its mot proper and eential definition is taken from eradicating dieaes by Art and manual Operation; for as
<>
hath it, uch medicines as are applied to Tumours, Wounds, Ulcers, or Fituaes, cannot o properly be aid to be cured by Chirurgery, becaue this health is purchaed and procured by help of medicine which was applied. But
where an Abcee or Impotume is opened by Inciion, bones diocated or fractured reduced by the hand, Fitulaes dilated, Cataracts couched, Cancers taken of by Intrument, and the like, thee may well come under the name of Chirurgery, it being from the ue of the hand that it taketh its name: for it is derived < in non-Latin alphabet >
à mann & opera, and thus Chirurgery quai
< in non-Latin alphabet > .Its end for which it was framed. As for its ubject matter I have already hown man, being alone the proper Intrument hereof. As to its end, it was ordered and framed to repair natures wants, to help her neceities, to make her curvations right. And to its order and method, it is divided into Theory and Practice.Its Order and method. The firt teacheth and is called cience acquired by demontration and knowledg of the principles of Art; this carrieth with it the precepts of Art: The econd practice found out by Knowledg and Reaon, arriving at a greater degree of perfection by manual Operation; and this daily experience adds to its lutre and truth. It may alo be divided into general and pecial parts. Thee held general,Into general and pecial parts. as the Articulations or oft parts: Thoe pecial, which teachthe right way of Operation about Tumours, wounds, ulcers, fractures, di • ocations, and the like. The cope of
Chirurgery directs the Chirurgion to the well knowing and undertanding thee four parts, as to remove olution of continuity, to retore union where wanting, to eparate parts unnaturally united, and to upply defects. The firt is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , the joining part, the econd < in non-Latin alphabet >
the eparating part, the third < in non-Latin alphabet >
the removing part the fourth < in non-Latin alphabet >
the upplying part. The firt performed by Conolidatives, Agglutinatives, adducing Luxated bones and curing fractures: The econd acted by Inciion, Phlebotomy, or Scarrification, or Amputation; as in wry necks, hare lips, imperforated Anus and Penis: The third is finihed by extirpating tumours, as Ganglions, Cancers, Nodes, Strumaes, Scrophulaes, Stones, Cataracts, drawing out of water from the Abdomen or Thorax, by a Paracentheis, Amputation, and the like: The fourth he upplies in retoring Ruptures into their proper places, as in retoring a new noe, and bringing the blind eie to its ight: And thee are to be done Citò, Tutò & Jucunde, uddenly without pain, afely without cheat or impoture, and pleaantly without fear or fallacy. And that the Chirurgion may perform thee with honour and repute, let him take a turn with me in the everal
borders of this Chirurgick garden;In the Chirurgick garden grows things natural, unnatural, and preternatural. where he may firt ee what is natural, what unnatural, what preternatural, thereby the better to furnih himelf with Indications or Intentions againt thee or any thereof. And the firt that offer themelves here are the things of nature, for whoe end this firt intention is appointed,Wh • natural. and that is health, its caue, effect, its trength and temper, all which are to be kept in their order and beatuy:What preternatural or unnatural. Thee are generally allowed unnatural or preternatural, as a dieae or ditemperiety; for this is aid to be a praeternatural effect of it elf, and hurting action by its caue; and this may hurt by action, hindring it, or by accident; and then by ymptoms, which follow a dieae as a hadow doth the body.Three general I • tentions. There are three general Intentions here requiite. The firt ariing from a preternatural thing taking from its contrary;The firt. as union from Solution of continuity, coldnes from heat, heat from coldnes, drines from moiture, and moiture from drines, ablation from matter exceeding, and encreaing from matter diminihing, apertion from obtruction, and dilatation from angutnes, atriction from amplification, repoition into its proper place from whence it made its receion. And as we are to oberve
this order of contrariety; o alo are we well to undertand it, which affect ought firt to be cured, the curing of which is the principal caue of curing the other,The econd. and without which no perfecture. The econd Intention heweth, how we are to keep thoe parts intire, which are placed according to nature; and to dicharge and expel thoe that are preternatural: and we may undertand an incurable dieae thee three-waies.Three waies to know how to cure a dieae. Firt when the dieae of its own nature is incurable, as the Elephantiais, or confirmed: Secondly when the patient ueth not uch means as hould be proper for his recovery: Thirdly when the curing of one ditemper threatens another greater and more terrible. The third Intention is performed by opportune helps and conveniency,The third. ue of right and proper medicines: and thee are either Medicinal or Intrumental; Intrumental for living well, and keeping a good order, as Pharmacy, Phlebotomy, Emplaiters, Uuguents Powders and the like. The unguents a Chirurgion hould alwaies have in readines atisfying his common Intentions, are thee, unguent. Bailicon, to maturate and convert into Pus; Apotolorum, to deterge and mundify; Aureum, to incarn and fill up; A •• um, to agglutinate and conolidate; Dialthaea,
to mitigate and eae pain. Intruments for all occaions large and mall, ome for earching, others for cutting, for ome drawing out extraneous bodies, and others for putting or reducing parts into their repective places: And thee bring me to the Chirurgion himelf, which is to be the man onely engaged both in their applications and adminitrations; and let us ee what peron he ought to be, how qualified, armed, furnihed, and exercied. To conider in what chair of honour and eteem a Chirurgion is eated, may well require his care and tudy, learning and excellency: and ince there is uch a conjunction of the mind with the body, uch a connexion and ociety, that they generally take hares of one anothers good and bad fortune, as ome deliriated with fevers, whilt others are blown up with madnes by the fury of choller; To ee the wonderful effects of blood, while melancholy acts her innumerable changes in our bodies, may well call into admiration the bet of mens knowledg, our thoughts varying according to the diverity of tempers in our bodies. Thus are we troubled with dieaes, inflamed by anger, weetned by love, exhilarated by joy, dejected by orrow, tempered by weetnes, haken by fear; and to earch out
the depth of thee, their originations and caues, their diverity of hapes and potures, may well require a quick ight to penetrate, a powerful wit to earch out, a well guided reaon to conider of. He therefore that will enter this tage of Chirurgery, mut well undertand its various cenes and acts; for its he alone guided by the provident hand and divine aitance that can maintain and keep up our orts and catles from the aailing batterings of wounds and contuions, &c. and by him alo may herbs and roots, eeds and berries, gums and fruits, be made capable intruments to banih the enemy having once made its entrance. It's by his Art the welling bubbles of calding water are dipert, the burnings of gun-powder allaid, its pain removed, and its black marks fetched out. Its by his Art dilocated Articulations and fractured bones are brought into their right form and order, old ulcers and fituales dilated, mundified, incarned and cicatrized, Herniaes and Stones bound up and drawn forth: and ince thee and many more are committed to his care and charge, what skill, knowledg, fathoming of dieaes, and judgment, ought he to have and be furnihed with to undertake this task? Take with me this as a hort character of
a good Chirurgeon,What peron a Chirurgion ought to be. he being a man both honet and careful in his art, prudent and provident for his patient, expert and skilful for defending himelf, well learned and educated for dicoure with others, well exercied and practied for the help of both. He ought to be well furnihed with books, thee being as o many afe Pilates to conduct him in his unknown way, and to keep him off from the helves and rocks of mitakes and errorsin his Art: Adorned with learning; for this makes him appear as a Sun, whilt others les literate hine but as maller Stars; this conducts him to the tree of knowledg, whilt others can onely boat of their impudence and ignorance; it is this gives life to his practice, chearfulnes to his tudy, and ecurity to his conduct: And as we eldome ee a wie man gain knowledg from a fool; o is it as rare, to gain awie medicine from an ignorant block. He ought to be well exercied in Anatomy,Exercied in Anatomy. for hinc dicimus artem rectiime operandi & ecuritate incidendi: It being as the cheif pillar or bais on which Chirurgery planteth its foundation; this is the great magazine, from whence he fetcheth her richet treaure of knowledg. It is the knowledg of this, which bringeth Honour to his name, Praie to his practice, Worth to his skill,
Plenty to his widom, Gain to his indutry, Reaon to his judgment, and a great meaure of ucces to his undertakings; hence he learns how and where to make right, oblique, and tranvere inciions; by this he finds out the Origination of the nerves, the trunks and channels of the veins and arteries; here may he find the difference between a nerve and a vein, a Tendon and a Mucle, a vein and an Artery, a Bone and a Cartilage. Thee may well convince their utility, neceity, and profit in Chirurgery.Well read in Phyick. He ought to be well read in Phyick, by which he may as well gain the knowledg of removing the caue, as the dicharge of effects; and this gives a great light to the well timing of dieaes; for outward medicines are very oft applied with little ucces, when they are not conducted with a cunning hand and a olid judgment. Beides thee a Phyician is not alwaies at hand to defend the Chirurgion, or to ait him; which hould upon neceity put him upon this excellent tudy, which gives life to his knowledg by teaching him to eradicate the growth of a ditemper. It is his bet friend at Sea, and as great aitance in the Wars, in helping him to pull down fevers, in frightning agues, in curing curvies, in dicharging
Itches, in allaying Calentures, and in bringing life, vigour, courage, and health, to his dying, weak, faint, and ick Patients. He is to be armed with Intruments both great and mall; the greater for greater ues, whilt the maller he carrieth as daily companions: but of thee you hall read more at large with their figures elewhere.The knowledg of medicine proper for him. The knowledg of Medicine is alo very proper for him, and a main wing of his Art: it is by this that he can draw and heal, dry and cloe up, repel and reolve, diget and uppurate, attract and emolliate, echarioticize and eae pain; ome of thee being proper in Tumours, whilt others are more ueful in Wounds and Ulcers, but of thee alo in their order. And when a Chirurgion hath purchaed all thee, thus furnihed, adorned, armed, educated and experienced, there remains yet omewhat to add to his excellency, as a quick ight, having an eie pointed upward to fetch down a bleing upon his practice; a nimble wit to apprehend every advantage that he may get from his Seniors; a pleaant countenance to call chearfulnes into the Patient's cheeks; a couragious pirit in things which he well undertands, and are afe, but as wary in matters of danger; prudent in his preages,
courteous in his behaviour, chat, temperate, not given to too much wine or venery; Charitable to the Poor for concience and charity, as well as to the Rich for fame and profit; furnihed with undauntednes in amputations and Lithotomy, having a teddy hand to act with evennes and without trepidancy, a hawks eie, harp and clear to look into the ditemper; dexterous at his work. He that is thus furnihed, may well aure himelf, he is in a happy etate of knowing how to remove olution of continuity, retore union, eparate parts unnaturally joined, remove uperfluous bodies, and then upply nature in her defects, taking this as his guide, < in non-Latin alphabet >
.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of Humours.
div.p:
SInce daily experience howeth, that out of Humors Tumours do take their Originals, our preent task hall be to treat of the matter of Humours, of what they are, how made, and how many they are, what good and michief they do; and then how you their Introduction
in one Scheme, their general Diviion, and then arrive at Tumours themelves. To undertand the nature and eence of a Humour, is and ought to be the work, tudy, and care of a Chirurgion, as well as a Phyician; there being no dieae with matter, which is not framed of a confued mas of Humours. It his hence that all Tumours, Wounds, Ulcers, and Fitulaes, and their differencies have their acknowledgments and ditinctions; the which is the only caue which makes both Phyicians and Chirurgions run preently to the tempering of the Blood, that is, to the correction of thoe Humours which are the occaion of thee Tumours. By Phyicians a Humour is taken for a thin and liquid body,What a humour is. flowing and cruiing in our body. Tagaultius doth call them more properly Humours, which are juices made by the Liver in the anguinary mas, for its nutrition and thinning of the blood all over our body. All thee are Choller Flegm and Melancholy, adjoined to the Blood, cattered and ent into our veins and arteries, the which the variety of their colours and conitence will make good, as Galen hath it l • b. Natur. Human. Of thee ome are natural, ome not natural. Thoe called natural, becaue o ordered according to nature, for
keeping, defending, utaining, and nourihing the life of man: Thoe counted otherwie, which act contrary to the rules of nature, and have unnatural effects. The one again being either alimentary, proper for life and growth of the body; the other excrementitious more proper for cleaning its inks and channels. As the Humour is, o alo is generally een its Colour: for as Blood is of a pure florid roy colour, o doth it give colour to the Mucles: It is this that graceth the cheeks, by affording them a a hare of its rednes: and as it is made of Chyle and Blood, o alo doth it end forth its white and red; and by how much the red exceedeth the white, by o much are the Mucles more red than the Skin. Choller is citrine and yellow, thin and griping; and as the four Humours do work man into a good humour, o this burneth him into a paion: it gives a lively paint of its colour in the Jaundies. Flegm is white and wahy, and o are they that have too much of it, being very cold and ubject to Oedematous Tumours, Dropies and Agues. Melancholy is black and masketh the whole body with an Ahy colour; this is long and tedious in executing its office, it being the mot heavy an dad part of the blood; but at
length bringeth forth the terrifying Scrophula, Corroding Cancer, Scirrhous Tumours, Quartane Agues and the like: and we daily find, when it hath hatched them up to any growth, it is very long, if ever, before it be made to part with them. Beides thee there are two others: one a erous Humour which erveth as a vehicle to the blood, ordered by nature for thinning it, that it may pas to its mallet capillary veels. Part of this is ucked up by the kidneys, where having made a hort tay it maketh its further progres into the bladder, and there remains whilt it be loaded; the which being therewith filled, is let out as ueles and unprofitable. Beides thee comes Wind taking its circuits and turns, and in our bodies is occaioned and bred by ill digetions, crudities, and wind: the former making watery Tumours, whilt this maketh latuous Tumours. But that we may well undertand the foundation of thee Humours, let us examine from whence they are bred, and whence they come.What blood is.
< in non-Latin alphabet > or Blood as it is the cheifet and of the greatet ervice for life, o ought this to take the preheminency in our dicoure.How <>
It is made from the temperate part of chyle in the tomack ent through the mall guts into the milky
veels in the meentery, whereby nature hath ordained it a Receptaculum commune, being here planted by Divine Providence as a bag for reerve, for the mot part full, from whence paeth this chyle along the great Artery jut by it, untill it reacheth the Subclavian vein; from thence it marcheth into the right ventricle of the heart by the vena cava; and from hence is carried into the left ventricle of the heart by the Arteria venoa from the lungs, and is there elaborated and made pure blood, weet of tate, and florid in colour, mild and benign. This anguification is a imilar action and performed by aimulation; and therefore taketh this chyle aforeaid as its ubject matter for this aimulation, and as they dewell together, o do they aimulate together; and this is done by proces of time, never paing to the liver, as the Ancients dreamed, for the chyle eldom or never reacheth it. This blood, as the vital liquor, is ent through the whole body by its veins and arteries, as its proper trunks and channels. And although at its firt appearance it heweth it elf pure and free, yet hath it alwaies thee three Humours adjoined to it, as three everal ubtances; as Choller, Flegm and Melancholy; ditinguihable one from
another not only in tate apour or colour, but alo in their effects: for as Galen oberveth lib. de natur. homin. the melancholy humour is acid, choller bitter, blood weet, and flegm having little or no tat; and out of thoe being benign and pure is bred Scirrhus, Eriipelas, Phlegmon, Blood hot and moit. Oedema. It is hot and moit, which are the two pecies of its natural and unnatural temper; and as Gal. lib. de Atra bile cap. 2. it is of a very red colour in its humour, and is made of the bet of juices, and o bred from the bet of tempers, made by a temperate heat; and thoe are its natural tempers. As of its unnatural, its proper ubtance is changed, as its thinner part converted into Choller, as Gal. 2. de Differ. where he aith, the thinner part is converted into yellow choller, whilt the thicker turneth into melancholy.Choller hot and dry. Next to this is choller, called by the greeks < in non-Latin alphabet > , it being a humour hot, bred out of the thinner and hotter part of the chyle and blood. It hath but few pirits, omewhat of Sulphure in it, mot of Salt and Earth. Its parvity of pirits are evident, in that it is of its own nature bitter; neither hath it in it any great quantity of Sulphure, for if we view its mae carefully, it being neither Oleaginous or pingued, neither doth
it oon take fire; yet it taketh Sulphure in it, being principally exalted by adution, whence it bred this bitternes; and although its alt excelleth in quantity, yet doth it not gain preheminence. Its flegmatick watery ubtance doth enlarge its liquid faculty; its earthly parts thickeneth it, and gives it the body it bears; its heats and drines are ufficient igns of its being an enemy to the radical moiture, and o unfit for nutriment, that it is declared by all to be excrementitious. This heat is the manifet caue of its bitternes made by a perpetual digetion of the blood;A imilitude between milk and choller. thus milk, unles oft times tirred in its boiling, oon burneth and turneth bitter, and as from heat and motion do colours change from white into red; as Quinces being pale by boiling gain a red colour, and chyle turned into blood by circulation and heat; o alo choller is as readily dicharged of its firt tate by adution and perpetual digetion. As to its ues,Its ues. Aritotle will grant it no waies ueful. Coryngius and ome others do as much cry up its value, offering that it erveth to warm the liver, and to help digetion. Helmontius calls it the balom of the blood deduced from the liver to the meentery; but this is contrary to Anatomy: for Anatomy teacheth, that this
humour is carried out from the liver, not brought into it, but onely ucked up by the Parenchyma thereof, as through a trayner. Others there are alo, as Zerbus amongt the ret, that offer, that if the bladder or gall be removed from the liver, the ubtance of the liver would oon be diolved and melted. And to conclude this, its mot proper ue is to render the excrements fluxile.What flegm is. The third is Flegm, by the Greeks called < in non-Latin alphabet > : and this alo is of two orts, natural, and not natural: The natural humour is cold, moit, crude in ubtance, white in colour, and ometimes weet in tate: that alo properly aid to be unnatural, which is void of thee, and hence doth it take its everal names; as that generally caled a thin erious Flegm, which is endewed with a waterih or windy ubtance; that called thick and glay, which is thick, vicous, and mucilaginous, and growing harder gets the name of glay flegm; if it putrify and corrode, it is called alt, eruginous and corroive flegm. Again
• legm is aid to be natural, being made in the blood not well digeted; and hence Aritotle the 6. Top. aith flegm is the firt of indigetions coming from meats; and Gal. 2. de different. feb. cap. 6. whatever humour in our body is cold and
moit, this we call flegm; Avicen Prima Primi numbreth up 8 kinds of unnatural flegm. We may well conider it in repect of its apour, and of its ubtance: of its apour, and here are three differencies, alt, weet, and owr; and its inipidnes may come in as well; but in repect of its ubtance, there may be four coupled to the former; and thee will make up Avicens 8. Every nutrition is as an aimulation, which nouriheth that by which it is nourihed: and as melancholy nouriheth the melancholly parts; o do flegm the articulations: and as this is a cold and flegmatick humour, yet in proces of time it is digeted and made blood held by ome; yet this generation is not to be allowed reciprocally, for cold cannot be made by heat, the humours by nature being rightly dipoed; therefore neither can flegm be made of blood; and o will its generation prove it elf no waies reciprocal.What melancholy. We come now to melancholy:
< in non-Latin alphabet > is aid to be either natural, or not natural. That natural which is the faeces or ediment of the blood, or the thicker part thereof, whoe colour is black, its tate owr and harp, generated for nourihing the melancholy parts. The not natural which wholly doth degenerate from its own nature; it
is a cold and dry humour ariing out of the thicker part of the chyle, whoe pecies are four.4 Species of melancholy. Firt, that is properly called a melancholy humour, in whoe proper ubtance the blood is burnt and made putrid; and hereby is made Bilis nigra, which is acid, and being poured on the ground like vinegar rieth and bubbles up. The econd is black choller, made out of the adution of the other humours. The third pecies is unnatural, ariing with a lapidous concretion. The fourth is when other humours are mixt with this; for then it puts it into its own bitter frame, and makes it a part of eroion. Gal. 2. de Temperament. cap. 3. aith the blood is the bet of all juices, and that this is as its ediment. And 3 de Prognot. here he telleth us it hath a double generation, one ariing from thick blood being as the lees of wines etling in the bottom; the other from yellow choller being much burnt, which paeth through and burns its parts. The natural is the faeces of good blood, and a uperfluity, being compared with the blood. This unnatural is not as an Hypotais and faeces, but more like a coal or cinder. Helmontius calleth the place, which is generally reputed to lodg this humour, the immediate Organ of the enative oul, of
undertanding, venery, leep, of various dieaes; but thee are merae nugae; but according to our later Anatomits it is held to erve for other ues, that it may prepare an acid juice for the fermentation of the whole mae of blood and chyle; and this acid part of the blood it draweth from the heart, and ends it prepared to the meentery, that thereby the remaining part elaborated from the liver may be more pure and perfect, as Wallaeus oberveth; and therefore as the bladder of gall is appointed by nature to be as a proper receptacle of choller trained in thither by the Parenchyma of the liver; o is this ettled and perfected in the pleen, by which the pleen it elf is made of a blackih blewih colour, and is acid. This acid humour mixeth it elf with the blood, both with the veels and chyle in the tomack, and o rendreth them more thin; for may we not oft find, the pleen being obtructed, that thick humours do coure about our bodies? not becaue thee thick humours are drawn from the pleen, but becaue it cannot communicate its attenuating acid humour to th •
blood and chyle; and whatoever of this acid humour is unfit for nutrition, it is ent out and dicharged with the erum by urine. And having given you this general
draught of the four humours, and hown you whence they are made, and for what ue, how natural and not natur • l, I will now how their everal natures, conitencies, colours, tats, and ues in this one following Scheme.

div.p: Thus have you a particular Scheme, wherein you may ee the rules of nature in well ordering thee humours. I now am to conduct you to the general diviion of praeternatural Tumours which arie from thee and the like, it being a mot excellent Pilot for conveighing you into the knowing the main of the differencies, effects, caues, igns, and preages of preternatural Tumours, or an exact Mater teaching the grounds and choice rules of curing every ort of tumour.

The other Water, and to this belongeth watery Tumours.

One bred of thick and harp choller, exact and incere; and this is called an Eryipelas with ulceration, the econd of Choller mixt with other humours; and then this Eryipelas may be termed Either
