div.p: And thus have I conducted you through the whole Garden of my firt cope: wherein you have een not onely the Origination and Antiquity, Honour, Excellency and Nobility, Learning and Vertue, the ubject Matter and Subject, the Contancy & Firmnes, the Neceity and Fruit, the Liberality and Charity, of this noble Art of Chirurgery: but alo I have hown you what this Art is, of what Parts it coniteth, and to what noble End it was framed; With thee alo have I preented to you the Chirurgion, and hown you how he ought to be furnihed, armed, qualified, and endued: After this conducted you to the true knowledg of Humours, whence they were made, for what ue, ome of which being and erving for building up our life and growth; whilt others, being planted as veels of a lower Orb, are imploied for wahing, cleaning, and keeping in decency our Channels and other Rooms: With thee have I adjoined the natures, conitencies, colour, tates, and ues of thee Humours; and have concluded this Introduction with a general diviion of Tumours, whence you may gain their everal Affects, Caues and Differencies.

I come now to enter the Stage of Tumours, where I hall act every part in its Order, concluding this Introductory dicoure with this aying of th •
Poet.
Principiis Obta: ero Medicina paratur,
Quum mala per longas invaluere moras.

div.head: OF Preternatural Tumours IN GENERAL.
CHAP. 1.
Of the names of uch Authors which have writ of Tumours in general.
div.p:
A Tumour by Falloppius is held to be a Preternatural dieae, very difficult becaue it hindreth contruction: and hence it may raie in us a diligent enquiry hereof, how this firt happened, what may be the bet and afet way to ail herein, what the bet order to oberve. But before we lanch too deep in this main Ocean, let us take and purchae uch Pilots as may afely bring us of from the Shelves and Rocks of fears and ditruts; and amongt the Graecians may Hippocrates and Galen well be call'd for aitance, who writ a Book de Tumorib. praeter naturam; and Paulus Aegi
• etta. Amongt the Latines are very few
of the Ancients. The firt is Octavus Oratianus, Cornelius Celus, the bet amongt them. Of the Arabians are Rhais, Haliabbas, Albucais, and Avicen. Amongt our late writers are Gabriel Falloppius, Hieronymus Fabritius de Aqua • Pendente, Gulielmus Placentinus, Ambroaeus Parraeus, Johannes Vigerius, Johannes de Vigo, Johannes Tagaultius and many others. Of our own tongue we have Crooke de Tumoribus & lceribus, Baniter, Read, Paul Berbet, and the like. Let thee erve as a mall Scheme of uch Authors who have already writ of Tumours, from whence we hall derive this method in our beginning of Tumours, firt acquainting you with the name of a Tumour; then its eence, and caues; then its difference and ymptomes, its igns and preages; and after thee its univeral cures both as touching general and particular Tumours. Of each of thee in their Order

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of the name of a Tumour.
div.p:
IT hath its name from the Greek < in non-Latin alphabet > , which ignifies inflammation or extutuberance; and hence by Celus and Avicen, The name of a Tumour. a Tumour is aid to ignifie a preternatural extuberance, and by Galen is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , Tumor praeter naturam; by the Aiaticks
< in non-Latin alphabet > , as it were a condened or conglobated matter; by the Arabians Apotema, which by the Greeks ignifieth an Abces, which is a ubtance converted into Pus, or as Aqua pendens calls it, an eminency of the body; this I call a preternatural dieae, in which ome parts of the body are indecently extended, being hereby unfit for performance of their proper action. Hippocrates doth chriten all Tumours with the name of Oedema. Its difinition. Galen appearing omewhat doubtful and incertain, doth ometimes reckon this amongt dieaes of the imilar, ometimes amongt the Organick parts. Haliabbas is of his Opinion. Guido defines an Apoteme a diaffection compoed of three orts of dieaes, aggregated into a bulk. And Avicen thus expounds them, ill complexion,
ill compoition, and a common olution of Continuity which is found in every Tumour. Tagaultius, after Guido, defineth an Apoteme to be, an Inflammation made in a member beyond its proper nature and form. Falloppius holdeth a preternatural Tumour to be a Dieae in magnitude, and therefore imple and onely conitent in a great extention. Fabritius de Aqua pendente, offereth a preternatural Tumour for the mot part to be a compound dieae, and taketh its denomination from that which hindereth action. Read calls it ometimes a Dieae; ometimes holds it to be a light Affection, for the mot part incident to the Organick parts encreaing their quantity by uperfluous humours. Or, if you pleae, after all thee you may take a preternatural Tumour to be, a material Intemperiety diolving the Union of the parts and ometimes hurting them in magnitude, figure and ight.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Of the Caues of Tumours.
div.p:
A Tumour is aid generally to have four caues attend it,4 Caues of Tumours. as a Material, Efficient, Formal and Final caue. By Guido the firt is called the conjunct caue: The econd, when Nature frameth any part o weak, as that it is not able and trong enough to keep the excrements of other parts out of its territory: A third caue, when any part of its ubtance is too rare or looe: & the fourth is a natural Humidity with exemplification of the part. Another caue may be aid to be the Site of the part; for the upper parts are aid to be les capable of receiving humours, than the lower part.6 Heads of T • mours by <> . Falloppins offereth ix heads, as o many Obervations of Tumours. The firt, when it begins to putrifie, it preds and extends it elf peedily, and uddenly groweth into a lump or mae. Secondly, there are Humours which • ake Tumours, and thee are either <>
or preternatural. Thirdly, when ome parts change and remove themelves <>
of their proper places into other <>
trange places, as you <> in Rupt ••••
and Diocations. A fourth is uch ••
mours as are bred of waterih <>
as Hernia Aquoa, Acitis, and the like. A fifth when vapours wind and the like either naturally or preternaturally do frame a Tumour. And the ixth is that which maketh the body unnatural to it elf, as Sanies, Excrements, and the like. But to bring this dicoure of Falloppius to one head, you may find ix Humours generally in our bodies, of which are generated thee ix Tumours, as out of Blood, Choller, Flegm, Melancholy, Wind, and Water, Phlegmon, Eryipelas, Oedema, Obervation of Falloppius. Scirrhus, Pneumatocele, Hydrocele. Beides thee we have Inects and other Animals, that very oft times are the occaions of Tumours: as Falloppius once oberved in a Maid, who having a large Tumour about the Inguen, the Chirurgion in his preence opening the ame aw it filled with Worms. Amongt the primary caues may well be reckoned Air, for out of its Contagion arieth many Tumours. Secondly, Contaction, as a cold Stone may occaion a Tumour:A Hitory. and for this Falloppius brings in another tory of a Woman, who itting upon a cold tone was afflicted with a cold Tumour. And a third may be olution of continuity, and this proveth either occult or manifet; thus after fractures we oft times find large Apo • emes to appear,
and what was the occaion of Luxation is very oft alo the occaion of Tumours; as too much contracting or binding of a part may occaion a Tumour, as Gangrene, biting of Beats, taking of offenive things inwardly, thee being ufficient matter for Humours to breed from.The caues of Tumours are either congetion or Fluxion. If a Humour do uddenly excite a Tumour, this is its evident caue, and the caue hereof is either Congetion or Fluxion.

The one when bred & carried in the part onely, whilt the other maketh its further progres by Fluxion, as Aqua pendens oberveth. And therefere as he advieth, we ought well to conider the part mit tant, and the part recipient; for the matter doth not move it elf, but is moved by ome other, as by the part mittant per
< in non-Latin alphabet > , and by the part recipient per
< in non-Latin alphabet > . The mittant part ought firt to be trong and able to expel the uperluities, as the attractive is made by the part recipient. And this bringeth me to the inward caues;Inward caues. and here ometimes the matter is hedged into one place, o that it cannot make its exit: Another may be its paage out of one place into another, and this is properly called Fluxion a Fluendo from thus • lowing; and as intemperiety is the caue of pain or olution
of Continuity, o alo is this intemperiety made either by outward or inward caues.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Of the Differencies of Tumours.
div.p:
THE true Differencies of Tumours by Aqua pendens are generally taken from thee two Fountains, as from Humours, and the depending parts; and from thee two do arie the cheif intentions in Tumours.Falloppius offers even things as touching the differencies of Tumours. Falloppius doth offer even things, which belong to the Differencies of Tumours. Firt a dieae, when it receiveth more or les: Secondly the material caue hereof diverified, and then are its Species and Differencies divere: Thirdly when the efficient caue, when manifold, doth draw many pecies to it: The fourth is the Fountain of accidents, which followeth the dieae: The fifth the time, which is the caue of all the differencies of Tumours: The ixth the ubject of the Tumour: And eventhly the motion of the dieae; for it is as its owner, and moveth as he moveth. Beides thee are we to conider of the times of dieaes; for ome are hort, ome
long, ome quick, others low; and therefore are we well to undertand their diverity of times. Hence alo are we to conider the largnes or malnes of a Tumour; and its pecies, without the knowledg of which we cannot be aid to undertand the curative method; its caues, which are conjunct with the dieae; the circumjacent parts, and the ymptoms which do follow, either from the nature or caue thereof; and latly the igns. And when we have thus far arrived, we are to conider the four great Tumours in general; as Phlegmon, it being as our firt to treat of, it proceeding of blood, the Son of nature generated for the treaure of life: Secondly, of Eryipelas, ariing from choller, the fury of the gall: Thirdly of Oedema, coming from Flegm, the proper intruments of the joynts: Fourthly of a Scirrnus, bred of Melancholy, the lumpy and terrene mae of the ret. Of every of thee are bred various Tumours, according to their various hapes and changes: but of thee in their proper places.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Of the niveral way of curing Tumours.
div.p:
HE that will undertake the curing of Tumours, ought well to undertand his curative copes and intentions; and the well timing of Tumours is a very great matter here. And here may we expect a Tumour either already made, or in its making: And hence arieth a double intention; the one prohibiting Fluxion, whilt the other cure is wrought by dicharging the matter already flown; becaue removing of caues do hinder Fluxion. If this happen from Plethory, breathing of a vein is very proper; whilt in a cachochymick body purging is as ueful. When a Tumour doth proceed from Fluxion,From whence cometh our firt intention. we are to begin our cure from the matter flowing, and hence cometh our firt intention; and this is performed by Repellers, Revellers, and Interceptives, ave onely in thee even caes et down as our even cautions by Galen. Galens 7 Cautions. Firt when the matter doth flow to the Emunctories or glandulous parts: econdly, when a venenate matter floweth; for this ends it more inwards and
o poyoneth the heart: Thirdly, when this matter floweth Critically, not croing Nature in her own way: Fourthly, when Fluxion is excited in a Cacochymick body: Fifthly, when the part, to which this matter maketh its Flux, is weak, and its heat but mean: Sixthly, when there is vehement pain, for here is more need of anodynes; and then eventhly, when this Fluxion is near ome principal part. And as touching thee curative copes, we are firt to probihit its Origination, and by this means to hinder its augment; econdly, to undertand the quality of uch things as are to be applied; for as Galen aith 13 Method. 16. we do detroy the breed of a Tumour, if we well undertand its caue; and this being ablated, the Tumour is oon een to vanih. Fluxion and congetion are the two cheif caues of Tumours; the firt offending either in Quantity or Quality, and o with violence doth eize uddainly upon any member, either by reaon of its loones or weaknes; Congetion being, when a Humour is gathered into a part gradatim by reaon of this weaknes of the digetive and expulive faculties.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
Of Phlebotomy, its manner of Operation, and where it is mot properly performed.
div.p:
IN this Dicoure we have many things do offer themelves to our conideration: As when there is a fulnes, Evacuation is in ue; and here is to be let out as much as is neceary: If there be a Plethory Quoad vires, here it is to be repeated. And as touching the part which is to have the lancet exercied on it, whether from above or below, this alo is to be minded and regarded; becaue Derivation, which Evacuation from the adjacent part doth not, agrees in the beginning of the cure; becaue this would make the Fluxion larger, and the Attraction to the part affected greater. And if we will make Revulion aright,Note. we ought well to undertand the place of Fluxion, that we may happily revell in the oppoite part: Thus if the right kidney be hurt, we open a vein in the left arm; in Tumours of the groin vena Poplitis. And if any may quetion our meaning between the upper and lower parts, Galen himelf giveth them this anwer:
All the parts above the navel, including the Liver and Stomack, are called the upper parts; and thus have we one part of the vena Cava called the acendent Trunk: the other below thee are properly called the lower parts. This knotty difference between Repulion, Revulion, and Derivation is not very eaily untied; I hall thus endeavour to looen it. Fluxion ariing from Expulion howeth expulion: if it followeth from the quantity of matter, this is either to be revoked or evacuated; and hence arieth this twofold intention, Revultion and Evacuation. This being out, another thing is to be oberved, the matter that lows hath three places, one from whence it floweth; the econd whither, and this is to the part affected; and thirdly through what parts, before it arrives hither. Thee being found out, we are to conider how to dicharge this matter, and thereby prevent its further preading; econdly we are to prevent the Fluent matter, which hath got paage into the channels, that it flow not to the part affected, and o run this alo into a Tumour. And the well conideration of thee may well make us ue tudy, where, and when to make this Revulion; and where to make evacuation. And in both of thee
we are to oberve Hippocrates Rule,Hippocrates his Rule. that all be done ecundum rectitudinem: and this is to be performed two waies, as by comparing the left with the left, and the right with the right; for with thee there is held a proper conent. Thus the Liver vein hath a rectitude with thoe veins which acend up to the head. Thus upon an immoderate Flux at the right notril by applying a cupping glas to the Region of the Liver, the Flux doth uddenly top; if the left, by applying one to the pleen doth work and perform the ame effects. Galen hath alo two pecies of Revulion, the one from the upper parts to the lower, from the right to the left; the econd not o exact, which we ue when the matter is much, and threatens danger. Galen alo in dieaes of the upper parts doth revel by opening the upper veins, as in Tumours of the head he doth order the Cephalick vein to be opened: and Falloppius aith in a Squinancy he hath breathed the left arm, and the Humour preently vanihed; and in ome caes this is very proper. In Tumours of the Axillaries being venenate, if we hould open the lower veins we mut conequently draw its venome inwards to the heart; and vice vera, if we hould open the upper veins
in a petilential Bubo, we may well make a free paage for the petiferous matter to make its addres to the heart, which is not onely a great fault in the Chirurgion, but alo as unhappy to the Patient. And thus have I hown ome of its benefits. I now come to teach the young Chirurgion how he is to ue his Lancet,How the young Chirurgion hould open a vein. and prepare himelf for this Operation. Firt let him make a pretty trict bandage, a little above the elbow of that arm which he intends to bleed; not too trict, becaue he will very eldome hereupon but meet with obtruction in bleeding, the Artery being too cloe girt that it cannot dicharge it elf into the vein. And as to his Lancet, let him make his apertion a little loping; or upon placing it a little obliquely, let him get his Lancet into the vein, and o lift it up, not penetrating too deep, let he commit thoe errours which daily are acted by ignorant Pretenders and Quackes, who oft go o deep, as that they prick an Artery, and o caue Aneurims and pains. Let the Orifice that you make, be neither too great or too mall; the firt endangering the Diviion of the vein, whilt the econd runs it into a Tumour. Here alo is he to judg of the goodnes or badnes of the Blood, and o according to his judgment
may take away more or les; and alo conidering the neceity of the dieae, the trength of the Patient, and the quantity and quality of the Blood. The veins which are generally opened are thee the Frontal vein, one under the Tongue, the Cephalick, Mediana and Bailick; but of every of thoe in their order, and as neceity requireth. The Frontel vein is mot properly opened in infirmities of the Face, and in pains of the Head. Two veins of the Temples opened in continual Head-ach, in ditillations of the Head and Eies. The veins under the Tongue in Anginaes, Apoplexies, pains of the Teeth, the Jugulars, good in preventing uffocation, Squinies, Athmaes, Dypnaea and the like. The three in the Arm, the firt being the outward or Cephalick, this may afely be opened in ditempers of the head, as Mania and other hot paions; The econd Mediana, o called in repect of its Scituation, being made both of the Cephalick and Bailick vein, in opening of this vein is made a general evacuation of Humours; this oft times opened in pains of the breat, and Pleuriies. The third is Bailica, or Hepatica, by ome called Axillaris, this dichargeth thoe parts which are beneath the Neck, as the Brets, Sides,
Liver, Spleen, and Pleuriies. And this note of the three in all icknees, and times, except in time of Petilence, That vein is to be taken, which is mot full and large. In the Feet alo are three veins Ichiatiea, Saphaena, and vena Poplitis: thee or ome of them are generally opened in Obtruction of the Montrues, in bringing them down, pains, toppings, wellings and the like. I hall conclude this with thee directions. In an Apoplexy open the Cephalick vein; if this appears not, open the Mediana: In a Lethargy open the Frontal or Cephalick vein: In a Squiney thoe under the Tongue: In a Pleurify the Bailica, and here bleed while the Blood doth change its colour: In dieaes of the Lungs vena Axillaris or Mediana: In inflammations of the Liver Bailica or Hepatica: In obtruction of the Spleen the Bailick or Hemorrhoidal veins: In dieaes of the Womb the Sciatick vein: In retraint of Mentrues Saphaena: In pains of the Hips firt open the Bailica, then the outward malcolus below.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
Of Evacuation of matter erring in Quality.
div.p:
IF a Tumour or Fluxion happeneth in repect of matter not onely erring in Quantity, but alo in repect of Quality, that this may be dicharged we are to conider two things: Firt, whether this matter may be altered, as if hot cooled, &c. Secondly to remove the ubject matter hereof, and in the firt, if Plethory, Phlebotomy is proper; if les, Pharmacy is mot convenient: And herein are we to oberve thee two Rules, that the matter may firt be educed or ent forth being contrary to the true genus of the part, and then, if it doth till remain, to alter it. The mot proper way to deal with this is by our later writers found out, which is by dicharging the body hereof by purging Medicines, which do work both quickly and afely, ordering the trength of the Medicine according to the vigour and trength of the Patient:If the thin matter cannot be digeted, it is to be revelled; and bow this as to be done. and herein alo are we to mind the motion of the Blood; for if it doth move to the eies, this is to be revelled, firt by Cuppingglaes without Scarrification, Secondly
that the parts ought to be rubbed for the better thinning the Humour, thirdly frictions which are proper for revelling from the Center to the Circumference; And Galen nameth the lat when parts are obtructed, we ought to obtruct with Medicines; but thee are tedious, painful, and troubleome. Our later Writers have found out better means and methods, as by wahing with warm water, which doth revell by opening the pores; another ort is by veicatories, and thee are in great ue in Apoplexies,Obervat. Rheumatims, or Ditillations; the third and lat is an actual Cautery and Fontinels, and Setons very much in ue in our times. And in all thee we are to oberve, that Revulion doth take its indication from that part from whence the Humour loweth, not from the Humour flowing, and this being known we are to undertand the parts which we are to revell.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
Of a Tumour, the part affected drawing to it elf Preternatural Bodies.
div.p:
THE greatet occaion or caue of attraction in a Tumour of a preternatural body is cheifly to be attributed to Laxity and Intemperiety of the part, and pain. This Intemperiety is therefore firt to be removed, by running it into a better temper. And this may be executed with oyl of Roes, Violets and the like, having fine linnen rags dipt therein and o applied; and thee are oft to be repeated to prevent inflammation: For this ue alo nguent. Roatum Refrigerans Galeni, Populcon, Album Camphoratum. If pain occaioneth this, we are here to give eae by Anodynes according to Galen 13. Meth. 1. and if any preternatural bodies offend, dicharge them, either by Medicine or Intrument: if pain cometh from venome, cure this as you do venomed bodies; and herein alo are you to conider the times of the poyon, for the longer it hath got room and entrance, the deeper doth it imprint its venomous Qualities and Effects. In this cae Venice Treacle, Methridate and the
like, are very good, Spirit of Wine, here alo is very proper. And thus are we to vary our methods according to the variety of our Objects. In venenate ditempers, in cold poyons, we ue hot Medicines; and in hot poyons on the contrary, cold Medicines, as Rue, Frogs, Scordium and the like, commended by Diocorides. Galen doth furnih us with many pleaant tories of poyon, and amongt the ret, he doth offer, that if any be bitten with a Scorpion, if the ame Scorpion be taken, opened, and applied to the part affected, it draweth out its own poyon.Obervat. This generally being here oberved, that before you apply any Medicine to the poyoned part, you firt well foment the part with a hot and harp Lixivium; and when the place beginneth to grow red, to apply your other Medicines, as for example.

. A Lixivium. Fob. Abynth. Scord. Rut. Angelic. Hyperic. Salv. Agrimon. Veronic. au. M. j. Roar. Rubr. m. . Scabios. Menth. Meli. an. p. ij. coquantur omnia in Lixivio q. . colaturae adde Spirit. vini lbj. with this foment the part, and then may you ue uch proper and mundifying Medicines as are mot requiite, as . rguent.Urguent. Bailicon. Bu •• r. recent. au. , Ol. Amygdal Dulc. j. Theriac. Andromach.
j. cum Vitel. Ovor. nov. ij. mice, fiat nguent. Or this. . Pulv. Mirrh. Alo. Aritoloch. Rot. Irid. Florentin. Angelic. an. 3j. Theriac. olut. in aqu. vitae 3j. cum mel. q. . fiat unguent. Or this. . Columbin. i. Aritoloch. rotund. Dictam. Creten. an. 3j. Ol. Lilior. q. . fiat Empl. If all thee fail, apply live Pigeons opened to the part affected; and if thee do not anwer expectation, make a peedy addres to the actual Cautery. If made by loones of a part. Another caue hereof is loones of the paages, the which, unles they be topped, do make a Tumour: as if an Humour do flow out of everal parts of the body into one particular part, unles this be altered, it is very eaily raied up into a Tumour; if this happeneth with an Intemperiety, we are to mix retringents with coolers, as thus in Fluxes of the Head, take this for a defenative.

. Unguent. Pulv. Roar. rubr. Myrtillor. Balaust. Gallar. Matich. Sang. Dracon. Bol. Armen. Oliband. Santal. omnium an. 3j. Ol. Roar. q. . Cer. alb. parum Acet. roat. . mice & coquantur omnia ad aceti conumptionem, his addere pois albumin. Ovor. no. j. vel ij. Or this. . Pulv. Santal. omn. Sangu. Dracon. Bol. Armen. Pic. Colophon. an 3j. his adde Empl.Empl. Diapalm. j. Acet. 3j. mice, fiat Empl. And thee are proper Medicines here, and by Galen called trengthening as well as retringent Medicines, becaue they trengthen by compreion, as Gal. 2. ad Glauc. 14. And having thus paed over the general Indications ariing from the matter of a Tumour, and its curative copes as Phlebotomy and Pharmacy, we come now to treat of the four times of Tumours.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Of the four times of a Tumour, and firt of its beginning.
div.p:
THE knowledg of thee times are very proper for our Diagnois, Prognois, and Cure. They are four in number, Beginning, Augment, State, and Declination. That time mot properly called the Beginning, when a part begins to tumefy: thus if a Tumour be made in a recipient part, Expulion and Repercuion is the Intention; and this Repercuion is nothing ele but Illiion and Impulion of the Humour, which floweth either from the whole body or ome part thereof into the affected part. This Repulion is a double motion from the part hurt, and from another part ending to this hurt part. And here we are to advie, that when members are looe and oft, then are we to trengthen with Medicines of a contrary affect,Obervat. that is with uch Medicines as are compact and dry. Gal. 14. Meth. cap. 17. aith that pure cold things do repel, as cold water; and he there adds that others which are not cold yet are retringent, as Mint, Roes, Wormwood and the like, and thee he
aies do repel: thee for the mot part are to be ued in the beginnings of Tumours, but not alwaies in every kind of Tumour; For experience teacheth us that in Petilential or Venereal Buboes,Obervat: if in the beginning we hould apply repelling Medicines, we hould end the peccant matter to the heart.In 6 caes no Repelling Medidicines to be applied in the beginning: In thee ix caes apply no Repellers in the beginning: as if it be bred by a venenate matter, and repelling here you oon do hut up the doors of life. If the matter be critical, yet this doth not alwaies deny Repulion; for in a violent Fever, in which it happeneth that the matter doth end it elf to the membranes of the brain, in this critical cae the Fluent matter is to be repelled, let otherwie the brain becometh inflamed. And then when this Tumour happeneth either in a Cacochymick or Plethorick body. When the matter loweth to the emunctories, we are not to repel, as Galen advieth 6. de Comp. per loc. cap. 2. Then when the part into which this Tumour hath got footing groweth weak, as Galen alo hath it, Meth. 13. cap. 7. And latly when pain and exaperation of the part is preent, for then Anodynes are more proper, as Galen citeth 6. de Comp. Medic. thee I have formerly hown you in the differencies
of Tumours; but this being their more proper place to bring them into, I have alo here given you their brief repetition, and in all other caues we may and ought to come to ue Repellers in the beginning of Tumours. Avicen peaking of repelling Medicines ordereth us not alwaies to ue one ort or kind thereof, but in cold caes to ue hot Repellers, and in hot caes to ue cooling Repellers. Now if pain arieth in the beginning, and draweth omewhat of Humour to it, here are you to ue mild Repellers, thee being of a ufficient capacity to lenify the parts being tirred up by pain. Such are Lettuce, Purlain, Trifole, Nighthade, Endive, Violets, and Plantane; thee being endued with a waterih moiture do much better in this cae, than uch which are two atringent. And out of thee may you frame many orts of Medicines by adding thereto Oyl, Water, Vinegar, and the like. And of thee may you make tronger or weaker Medicines as occaion may require: as, . Malvar. Parietar. Plantag. an. Cataplama
M. j. coquantur in aqu. fontin. & contuis adde farinae Fabarum, Hor dei an. i. Pul. Roar. rubr. . Ol. Chamomeli. iiij. cum decocti. praedicti q. . addendo fl. Chamomel. Melilot. in pulv. a
j. fiat Cataplama tepide admovendum.

div.head: CHAP. X.
Of a Tumour in its augment.
div.p:
THE Augment of an Inflammation or Tumour, as Gal. hath it cap. 4. lib. de Morb. Tempor. is, when the Influx hath ceaed, and the part affected Tumefies more than it did formerly. And the reaon hereof by Aquapendens is, becaue the blood prolaped out of the veels doth necearily grow hot and putrify, whence the blood is poured out and converted into a Spirit. A •• cen aith that the Augment is then mot properly to be o called, when the Tumour encreaeth o that it is extended. We may know when Tumours have arrived at their Augment by their caues and Symptoms, by comparing its times; and therefore here our intention is two-fold, for that ome part hath already made its Flux, and other part is till to make; and this requires two copes, to remove the compacted matter, and that we take away the caue hereof. We have already dicoured of Repulion, we
more properly in this place and time peak of Digetion or Dicuion.Here Digetives are mot proper. This Digetion is an Evacuation of a thin matter gathered in a part by inenible Evaporation, procured by the natural heat, encreaed by proportionate Medicines. And this is aid to be performed four waies:Four waies of digetion. for firt, the Humour is to be made thin, then reolved into a Vapour, afterwards drawn from the Center to the Circumference, and latly expelled or thrown forth by the pores of the Skin; and thee therefore do how that the proper Medicine to be here ued is to be a Digetive, a Medicine hot and dry in the third degree, and of thin parts. Of thee Digetives ome are mild, ome trong; ome imple, others compound. Of the imples are Dill, Rue, Chamomile, Ammoniacum, Galbanum, white Lillies, Lupines, Fenugreek and the like. Such as are tronger are Time, Origanum, Mint, Pennyroial, Hyop, and the like. Of the tronget ort are Sulphur vivum and Chalk, &c. Of the compounds. . Malv. Dialth. Abynth. Lilior. Albor. an. M. i. coquantur in aqu. fontin. q. . colaturae adde Pulv. Roar. Rubr. ij. Pulv. Abynth. Puleg. Fl. Chamomel. Melilot. Catapl. an. ij. farin. fabar. Lupinar. Hord. an. i. cum ol. Chamomel. iij.
mice, fiat Cataplama. Ever oberving this,Oberv: that according to the trength, Age, Temper, and Contitution, of your Patient, you endeavour to regulate and order your Medicines. If the former will not erve, you may make ue of this Empl. . Farin. Fabar. i. Farin. em. lin. ij. Empl. de mucilaginib. i. Melilot. . Pulv. Sem. Cumin. Abynth. a. i. cum Ol. Chamomel. q. . fiat Empl. Or this. . Fol. Mal. Alth. Violar. an. M. Catapl: i. Rad. Alth. Irid. Lilior. Alb. an. . fl. melilot. Chamomel. Aneth. an. p. i. Cumin. i. Bacc. Laur. ij. Croc. i. cum Adipe Anatis Anerini Butyri recentis ol. Lilior. an. i. M. fiat Catapl. Or this of Aquapendens. . Myrtillor. Lactuc. Catapl: Solan. a. M. i. Puleg. Calamenth. Hiop. an. M. . coctis & in aqua contuis adde Farin. Faenugraec. iij. Pul. Betonic. Chamomel. an. i. ol. Anethi Chamomeli a. iij. cum decocto praedicto fiat Cataplama.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
Of a Tumour in its State.
div.p:
THEN is it properly aid to be in its State, when it can reach to no higher degree, the beginning of this State doth carry with it ome rellih of the Augment; and here therefore are Anodynes and Digetives proper being equally mixed. In its middle you are to mix more of the Digetives; and at lat to ue Digetives altogether. It is in this tate, that the matter is very near digeted and converted into Pus. And thee have harp Symptoms attend them: for while this pus is making, there are Fever and pain as two ineparable companions that go along with it, thee in its declination taking their leave with the Tumour.Obervat: And this we are to oberve, that when nature digeteth, we ought to help her forward in her deigns. But a Tumour is very oft times een to terminate into many other dieaes; and herein we are to conider the Pulation, if it hath been long, if pain be not diminihed, when the heat endures, then is its tranition to be expected; and where any one of thee are, it is an evident ign there is
matter at hand, againt which we mut be prepared, and o mind the ymptoms, as Pain, Tenion, Hardnes, Heat; for thee are toubleome companions, and then are we to ait nature in the dicharge hereof, taking away their caues: which is to be performed by Medicines, as this or the like.
<…> . . Ol. Chamomel. Roar. a. iij. farin. fabar. pul. fl. Chamomel. an. ij. Hyop. i. Sapae dulciim. 10. mice, fiat unguent. Or this Catapl. . Lapath. Parictar. Chamomel. Melilot. Catapl. an. M • . Roar. Rubr. pug. i. fl. Melilot. Chamomel. an. p. i. farin. H • rd. pug. iij. cum. . q. aquae fontinae, fiat Catapl. Catapl. Or this. . Fl. Chamomel. Melilot. an. pug. ij. Herb. Chamomel. M. i. Coquantur omnia cum Radic. Lilior. Albor. iiij. & imul contuis adde farin. faenugraec. ij. ol. Aneth. Chamomel. an. ij. Vini albi. q. . fiat Catapl.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
Of a Tumour in its Declination.
div.p: WHEN all the former Symptoms do abate and ceae, then we generally hold we have arrived at the Termination: and here according to Gal. cap. 1. lib. 2. < in non-Latin alphabet > . we are to ue purely Digetives or Dicuives; and thee are to be o much the tronger, the declination of the inflammation being in its progres. And in this part thee two Cataplams are very proper. . Hyop. Origan. an. M. i. coquantur in vino albo, & imul contuis adde Ol.Catapl: Lilior. Albor. iiij. Pulv. Puleg. Abinth. an. . Farin. Faenugraec. i. mice, fiat Cataplama. Or this. Alth. Malv. an. M. i. fl. Chamomel. Melilot. Roar. Rubr. an.Catapl: pug. i. Rad. Lilior. & Alth. an. i. Sem. Lin. faenugraec. an. . Ficuum pingu. no. 10. furfur. farin. hord. tritic. an. pug. ij. contua coquantur in aqua ad mellis craitudinem, fine addendo ol. Chamomel. Axung. Porcin. an. i. mice, fiat Catapl.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
Of a Tumour tending to Suppuration.
div.p:
THE true waies and methods of curing Tumours we have already hown; but it oft times doth happen that a Tumour doth tend to uppuration, that is the influxed Blood is converted into pus or matter; whence doth arie another method of curing. And here Galen doth propoe two waies, which are performed either by Digetion or Concoction: but the firt is the bet; for thee two things follow concoction, two much generation of this matter, and an Abces made hereof into another place. In repect of its generation its long in curing: in repect of the Abces the Inflammation oft times doth run it elf into another dieae; as oft times into a Gangrene as Jubertus, oberved in the wife of Rondeletius. As touching the efficient caue of Purity or Matter,The efficient caue of matter. Gal. offereth lib. de inaequ. intemper. cap. 3. that in an inflamed part there is found both a native and an extraneous heat; the firt preerving the part, and doth adminiter uch things to it as belong to its health and welfare;
the other Extraneous, arieth from the influxed Blood, prolaped out of the veels, and there putrifying, this being contrary to the former, and o doth detroy and pull down or extinguih the natural heat. The firt matter is thick, laudable, white, equal, well tated; but if the other prevail, it appears livid, red or black, thin, inequal, grumous. The Tumour offers it as a ign of its tending to uppuration by its intenenes;Signs of Suppuration. and when the inflammation is great, and the pain vehement and doth daily encreae, and when pulation joins with this Tenion and this be large, when thee igns are at hand, ue neither repelling Medicines nor Digetives; but ue your greatet care to ait nature in her progres of uppuration by maturating Medicines, that is, to prepare the matter and make it fit for expulion, and then to dicharge it when we have thus prepared it. And that therefore we may procure the Tumour for this uppuration, and produce a good and laudable matter, we are to encreae this Quantity of native heat, by uch Medicines as are of a digeting faculty, the which ought to be of the native heat with the part. Thee are to be applied from the beginning of the Augment to the end
of the vigour. Some of thee are imple, as Marhmallows, • iggs, Chamomile, Galbanum, Bdellium, Ammoniacum, Hogs lard, Gooe greae, and the like. Of the compound may be reckoned Empl. Diachylon cum gummi, de Mucilag. Flo. nguentorum, or ome of thee Emplaters or Cataplams: Of which for this ue thee may be applied very properly.

Ficuum pag. iij. em. lin. faenugraec. an. iij. fiat decoctum in vino albo q. . & colaturae adde Vit • ll Ovor. no. ij. Croc. . Ol. Cham. Melilot. an. Catap • . ij. mice, fiat Cataplama. Or. . Rad. & fol. Alth. Malv. an. M. i. Coquantur, & pit •• tur ut artis et, quibus adde • arin. Tritic. ij. farin. em. Lin. • e ••
graec. an. i. Butyr. recent. • l. Lili • r • . alb. nguent. Dialth. an. i. Croc. . vitell. ovor. no. ij. mice, fiat Catapl. The matter by thee, orany of thee, or
the like being brought to Suppuration, this is to be dicharged, and this generally is to be performed by Inciion or Cautick. And before we attempt either of thee, we are well to undertand whether it be ripe enough,A method to find whether a Tumour be ripe enough to open. and this you may thus find out. The Tumour at this time eeming by contracting it elf to appear les than it was in its tate, then it draweth it elf to a point, its hardnes is much abated, and therefore dicued, and by touching it with the finger we find it Fluctuatous, the heat and pain ceaeth, the part is changed in its colour, the Cuticula is hriveled, all thee being good igns of its Suppuration. This not being all drawn out, you are to arm your Tents or Pledgets with this or the like. . Terebinth. Venet. i. Mell. ij. ucc. Ap. . Farin. Fabar. v. mice, fiat Linimentum. After the Application of which apply Diachylon cum gummi or Empl. de Mucilaginibus. All thee being dicharged, and the Orifice being well mundified and deterged, your next buines is by the helps of Sarcoticks to fill up with fleh, as nguent. Bailicon. Aureum, and the like, and then with Epouloticks to induce a Cicatrice as with
nguent. Diapompholigos, Deiccativum, Rubrum, Sanativum, or Diapalma.
And thus have I run through the four times of a Tumour; and becaue a Phlegmon doth bear the greatet hare in thee four times and orderings, I hall be much briefer in its dicoure and o proceed.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.
Of a Phlegmon or Inflammation in General.
div.p:
IT is by all Authors granted that a Phlegmon hath its four times, and that out of Blood beides this doth arie everal other Tumours, as a Carbuncle, Gangrene, Sphacelus, Pernio, Phyma, Phygethlon and everal others. And here let us firt inquire what a Phlegmon is,What a Phlegmon is. and whence derived. It taketh its name
< in non-Latin alphabet > , which ignifieth to inflame. This is an Intemperiety not only of the imple but alo of the Organick parts, as Galen oberveth in 13. Meth. Our latter Writers do make two ditinctions about the material caue hereof, the Blood being either natural or not natural; the natural furnihed with thee conditions, being of the ame Blood with that which cometh from the Sanguinary mas, having
in it the four Humours and thee Qualities, as being hot in action, and moit in conitence, in colour red, in tate weet; the unnatural being denied of thee good Qualities, and alo deveted and deprived hereof.Whence it arieth. Thus out of pure and benign Blood arieth an exquiite Phelgmon: if this Tumour hath any other humours annexed or joined to it, it occaioneth a various pecies of Inflammation; as having Choller admixed, it maketh Phlegmon Eryipelatodes; if Flegm, Phlegmon Oedematodes; if melancholy, Phlegmon Scirrhodes. Beides thee alo, other accidents belong to Inflammation; for if an inflammation doth get into the membranes of the brain, it maketh Phrenitis; when it creepeth into the Tunica conjunctiva, there it frameth Opthalmia; when into the Fauces, Angina; into the Pleura, Pleuritis, and o into the Emunctuories, Bubo. Its caues may arie either inwards or outwards:Its caues: Inward caues are Plethory or plenty of Blood; and this not having its free paage mut necearily inflame and putrify, inflamed heat in the Sanguinary mae, and this oft times doth exalt it elf into Fevers, the part hot and painful doth draw the Blood, and this maketh up the Inflammation. Outward caues
may be aid to be Aires, which do inculcate and hut in this putrid matter; Attrition, Attraction, olution of Continuity or Luxation,Signs: thee or any of thee cauing pain and o Inflammation. As to the igns, when you perceive a Tumour is oon made, and doth oon encreae, you may properly judge this an Inflammation; when the patient doth perceive a great heat, and burning ariing from this heat, the colour of the part Florid and Red occaioned by heat and thinnes of parts, pain great, and a pulation joined to this pain, by reaon of its hot intemperiety, when any part extendeth it elf upon compreion, aggravation, and vellication of the nervous parts, and the veins evidently appear, which before lay hid, when Tenion is made by reaon of the contipated matter, all thee are ufficient igns which may pretend to paint out Inflammation. I hall follow Guido's method in the cure of Inflammations;Of the cure of a Phlegmon as firt by removing the caue, then come to the Inflammation it elf, and o to the dicharging of the peccant matter: And for this he propounds four methods,Four methods according to four times by Guido. according to the four times; and whereas a Phlegmon hath a Beginning while the Blood is nowing, an Augment when in its Flux it is
made hotter, a State when it is converted into Pus or Matter, and a Declination when the Inflammation is digeted, reolved, and the Tumour diminihed: So alo the four Intentions hall be thee, firt in having a repect to the order of diet, econdly to hinder the Flux of Humours, thirdly to dicharge the Matter, and then latly to correct and amend the Symptoms. The firt doth conit in moderating the Air, and this more properly in a long inflammation: the econd is eae and quiet, becaue too much motion heateth the body: the third is watching and leep; for as the one doth put our bodies into action, o the other doth refreh and cool them: the fourth and lat is order of diet: a fifth may be added, which is retention or inanition of excrements; for hard and dry excrements do obtruct, and hence are bred harp and malign vapours, which do coure through the whole body, and do render the inflammation more dangerous; and then actions of the mind may take a part here alo. The whole cure may be performed by Diet, Pharmacy, and Chirurgery. Diet for prohibiting Inflammation of uperfluous Humours and their generation, and making them more unfit for Fluxion; and here
the Patient's diet hould be thin,His diet. moit and moderately cooling: as broths wherein are boiled Lettuce, Borage, Buglos, Spinage, Purlain, or Marigolds; if in Summer time, our green auce (as we call it) is very good being made of Sorrel; if he will drink wine, let him mix it with three parts of water to one wine. Fluxion is dicharged, if we dimis its caues, as Plethory, and Cacochymy; and thee may be leened either by Phlebotomy or Pharmacy. If the Inflammation be large, and the Patient young, trong, and full of Blood, we may afely breath a vein:Obervat. and here we are to oberve, that we breath not a vein too far ditant from the part affected, both for Revulion and Derivation; the firt being to be made in the oppoite part, whilt the econd is made in the ame ide near the part affected. And ince the body is een eldome o clean, but that there is ome ill humours or other mixtures with the Blood, purging alo is here aid to be convenient; and for this cae Caia newly extracted, Tamarinds, Sebetins, and Syrup of Roes are very excellent: or if you pleae to take any of thee, as for Electuaries, Bolus, or purging potions. As . Electuar. Diacatholic. vi. Lenitiv. . Ca. recent.
extr.Electuary. i. pul. Diaenn. i. Cremor. Tartar. ij. mice, and of this let the patient take the quantity of a Chenut every morning: or this Bolus. . Caiae recenter. extr. i. pulp. Tamarind. . mice, Bolus. & cum Saccharo fiat Bolus. Or this Potion.Potio. . Aqu. Endiv. Fumar. Cichor. an. i. Aq. Roar. Damac. vi. Electuar. Diacathol. vi. Electuar. è Suc. Roar. 3ij. Crem. Tartar. . mice, fiat potio mane umenda. The body being thus dicharged, cooling Syrups, Electuaries or Trochices are very properly to be ued, as Syrup of Violets, Roes, Mirtills, Poppies, Wood-orrel, or the like; or thee following,Troch. , Spec. Diarrhod. abbat. ij. Aromatic Roat. Troch. de Rhabarb. an. i. Sacchar. candit. olut. in Decoct. Agrimon. Veronic. iiij. mice, fiant Trochici. Of which let the patient take a dram or two a little before Dinner. An Electuary for this ue may be this,Electuary: . Con. Roar. Rubr. Violar. an. ij. Conerv. Lujul. Parali. an. i. cum Syrup. Oxyacanth. Granator. Violar. an. . mice, fiat Electuarium, of which let the patient take the quantity of a Nutmeg at his pleaure. Clyters alo may be very neceary; and of thee may this very ucceively be adminitred. .Clyters: Rad. & Fol. Malv. Alth.
Parietar. iolar. Agrimon. Veronic. an. M. i. fl. Melilot. Chamomel. an. M. . em. Ani. Faenicul. dulc. an. . em. Faenugraec. Lin. an. ij. coquantur in . q. aqu. fontinae ad lbi. colaturae adde Sacchar. rubr. ij. Diacatholic. i. Sal. Commun. pug. i. Ol. Violar. Roar. an. i. Purging potion. mice fiat Enema. Or this purging potion. . Herb. Agrimon. Veronic. Cucuth. Scabio. an. M. . em. Ani. Faenicul. an. ij. Liquirit. ra. . coquantur in . q. aqu. fontinae ad iiij. colaturae adde Electuar. Diacatholic. vi. Syr. Roar. olutivar. cum Rhabarb. i. mice, fiat potio: thee being all managed with a prudent conduct according to the variety of occaions. We arrive next to the part affected,Revulion: and this is to be dealt with by Revulives, Interceptives and Repellers.Revulion. And as I have already declared that Revulion is made in the oppoite part, o uch things as are here mot requiite are to be hot and attractive; of this ort are fomentations, made of Sage, Chamomile, Calamint, Hyop, Lavender, Pennyroial, Dill, Tyme, and the like; thee being boiled in water, and applied very hot, until the part looketh red. Lixiviums alo are here very convenient,Veicat •
ries. and Veicatories, epecially if the Humour be
fierce and plentiful, as in Inflammations of the eies, thee being to be applied to the neck. Aqua pendens gives us this as the bet Epipatick. . Cantharid. praeparat. i. em. Sinap. i. Ferment. . Defenatives. Aceti Scillitic. q. . fiat veicatorium. After thee Defenatives are to be chiefly ued, thee being mot properly aid to be for hindring of Fluxion, being in Quality cold and dry, fit for contracting the veels: as . Bol. armen. Sangu. dracon. Matich. an. ij. Empl. Diapalm. ij. mice, expande uper corio, and apply it. A tronger than this, is . Bol. armen. Sangu. dracon. Mirtill. Balaut. cort. Granator. Coral. rubr. Sus Cin. an. . Farin. Tritic. ij. album. Ovor. no. i. cum Aceti & Olei q. . fiat Retrictivum. Oberv. To prevent all mitakes and errors we are to be well advied, that after Application of thee Medicines we commit not that error which is too common amongt ome Chirurgions, who roll trictly upon the affected part, not conidering thereby that they both do detain the Humours, and oft times by this their ignorance or carelenes they make a fair way for the invaion of a Gangrene into the part. The third and lat way is by Repellers performed,Repellers. and their cheif ue is to hinder
the Fluxion of any Humour to the part affected. Thee hould be cold in Quality; and o hould alo be either moit and waterih, or dry and retringent: and of thee ome may be Plantane, Balautines, Roes, Dragons blood, Whites of Eggs, Vinegar, Bolarmeny, Myrtles, and the like, as thus. . Aceti Roati. Catapl. iiij. Album. Ovor. no. ij. Bol. armen. angu. Dracon. an. ij. Pulv. Myrtillor. Roar. rubr. an. i. mice, fiat Cataplama. Or this, . ucc. Semperviv. Portulac. Plantag. an. i. Acet. Roat. Vin. Rubr. an. i. Ol. Myrtin. Unguent. Roar. an. i. pulv. Myrtillor. Roar. Balaut. Bitort. an. i. mice, fiat unguentum. Oberv. And this thing we are to oberve, that thee repelling Medicines, by how much they do intercept, they are not to be applied to the affected part, but onely about it encompaing it. And this may erve for curing of Phlegmons in General. We come next to treat of the curing of Phlegmones according to the everal times.

div.head: CHAP. XV.
Of curing a Phlegmon in its beginning.
div.p:
IN the beginning of a Phlegmon, repelling Medicines are mot proper, as Galen doth offer, for hindring or topping, the matters decent or arriving to the part affected.Quetion. But let any may object, as Aquapendens doth propoe, why in the beginning, the Blood being in the maller and capillary veels, may we not inenibly evacuate this matter by the affected part, as by digeting it, and drawing it out from other parts, and by attenuating and turning it into a vapour, Repellers being wholly dimit? I give, being led by the ame Author, this as an anwer,Anwer. we are rather to ue Repellers in the beginning of an Inflammation for thee caues.By everal reaons. For firt, that which floweth is but mall and thin, and therefore by the help of Repelling Medicine we end this Fluxed matter to another part. Secondly, becaue Evacuation by Repulion is ooner performed, for it is by this Medicine alone that the Blood is ent and dimied out of the maller into the greater veels. And thirdly, by thee we do perform another
intention,Their ue and benefit. which is the allaying the extraneous heat. And thee are to be regulated according to the Criis of the body; for if there be a hot criis both of the whole and the affected part, here are we to ue mild and gentle Repellers, as the white of an Egg, Roewater, and Vinegar, and oyl of Roes, leaving out the Vinegar if you pleae, dipping fine rags herein and applying them to the affected part:Catapl: Or this Cataplam, . Pulv. Roar. i. Farin. Hord. ij. coquantur in Pocâ & fine addendo parum ol. Roar. As alo on the contrary, if the criis be cold, the Inflammation large, we are to ue tronger; and let this erve for a reaon hereof, becaue here is ignified a great plenty of Blood, and here conveniently may be ued thee following,Unguent. Another . nguent. Roat. lot. in aqu. Plantag. pulv. Roar. Plantag. an. ij. Aceti parum, fiat unguent. Or this. . Ol Roar. i. Aqu. Roar. i. Albumin. ovor. no. ij. mice, or this Cataplam, . farin. Hord. ij. pulv. Roar. Plantag. Catapl. Unguent: Malicor. an. i. cum uccis Semperviv. Lactuc. & Solan. Oxycrat. an. q. . fiat Cataplama. Or this Unguent. . Mucilag. em. Pyll. extr. cum aqu. Plantag. & Acet. Roar. iiij. ucc. Plantag. Solan. an. . ol. Roar.
i. coquantur ad uccorum conumptionem, fine addendo uguent. Roat. i. mice, Catapl: fiat unguent. Or this, . Lactuc. Malv. Plantag. an. M. . Semperviv. M. i. Coquantur in Oxycrat. q. . fiat Catapl. fine addendo pulv. Roar. Rubr. Plantag. cort. Granator. an. ij. Farin. Hord. iiij. mice, fiat Cataplama; but if the beginning doth turn towards the Augment, then may you ue this, . Malvar. parietar. Plantag. an. M. i. coquantur in aqua & contuis adde farin. Hord. ij. pulv. Roar. R. fl. Chamomel. Melilot. an. . ol. Chamomel. iiij. mice cum decocti praedicti q. . fiat. Catapl. This here alo is to be oberved, that thee Medicines be oft times changed, let they do inflame the affected part.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.
Of Curing a Phlegmon in its Augment.
div.p:
GAlen. cap. 4. lib. de Morbis, doth mention that for the Augment, when the Flux ceaeth, and the part eemeth more affected than it was formerly, and therewith increaeth; and the reaon hereof may be this, becaue the Blood, which formerly was hut up in the veels, now falls out, and doth grow hot and putrefy, an at length is converted into a vapour. And hence doth arie this Intention, the dicuing of this vapour, or evaporation of this matter. And this being dicharged out of the veels, is not to be treated with Repellers,Cured by Digetives. or cured thereby, as it was when it was hedged in; but rather evacuated by Digetives. Thee < in non-Latin alphabet > do cure by educing the Fluxed matter, and converting it into a vapour, and o do dicharge it by inenible paages or pores of the Cutis. And of thoe ome are imple, ome compound; ome mild, others trong. Of the imples are Chamomile, Marhmallows, white Lilly Roots, Faenugreek, Melilot, Cumins, Rue, Bayes, and the like. Stronger are, Tyme, Origanum,
Mint, Pennyroial, Calamint, Hyop, &c. The tronget are Nitre, Sulphur Vivum, Lyme once extinguihed. Out of thee mixed with ome of the former Repellers you may make a compound Medicine, they being a like tempered are very proper here. As, . fol. Malv. Catapl. Abinth. Plantag. an. M. ij. Coquantur in aquâ fontinae, contundentur. Trajectis adde farin. Fabar. Hord. an. i. pulv. fl. Chamomel. Melilot. Roar. rubr. Abynth. an. i. Ol. Roar. Chamomel. an. i. Oximelit. impl. ij. mice, Catapl. Authoris: fiat Catap. Or, . Chamomel. rad. Alth. Aneth. an. M. . rad. Lilior. alb. no. ij. coquantur omnia in aqu. Hyop. q. . fiat colatura, Colaturae adde farin. Fabar. Hord. Lupinor. an. ij. pulv. em. Faenugraec. Roar. an. ij. Ol. Roar. Aneth. an. i. mice, fiat Catapl.

div.head: CHAP X. XVII.
Curing of a Phlegmon in its State.
div.p:
THAT is generally related and uppoed the State, when the matter can make no further progres, that is, when very much pain is perceived, and a great heat doth accompany the part. There may a quetion arie, what Medicines may be here mot proper? Gal. chapt. 16. lib. 13. Method. aith, that Digetives do chiefly take place here; and in another place, chapt. 4. lib. 1. < in non-Latin alphabet >
doth offer, that the indication of curing a Phlegmon in its State, ought to be both Repelling and Digeting. In the firt part therefore of the State Repellers and Digetives equally mixed are very proper; Catapl. of this ort may be ordered uch as thee. . rad. Alth. iij. Lilior. alb. i. fol. Malv. Partetar. Plantag. Chamomel. an. M. j. em. Lin. & Faeungraec. an. 3iij. coquantur omnia in Aquae fontinae q. . fine addendo farin. Hord. Fahar. Lupinor. an. i. pulv. Roar. rubr. fl. Melilot. Chamomel. an. 3ij. Ol. Anethi Roarum an. ij. mice, fiat Cataplama. Or this. . Lapath. Parietar. Malv.
Plantag. an. M. i. contundentur & coquantur, colaturae adde pulv. fl. Melilot. Chamomel. an. . pulv. Roar. rubr.Catapl: 3i. mice, fiat Catapl. Or this. . rad. Lilior. alb. ij. fl. Chamomel. i. Aneth. Calaminth. an. M. . coquantur in a quâ fontinâ q. . colaturae adde pulv. fl. Chamomel. Melilot. an. 3ij. pulv. em. Aneth. . farin. Hord. Fabar. an.Catapl: ij. farin. em. Faenugraec. . mice & cum Ol. Chamomel. nguent. Dialth. an. i. fiat. Cataplama.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.
Of curing a Phlegmon in its declination.
div.p:
IN its declination according to Galen. cap. 1. lib. 6. pure Digetives are to be ued, uch as you already have ordered you in the general cure of Tumours; and you may very well follow the ame method, and ue the ame Medicines, as you have already et you down there for your direction. I hall conclude this chapter with this hitory.A Hitory. Hildanus relateth of a Phlegmon in the Perinaeum equalling the bignes or largenes of a Gooe Egg, accompanied with
a pricking pain, with a hardnes both of the Scrotum & penis, for which was applied this uppurating Cataplam.Catapl. . rad. & fol. Alth. Malv. an. M. i. coquantur & pitentur, his adde farin. Tritic. ij. farin. em. Lin. Faenugraec. an. i. Butyr. recent. ol. Lilior. alb. nguent. Dialth. an. i. Croc. . Vitell. Ovor. no. ij. mice, fiat Cataplama, of which is to be applied warm two or three times in a day. The abces being broken, a great quantity of fetid and putrid matter came out for many daies together, and continued o long, that it left a large Ulcer; for the cleaning of which was ued pirit of Wine and nguent. Aegyptiacum, over which was applied this Cataplam. . farin. Lupinor. Fabar. an. Catapl. i. pulv. ummitat. Abynth. Scord. Rut. an. ij. Coquantur, & cum Oxieml. impl. q. . fiat Catapl. fine addendo, dum calens et, Mirrh. Alo. an. i. The Ulcer by thee being well deterged, and filled with fleh by a good cicatrice and well ordering of the body, the Patient recovered to his perfect health.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.
Of an Eryipelas.
div.p:
FROM Choller arieth this Eryipelas, accompanied with many other Tumours, bred alo from this Humour as Herpes miliaris, Herpes exedens, Pustulae and the like. There is generally allowed three orts of Choller,Natural: natural, unnatural, preternatural. The natural is that fourth part of the Blood, which hath a hot and dry temper in it, being of a reddih yellow colour, and bitter-weet in tate, much like toted honey. This is one of the natural Humours, o called for a double caue, becaue they perfect natures work, and are as vehicles for nutriment and conervation of the body; for if man were without blood he could not be nourihed, if without Spirits he could not be aid to live; and were it not for this natural bilious Humour man would oon well into a Dropy.Second not natural. A econd ort hereof is aid to be not natural, becaue this yeilds no perfection to the body, its ubtance being altogether unfit for this office of nutriment, this hath in it no bitternes or harpnes: of this ort is
that of the bladder of the Gall; and hould this contain any harpnes in it it would oon fret the guts into pieces; and beides this, daily experience howeth it is free of all Acidity, for it daily paeth through the Kidneyes into the Bladder, and then maketh its exit. But this Quetion in the Phyick Schools hath been very oft times controverted.Quet. Was not this Humour framed and ordered for deterging the capillary veels, that Chyle might pas to the Liver, and o the Blood hereby conequently there made?Anw. But this conequence may be very readily denied, for the Chyle does never reach the Liver; and this may appear different from the other, in that it is not o natural.Third preternatural. There is a third ort hereof different from both the former, being neither good to help the body in its nourihment, nor yet o mild as unnatural; which although it do not nourih the body, yet doth it not offer any micheif to it; this is both unprofitable, and unnatural, and preternatural, alwaies hurting the body; and o is called preternatural Choller, which properly pere and in e is apparently o. There is another ort of preternatural Choller, which mixeth it elf with other Humours, and doth make them wore;
the one having in it Serum and Flegm, and this is very fit and proper for obtruction. There is a econd ort doth mix it elf with tough vicous Flegm,Its differencies. and this is called Bilis vitellina; and this doth promote and help forwards obtructions. A third is burnt choller by admixture, and this doth make & frame our great pains and excoriations, whilt it doth lodge in the veels; and when it getteth out from hence, is the mot apt Author of cancerous Tumours and Melancholick vlcers. And thus much of the differencies of Choller. We now arrive to an Eryipelas, the proper ubject of this Chapter, and Guido doth give that ditemper which adhereth to the Cutis the name of Eryipelas. The names of Eryipelas. Some of the Ancients called it Ignis acer; ignis, becaue it burneth like fire; acer, being ent as a punihment from the Sacred hand: but it is more properly called Eryipelas, quai
< in non-Latin alphabet > . For as < in non-Latin alphabet > doth ignifie rednes (by ome called
< in non-Latin alphabet > ) o < in non-Latin alphabet > doth as well ignifie near. And thus may we define it, calling it Eryipelas, becaue it maketh all its neighbouring parts red: It is a hot Tumour, ariing from the aforeaid choller, poeing ome exterior part of the body.What it is. A true and imple Eryipelas is bred
of thin, ubtile, hot, and chollerique blood; and this appearing in any one part of the body doth form and fahion this dieae; and becaue it cannot by reaon of its thinnes have any conitence in the inward fleh, it therefore doth content it elf with getting into the outward parts of the cutis, and there it doth exercie its terrifying Qualities. You may know it by its hot igns,Signs. having belonging to it a large heat, pain, a red colour, or rather omewhat turning yellowih. But becaue thee igns are o near related to thoe of a Phlegmon, Its differencies from a Phlegmon. I hall here make a larger ditinction between them. And thus it firt doth differ from a Phlegmon, in that a Phlegmon doth apprehend both cutis and ubject fleh; in this onely the cutis is concerned. Secondly, this is much hotter, for you ee it appear as it were burnt up by its bliters, by how much the choller is hotter than blood. Thirdly, here is les pain. Fourthly, its rednes doth oft times change into a blacknes or blewnes. Fifthly, it yeildeth to the touch. Sixthly, upon the touch the rednes doth vanih. Seventhly, here is no tenion. Eightly, it doth differ from a Phlegmon, in that it never doth move from its place; whereas this preads it elf and encreaes about
its neighbouring parts. That which doth proceed from yellow choller is mildet;Praeage. it is a bad ign if an Eryipelas turns inwards. In Tumours, Wounds, Fractures, and Dilocations, it is generally held mortal; or if it doth tend to uppuration it is no waies to be accounted a good ign, neither may it be judged but very very bad, if it do poes the neighbouring parts of a bone being bare.Cure. As touching its Cure, according to Galen in his Arte medendi, whereas it is a dieae encreaing in a great quantity of choller, this is to be evacuated, and the whole Cure performed by diet, Chirurgery and Pharmacy. As to the firt, we are to oberve that the Air be cold and moit, o naturally, or made o by Art; let the Patients diet be cold and moit, and as this choller is thin, let him take uch diet as is cooling and thickning; and for his broths may very properly be boiled thee herbs. Lettuce, Beets, Mallows, Chichory Sorrel, and the like. Chicken-broth here alo is very good, Barly water, Ptyane, to which may be added Borage, Bugloe, and the former, or ome of them. For his common drink he may take Almond-milks made of blancht Almonds, the cold eeds, wood-Sorrel and the like, weetned with Syrup
of Violets, Lettuce, Lemmons, Woodorrel, &c. or uch Juleps or Emulions as thee are very proper.The Authors Julep herein: . Hord. perlat. ij. fol. Lujul. Lactuc. Aceto. an. M. s. fl. 3 Cord. an. pug. i. coquantur in aqu. fontinae. q. . colaturae adde yr. Papaver. erratic. Violar. an. ij. Lap. prunell. . aqu. mirabil. . pirit. Sulphur. gutt. 10. mice pro Julapio. . Amygdal. dulc. excorticat. i. em. 4. frigid. major. an. ij. em. Lactuc. Papaver. alb. Emulion •
an. i. contundentur in mortario marmoreo enim affundendo aqu. Hord. & Liquirit. lbi. in colaturâ olve yr. Violar. ij. Lujul. Aceto. an. i. pirit. Vitriol. . mice, hujus umat ad libitum. Let the Patient's body be kept open by convenient clyters, Apozemes or Purges,Bleeding. let him hun all watchings and anger. As touching Bleeding, in this cae it is very diputable, whether it be at all proper or not; but if it be convenient at any time, and at any place, it is when it gets into the head and face, and then are we to open the cephalick vein, for prevention of a Pleurify or Squinancy. In an Eryipelas Phlegmonodes we have nothing which may contradict Phlebotomy; but in other caes I think it neither neceary or afe; in that you draw hereby
the good as well as the bad blood out, and leave the thinner part of the blood behind. And ince I have given thee directions to arm your elf with every intrument, which may quell or allay the heat and fury of this Tumour, you are to keep its doors alwaies open, and thereby dicharge thee peccant Humours; and this you are to do before you apply any outward means or Medicines. As for Simples very ueful, here you may take Caia newly drawn, of Manna, Tamerinds, Rhubarb, Prunes, Senna; out of thee and the like may alo be made many famous and excellent compound Medicines, having in them a ufficient power to pull down the heat and fury of this dieae: and here may properly be taken uch a potion as this.Potion. . fol. In the application of thee or any of thee this you mut oberve, that they are very oft to be renewed, let by their being left too long on the part affected they rather inflame than allay the fury and heat of the part affected; neither are they to be ued too long, let they do extinguih the native heat of the part; and then are you to abtain from their ue, when the Patient doth acquaint you his pricking pain or heat in the part affected is not o much as it formerly was, and when the part appears more tepid to the touch, and then thirdly, when the red colour doth begin to turn into a blewih or black colour. After thee you are to ue Digetives, that thereby the part may get warmth and trength, which for ome time hath been diabled of its native heat: and for this uch a Medicine as this is good. . farin.
