div.head: CHAP. XX.
Of an Eryipelas in the Face.
div.p:
THIS for the mot part arieth from the noe, it firt growing red, then doth well, and then preads it elf, and ometimes it doth get into the head, and neck. The caues which may occaion this may be aid to be two, being either inward or outward; outward as contuions, wounds, or the like, which may be accounted capable enough to excite heat and pain; or inwardly taken too much hot wine, pice, or the like, a hot intemperiety of the Liver, which doth breed this o plentiful a quantity of Blood, a redundancy hereof, and a Fluxion of Humours to the part affected.
<> . The cure hereof is much different from the former; and in this we are to make a diligent earch as touching its caues, happening either by an outward or inward occaion. If by an outward, this being removed, the Eryipelas doth ceae; if from a redundancy
of chollerick Blood which floweth into the face, the outward veins are to be opened; and hence do arie three intentions in this cure, firt a cooling of the hot intemperiety of the Blood; of evacuating and dicharging of this chollerique Blood; and thirdly to hinder this Fluxion. And thee are to be performed by Diet,Chirurgery. Chirurgery and Pharmacy; by Chirurgery in Revulion by Phlebotomy, which ought to be performed in the arm in the ame ide; and here you may bleed plentifully, if the patient can endure it; if not, you may repeat it: beides this other Revulives are good, as Cupping-glaes, Veicatories, thee being applied to the neck and houlders. Pharmacy doth relate to the better tempering the intemperiety; and for this you may take thee as proper Medinces, being very good and ueful in this cae to be ued and adminitred, as,Electuar: . Pulp. Prunor. damacinor. i. Crem. Tartar. i. Rhabarb. ij. Cinamon. pulv. . Santal. citrin. pulv. ij. mice, fiat Electuarium; cujus umat patiens q. nuc. cataneae omni mane. Or this potion,Potio: . Tamerindor. ij. Prunor. Jujub. an. par. no. 5. Paular. enucleat. . Hord. mundat. pug. i. em. Melon, Lactuc. an. iij. fl. 3 cordial.
an. pug. . fiat decoctum, in colaturae vj. olve Ca. recent. extr. . pulv. Jalap. . yr. Roar. olutivar. ij. mice, fiat potio. Or this of the Author. . rad. Petroelin. Faenicul. Cichor. Lactuc. inci. an. i. coquantur in aquae fontinae ut colatura redeat ad lb. huic adde vini albi lb. in his imul mixtis tent per noctem in infuione Senn. mundat. . Rhabarb. i. Polypod. querc. . em. Faenicul. Ani. contu. an. ij. Epithem. Ceterach. Capil. vener. an. p. j. ZZ. i. hujus infuionis umato iiij. his adde pulv. Jalap. . Crem. Tartar. ij. yr. Roar. olutivar. ij. mice, umat cum cotodia. As to his diet which is the third part, let the Patient abtain from Wine, and intead thereof let him drink Barly water, or Julep of Roes, or cooling Emulions, uch as you have already directed you. And thus much of the inward caues. As to the outward Applications, they ought to carry with them a moderate temper, between heat and cold; for when heat and pain do urge, thee do call for eae and mitigation; and if pain doth proceed from heat, here mot properly are we to ue coolers, without atriction, as is the Decoction of Mallows, mixed with a little oyl of Violets
or Roes; in the end we are to ue Digetives, as we have formerly directed and precribed. And thus much of an Eryipelas getting into any part of the head. A country man being vexed with an Eryipelas Phlegmonodes, A Hitory. the which being anointed by the advice of a Barber with oyl of Roes for ome daies, (this happening in the arm) hence did arie pain, inflammation, and other ymptoms, o that at length the whole hand was correpted with a Gangrene, the which at lat being well carrified, and uch convenient Medicines applied, as I have hown in my dicoure of a Gangrene, he afterwards recovered. Let this erve as a caution to young Chirurgions, that Oyl doth add to the flame rather than extinguih it, as Galen doth offer in lib. 5. de Simpl. A Gentlewoman, a peron of very good Quality,A Hitory. had an Eryipelas all over her face, the which at length had a Herpes miliaris joined to it, in which time the Eryipelas imprinted its marks, o as the whole face was marked therewith; he being of a plethorick contitution, when neither by the advice of Phyicians by bleeding, purging, or application of everal external Medicines good could be done, after the applying of everal
Unguents this at lat being applied brought her unto her health, as, . nguent. de Lithargyr. i. Hydrargyr. extinct. cum ucc. Limon. . Tuth. praeparat. iij. Ceru. lapid. Calaminar. praeparat. an. ij. aqu. Roar. acet. Roar. an. i. agitentur omnia in mortario & pitillo plumbeis. Of this you may read in Obervat. 34. Riverii.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.
Of Oedema.
div.p:
AS the former two have their variety of dieaes belonging to them, o alo hath this its various companions bred of and from the ame Humour; for from Flegm are bred, Oedema, Artheroma, Steatoma, Meliceris, Nodi in Juncturis, Ganglion, Leucophlegmatia and the like. This Flegm is the fourth part of the mas of Blood, that is, the colder and moiter part thereof: and if it o happen that this doth increae in quantity,What flegm is. the expulive faculty being tirred up by the great plenty of this Flegm, this doth offer very fair to the generating of an Oedema. This Flegm is cold and moit, and by ome called
pituitous Blood. And of this there is two orts, one Alimentary, the other Excrementitious. The firt is the origination hereof,Its name. by the Arabians called undimia, by the Greeks < in non-Latin alphabet > ; which word
< in non-Latin alphabet > ignifies no otherwie then an eminency. There are of natural or excrementitious Flegm thee three orts: the firt being acid, o called from its tate; the econd alt Flegm; the third glay Flegm, from its coldnes, thicknes, and toughnes. And if Flegm doth erecede from its nature by admixing it elf with Blood, it is called Oedema Phlegmonodes; if with Choller, Oedema Eryipelatodes; if with melancholy, Oedema Scirrhodes. A great matter hereof is a great quantity of Flegm reiding in the body, cheifly about the extreme parts, as the hands, knees, or feet, thee being the mot remote from the Fountain of heat. This Flegm is thrown forth from the greater veels to the maller,Its generation. the which being there deteined by the thicknes of the Cutis, is collected in the muculous parts, and there doth form this Oedematous Tumour. It is a Tumour oft, indolent, looe, yeilding to the touch, generated from a pituitous matter.Definition. It is oft and looe,Signs. and thee two come from the Humour of thin Flegm; indolent,
for it neither doth make or caue any pain, or diolve unity; It gives way to the touch, and is a white Apoteme, and without heat; white, being mot like its object Flegm; without heat, being like the matter out of which it is generated, which is cold and moit. A pituitous Humour redundant in the body is the cheif caue,Caue. to the which a cold and moit air, a flegmatick diet, too much leep and idlenes, and a cold dycray both of Head, Stomack, or Liver may help forward to the encreae of its caue.Praeage. And as Galen aith, Comm. 46. that out of Fluxion of Humours ome are cruel, as Chollerick fluxes, and burnt Melancholy; and others are more kind, as this Oedema: o this is a tedious and long dieae, becaue it is cold, the native heat being herein very weak. It is oft times oft, and without pain, and o carrieth the les danger; but if it be hard, and with pain, it is dangerous. As touching its cure, here ought we firt to ue proper means by Retraction and Revulion of the Matter, and leening of it. Secondly, becaue it is cold, remove its caue by implanting heat and warmth herein. Let the Air be warm and dry, the Diet attenuating and drying; here Wine is good becaue
it doth diget and warm. Let his diet be of good and light digetion, as Chickens, Rabbets, Partridges, and the like, to which may be added all orts of pices. Let his leep be moderate; and let him avoid all paions of mind, and venery, and oberve that he keep a good habit of his body. After this let him ue uch evacuations, as may both attenuate, open, and dicharge this Flegm. Bleeding here is in no wie to be ued, unles a Phlegmon do accompany it, Fever, or the like. And for his ue thee Phlegmagogicks are very proper and convenient: as, . Alo. lot. cum. Pill. aqu. Majoran. Agaric. trochic. an. i. Matich. Cubebar. an. gr. vi. Troch. Alhandul. . Cum yr. de Betonic. q. Pil. . fiant pillulae, dois i. Or . Pil. Coch. ij. Aurear. i. Troch. Alhandul. gr. Pil: iiij cum Oxymelit. cillitic. q. . fiant pil. no. 18 quarum umat 2 omni mane. Or if you will . Pil. Coch. . extr. Rud. i. Mercur dulc. gr. 15 ol. C • ryophyllor. gut. i. mice, umat mane. A potion preparing Flegm,A potion. . Hyop. M. i. Menth. M. . Abynth. M. . em. Ani. Faenicul. Calamenth. an. . Roar. rubr. . fiat decoctum ad lb. colaturae adde Sacchar. lb. & aromatizetur cum pulv. Cinamom. i. or this
potion.Potion. . aqu. Meli. Buglo. an. ij. in his in funde per noctem Rhabarb. i. Agaric. trochic. ij. pulv. Cinamom. . ZZ. . colaturae adde Mann. . Cambog. gr. iiij. aqu. Cinamom. hordeat. . mice, fiat potio. Or if you pleae this.Potion. . Electuar. Diacatholic. s. Diaphaenic. ij. pul Agaric. troch. . olvantur omnia in aqu. Hyop. Roar. damacinar. Faenicul. an. i. mice, fiat potio, cui adde yr. de Betonic. i. And becaue Oedema is a dieae offending partly in quality,Topicks. partly in quantity; in repect of its cold and moit quality, we are to ue uch Medicines to the part affected as are warm and dry; and in relation to its quantity, we are to endeavour its dicharge and evacuation. And ince here is required a double intention, here ought we carefully to inquire and examine, whether Repellers mixed with Digetives are in the beginning firt to be ued. Galen doth atisfie us cap. 3. lib. 2. ad Glanc. that they are to be ued: as you may find him there uing a peice of ponge, or linnen rags dipt in Oxycrate, to which a little alt is added, and o applying it over the part, and then ordering it to be rolled up: for Repulion is this roller, being dipt in vinegar; and the
ponge and the water do diget the pituitous Humour.Quetion. But it may be asked, how Digetives, being hot and dry, may or can agree with water, which is cold and moit in digetion? Galen doth anwer this, Chapt. 8. lib. 1. that water doth diget:Anwer. and this we may ee in the hands and feet of Fihermen, who having been much imploied in the water, you will find them both corrugated and wrinkled; which corrugation is nothing ele but the evacuation of that matter which formerly filled up the paces. But hould an Oedema happen upon the Tendinous or Nervous parts,Obervat. we are to ue little vinegar; and for dicuion of the matter this may be very proper.Digetive. . fl. Chamomel. Roar. Mirtin. Abynth. Staechad. a. M. . Alumin. Roch. Sal. commun. an. . Balaut. nuc. Cupre. an. M. i. Salv. Rorimar. Squinanth. an. pug. i. coquantur, pocâ factâ ex Lixivio, & coquantur omnia uque ad ae partis conumptionem, in quo madefaciatis Spongiam; and this you are to ue to the tate: Or this Cataplam. . pulv. Roar. Catapl. rubr. Mirtin. Abynth. Rorimar. Staechad. an. ij. pul. fl. Chamomel. Melilot. an. i. mice, & coquantur cum q. . Hydromelitis, fine addendo pulv.
nuc. Cupre. Squinanth. Balaut. an. iij. Or this Cataplam.Catapl: . farin. Fabar. mic. pan. an. iiij. pulv. Terrae cimol. ij. em. Lin. Faenugraec. an. j. Bol. armen. i. coquantur in . q. Lact. vaccin. ad Cataplamatis formam; fine addendo Camphor. Croc. an. i. vitell. ovor. Catapl: no. ij. mice, fiat Cataplama, Or this. . farin. Hord. Fabar. an. iiij. pulv. Roar. ru. Bacc. Laur. Mirtillor. an. i. pul. fl. Chamomel. Sambucin. Melilot. Ivae arthritic. an. . fim. caprin. ij. cum vino rubro, fiat Catapl. fine addendo Sapon. nigr. iij. applicetur bis in die. And becaue Quickilver hath a very trange penetrating quality allowed it, that it can command Flegm from the mot extreme parts of the body, it may very well and properly be here applied and made ue of; and for which this compoition is mot excellent. .Unguent. ex Mer ••• : Axung. porcin. iiij. Pinguedin. human. ij. Ol. Chamomel. Aueth. an. ij. Styrac. Calamit. Benzoin. Matich. an. . Theriac. Methridat. an. i. Argent. viv. i. agitentur omnia bene in mortario, quibus adde Ol. Spic. Salv. granor. Juniper. an. . mice, fiat linimentum. With this you may anoint the part affected; or you may apply this often in this cae applied with good
ucces by my elf.Empl. . Empl. Diachyl. cum gum. Paracel. an. i. Oxycroc. ij. nguent. Praecript. s. mice, extende uper alutam, & parti admovetor. Or this. . Empl. de Ran. cum . Pic. Burgund. ij. Taccamahacc. iij. Empl. Paracel. . mice pro uu. It eldome or never is brought to uppuration, by reaon both of its coldnes, and that it for the mot part is very far ditant from the Fountain of Heat: but hould it tend that way, Empl. Diachylon cum gummi, or a Cataplam made of white Lilly roots, Marhmallow roots, and the like, as you have already precribed and hown you, may do both very well here and be very erviceable. A young Maid, about eight years of age, being much troubled with a Phlegmonous and Oedematous Tumour in the outward part of Her lower Mandible,A Hitory. which came to uppuration, fearing its fecies would hinder its cicatrice, before I could open the Abces, I firt tried by Guido's Counel to reolve it, who aith that Apotemes being ometimes uppurated do end in reolution; the which was confirmed by Parraeus his experiment, who averreth that he cured a uppurated Apoteme by mixing Quickiver with Diapalma, and o applying it: and thus
I took to an Ounce of Diapalma a dram of Hydrargyrum, and applied to the uppurated Apoteme, and within four daies it was wholly reolved: and for dicuing the uppurated matter to the following Conditions are thee neceary, that the matter be mall in Quantity, thin and erous, occupying the uperfificies of the Cutis, and not penetrating; that it be in a trong and young body, happening in the oft parts, and a convenient time of the year. By the vertue of which Medicine, and oberving of which method, a young Gentlewoman was perfectly cured of an Oedematous Tumour, which was but little uppurated, upon the Region of Her Loins the largnes of the palme of a hand.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.
Of a Scirrhus.
div.p:
OF Melancholy cometh Scirrhus, Cancer lceratus & non lceratus, Elephantiais, Poras and others. Our late writers do call this Scirrhus Durities, becaue it is a hard Tumour detroying ene, lodging in a Member in that Capacity, as that it produceth little or no pain: or it may be called a preternatural Tumour, having no infeting ymptome. It is by ome called Apotema Lapidoum, by Avicen Sephiros. It is the onely brat of Melancholy: and this Melancholy hath a double contruction. For there is < in non-Latin alphabet > , or uccus Melancholicus, & < in non-Latin alphabet >
atra bilis. Between which two there is a vat difference, the uccus or juice being as the fecies or dregs of the Blood, and is drawn from the puret part of it by the pleen: the other Black Choler, being caued of immoderate heat and burneth the parts, and like vinegar being poured on the ground, it boyleth and raieth it elf from thence. There are four pecies of Melancholy;4 Species of Melancholy firt, when its pecies are burnt, it frameth
an illegitimate Scirrhus; Secondly, when Melancholy is made preternaturally by other Humours, it doth take hare of their qualities; Thirdly, when it is made thick by too much cooling or drying of Humours; Fourthly, when it is mixed with Flegm, Blood, or Choler, then it maketh Scirrhus Oedematodes, Burnt Melancholy made four waies. Scirrhus Phlegmonodes, Scirrhus Eryipelatodes. There are four waies alo hown to the making of burnt Melancholy. The firt is made of yellow Choler burnt, and o repreenting a yellow inder, and doth burn like it; The econd is made of thick and vicid Flegm; The third is made of burnt Blood, which is very bitter; The fourth is made of Melancholy Juice, being both acid and corroding.How a Scirrhus is made. There are two kinds of Humours which do make this Scirrhus; the one being a Crudity, as Flegm, thick and yet not vicid; the econd is vitreous matter, or a glay ubtance of Flegm. And hence may we take a Scirrhus either to be exquiite, or not exquiite: and therefore if Flegm be in a great quantity, it hapeth out Scirrhus Oedematodes; if Choler be predominant, Scirrhus Cancerous. Or if you pleae a Scirrhus is bred out of a natural melancholy Humour, which is cold, dry and thick,
and from glutinous Flegm;Its definition. and hence it may be defined a Tumour hard and indolent, a Tumour proceeding from a thick and glutinous Flegm, or a natural melancholick Humour. It may be known by thee Signs, it is a Tumour without pain,Signs. hard to touch; if not exquiite, it is carcely perceived. Every Scirrhus hath not pain; and this necearily happeneth, becaue it is deprived of ene. Melancholick Scirrhous Tumours are generally of a leaden colour, but a Scirrhus ariing from a Flegmatick Humour carrieth in it the natural colour of the Cutis. They take their principal Caues from the beginning of thick and tough Humours, and collecting themelves in the parts; and that occaioned by evil Diet generating a thick and vicid Humour,Caues: as by reaon of intemperieties of the Liver or Spleen, all uch caues may be aid outwardly to generate thick juices, as a cold or dry Air, Watchings, uppreion of Mentrues, and the like. Expect to do no good on an exquiite Scirrhus; for this alwaies is to be upected: If it happeneth about the Joints,Preage. Knees, or thee remote parts, be not too forward to undertake them. If it be exquiite and not turning Cancerous, yet it is hard to cure: for
firt, the Matter is dried up; and then cold and compact, and o tedious; and that which is lapidous gives no way to Medicine.Cure. As to the cure, the external caues are firt to be removed, by chooing a thin Air, hot and moit, free from Fogs and Mits; let the Patient hun thick, leguminous and cold Diet; let his Drink be Wine to help forward Digetion, and warm the parts; and let him get himelf clear of all paions of the mind. After this are we to take care to remove the inward caues, by preparing the Humour with Syrup of Apples, Buglos, Fumitory, Hyop, Oxymel, Balm, and the like. This being done, we are to purge this melancholick Humour with Senna, Polypody, black Hellebore, Confectio Hamech, &c. of thee or the like may be framed excellent compound Medicines, as this Apozeme. . rad. Thee being compleated, we arrive now at the part affected; and here are we to endeavour to dicharge the Matter which makes a Scirrhus. Repellers here will do no good, for it is too thick for them; Digetives therefore, which can work by inenible Tranpiration,Digetives: are mot proper: and thee at firt hould be milde, and in reference of its hardnes Emollients are mot fit; o that the proper Indications which are to atisfy thee copes, hould be Emollients and Digetives. Cator. opt. i. pulv. Rad. Irid. i. Empl. de Ran. cum . . Ol. Chamomel. Lilior. an. q. . fiat Emp. And thus have I paed through the four general Tumours ariing from the four Humours. I hall conclude this
with the Hitory of a Woman of fifty years of Age,A Hitory. which had frequently in Her left Mandible a fixt Scirrhous Tumour, and this did grow to o large a bulk, that it almot hindred her wallowing; it welled and filled her cheeks o much with its Tumour; it began jut about the extreme proces of the lower Mandible: and for the removing this Tumour, and preventing uffocation, and endeavouring to give eae and cure to the Patient, this method was propoed and followed, the Excrecency was to be urrounded with a thred, and apprehended therewith, and o by degrees bringing it cloer until it had eaten it away, by which means it was wholly eradicated; by drawing out the tooth, and with atringent and deterging Gargarims well ordered the whole cure was performed; this you may read in Bald. A Hitory: Ronius in his Epitle 7. Another Gentlewoman having had a Contuion in her Hand, a great pain did arie from thence, about the Carpus or Writ with inflation of her whole Hand; at length it degenerated into a Scirrhus of the largnes of a Hens egg, in o much that he could not bend her Fingers; her Body being univerally purged and ordered, I applied a potential
Cautery to the part; afterwards I removed the Echar, which was but lightly penetrated; afterwards applying new Echarioticks, which might penetrate deeper, I oon aw appear a thick vicous and yellowih Matter, the which took ometime for the getting its dicharge; Sponges being clapt into it for dilating the Ulcer, the Matter being expoed to the Air, hardened like a tone, much of which I drew forth, and the Ulcer being well mundified, I filled it up with Fleh, skinned it, and the Patient perfectly recovered.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII.
Of Aqueous Tumours.
div.p:
I Proceed now to the other two Tumours ariing from Water and Wind, out of which watery Fountain do arie and pring up Acitis, Hydrocele, Hydrocephalos, Phlyctenes and the like. Now this Serum from whence thee Tumours do arie, is a collection of Water in ome member of the Body, void of pain, and there is but a mall quantity hereof in healthful perons, it doth tamp its various pecies on its places where
it inhabits or hath any thing to do. Galen calleth all waterih Tumours Putles, that have any moiture in them. And when it thus getteth into the Scrotum, it maketh Hydrocele; if into the Navel, Hydromphalos. They arie from a thin Humour, which ometimes is profitable; profitable o far as it doth perform its office, which doth erve as a proper Vehicle to the Blood; wherefore if it at any time happeneth that a waterih Humidity be refunded into the Body forcing its excretion, this expelleth it to the Cutis through the other parts, and doth form and make thee waterih Tumours. A econd may be a redundancy of this waterih Humour in our Bodies, which oft times doth happen and arie from a weaknes of the Kidneyes, which are not trong enough to attract this plenty of Serum: or may be occaioned by drinking too much Wine; for as Galen aith, this waterih Humour is the excrement of potion.Signs. You may know it by its Splendor and Fluctuation, if you pres it with your Finger; and a particular Sign of a waterih Tumour is, that it is made with itching, occaioned by the altnes which is contained in the Humour. Such as cometh from an evil affect either of Liver
or Spleen,Preage. is very bad and dangerous, not becaue of the Tumours but in repect of the principal parts; yet they are not o dangerous as windy Tumours.Cure. The Cure is to be performed by ablating the Caues: and if this do arie from two much drinking, order your Patient to leen his quantity, and abtain from this coure and habit of living, and ue Driers: and if it happeneth from a vice either of the Liver or Kidneyes, this is to be corrected; Hydragogicks are mot proper here; as, .Pil. extr. If with thee they are not cured, they are to be opened, and the Ulcers to be mundified with Reine, Turpentine, and Honey, or nguentum ex Apio, &c. then is it to be impleted with Fleh with nguentum Tuthiae, and dry it up with Pulvis Tuthiae Deiccativum, Rubrum, Diapompholigos, or Diapalma. Fabritius Hildanus relateth of a man of thirty years of age,A Hitory. very trong and of a anguine complexion, who fell into a Leucophlegmatia: that he welled from the neck to his
foot, his Optick nerves being obtructed, hereby he grew blind: Upon ordering the Patient opening Apozemes, and giving him preparative Decoctions, a great Flux of Blood fell accidently from his Notrils, o that he bled above four pounds, and hereby fell into a Syncope; but being a little revived after his Flux was topped, and his Faculties beginning to gain a better habit and condition, beyond the ue of any Medicine, this flux perfectly cured him of his waterih Tumour. This is occaioned as the Greeks do call it, < in non-Latin alphabet > , from an aluminous alt of the Liver, or ome other principal part, the which by its ubtile penetrating quality doth force it elf into divere parts of the body.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV.
Of Windy Tumours.
div.p:
UNTO this windy Commander do belong thee everal Souldiers, as Pneumatocele, Tympanites, Priapimus, Satyriais and the like. This Wind doth carry in it a very trange and wonderful power and force in our bodies, and is as it were a certain Lightning cattered through the inenible Trunks, ininuating it elf into abtrue parts; for it reacheth the Bones,What i • Wind. and doth create very great trouble in our Joints; it bringeth greifs between skin and bones, and doth ruffle and diorder the whole Man, for where it is compact with any other Humours, it doth there make both a long tay, and doth tir up but many ad Symptoms: This heweth what Wind is, whereof are bred thee Tumours. Let us now ee what thee Tumours are.What a windy Tumour is. A latulent Tumour by the Greeks is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , or < in non-Latin alphabet > , and he that is afflicted with thee is oft times girded in his Sides, and tretches in his Belly. It is oft times caued of Crudities;Caue • . and becaue it maketh the part thick by reaon of the
grones of thee Flations, it doth oft times make troubleome and tedious work for the Chirurgion. Its caues are flatulent Spirits, vicid, or vitreous Flegm, and want of native Heat; thus the heat is but mall which doth work it elf into thee Humours, and o doth omewhat diolve them, and o doth arie this flatuous Spirit; and this being bred, doth elevate the part where it once getteth footing, becaue it cannot work its free paage by reaon of the denity of its parts. It is een to arie in everal parts of the Body, as well inwards as outwards. Here is held by Avicen a double kind of this windy Tumour:Differencies. the one being made by a light Vapour aimulated to Althege •• um, the which is nothing ele than a Tumefaction like to a Cachexy, this ariing from the diaffection of the Liver: and there is another Tumour ariing from a windy Vapour, and this by Avicen is called Inlatio. This is bred from Flegm coming from the larger Veels to the maller, until it hath arrived at the mallet, and at the coldet parts.Signs. It howeth it elf apparent in compreing the Tumour with the Finger, and you may then ee it eaily yeild to the touch, as doth an Oedema: Then upon this compreion
it maketh a noie; for Wind being kept in, and being by your Finger pret out from its quarters, this never parts from its place without a noie or ound: Thirdly, it is deteined in a cavity: Fourthly, as Guido doth offer, it appeareth lucid and plendid in its upper part. Fifthly, it is not alwaies free from pain: And latly, being contained in the larger Veels, we daily find the great and many troubles and vexations it brings to mankind. As touching the Cure, pray oberve with me this method,Cure •
wherein we are to oberve an Order, Mode, Time, and Subtance, Order, this cheifly coniting in Diet. As touching the Patient's times or eating and drinking, that he neither eat too oon or too late, between meals, or after upper, going to Bed and the like, or in his bed. Mode, that he neither eateth more than may reaonably atisfy his Stomack without difficulty. And to its ubtance, this requires that he take notice, that he abtain from all Flegmatick Meats, or uch Diet as hath therein a latulent or windy •• tance, uch as may obtruct the pa ••• es, as Fruits, Peae, Beans; and let <> hun all windy A •• s, or other uch like Liquors. A moderate exercie is very good
here, for it doth recreate and refreh all the paions of the Mind, and doth diffue, concoct and diget the native Heat through all the Body, and maketh every Member and part to perform its office and function. In the Patient's Bread may well be ordered weet Fennel eeds. Let his Meat be well Aromatized and his Drink be Wine of the bet ort, that may both trengthen his Stomack and hinder the afflux of any windy Vapours acending up to the brain, excite the native Heat, help forward Digetion, and drive the Excrements downwards; after thee keep his body free from thee flatuous Humours, by convenient Evacuations; as by Pills, Potions or Clyters, for which thee are very convenient. .Potion. Lumbricor. ij. Terebynth. venet. q. . fiat Empl. And thus much for dicuing of windy Tumours. And that Wind is bred in the Ventricle, and Intetines Phyicians have alwaies confirmed; and that it hath crept and forced it elf into other parts of the body, this thing I have very oft times een; an example of,Hitory: which you may here read off. A Child about ten years old, lately ditempered with the mall Pox, in o much that it had near cot her her life, for he was o blown up with wind from the Navel even to her Feet, this getting a paage between the Cutis and the Muculous parts. There was no pain, the inward parts were ound and almot
• reed from the aforeaid ditemper. Various Medicines were precribed inwardly for trengthening of the parts, and creating in them a native heat; outwardly Medicines for dicuing this Wind, and by thee he grew well. Riverius obervat. 69. writeth of a Child being eighteen months old, who was much blown up with Wind, and troubled
with a Fever: everal Medicines being precribed, as Purges, Clyters, Juleps, nctions, and the like, with the Syrup made of a decoction of Agrimony both Wormwood and the leer Centaury taking a Spoonful thereof twice in a day, within three daies perfectly recovered.

div.head: CHAP. XXV.
Of a Cancer.
div.p:
AND becaue this is a Tumour doth happen very frequently in our Art, and proves an enemy both very powerful and painful, that we may undertand the right way of dealing herewith, it generally happening in the Bret,What the Bret is. let us firt conider the Bret it elf and its parts. The Bret, according to our Countryman Wharton, is aid to be framed of a glandulous pongeous Parenchyma, not divided into ditinct conglobated Glandules,The Anatomy of the Bret. but is rather to be accounted a conglomerated Glandule; but in a Scirrhus and in a Cancerous Tumour they appear knotty. It hath Veins, Nerves, Arteries, and Lymphaducts, and a porous Cavity: its Veins and Arteries
come from the Subclavians: it hath its Nerves from the fifth pair, and from other Originations: Lymphaducts are here very frequently cattered: and as touching its Poroities or porous Cavities, thee do erve for its Excretion, or its excretory ues, they being more large in the Bret then in the common Ductus, which is opened with many mall Foramulaes, their general ue is to prepare the Milk fit for the Infant: and for the making this there is held a great controvery, ome holding the Blood to be the Prima Materia hereof, whilt others do contend as toutly for the Chyle to be its Origination. The firt is not to be defended; for if Chyle be to be made mot properly into Blood, it may very properly be accounted retrograde for Blood to turn into Chyle. And uch as do tand up for the Chyle to be the onely ubtance of the Milk,How milk is made. they do offer this as their aertion, that the Chyle doth immediatly pas through the Milky veels into the Bret, or that it is there received into the Veins, and thence effued through the Thoracick Arteries into the Brets, and that they have a power or faculty to eparate the Blood from the Chyle, and to dipoe it through the Mammillary veels
into the Body, and this they call Milk; but the way or paage which hould conduct this to the Lactiferous veels is not yet arrived at. Our worthy Wharton's opinion is, that Milk is peculiarly a nervous Juice, not properly contituted for the ubtance of the Milk, but alo for carrying a double Matter with it, as being both Chyliick, and Spermatick; and thee two do breed the greatet part of the Milk, not immediatly ent from the Ventricle to the Brets by the Milky veels, but carried by or through the Ductus chyliferus into the Subclavian, thence circuled with the Blood through the Ventricles of the Heart, and o paeth through the Thoracick Arteries, and in time of the Mother giving milk it is refunded into the ample capacity of the Brets, and there do eparate the Sanguineous part from the Chyle, and do reduce it through the Mammary Veins into the Meditullium of the body. And this he offereth as the cheif matter or ubtance of Milk, and the mot proper nutriment for the Infant. And ince we daily ee the young ucking Babe is nourihed by alluring this Milk from its mothers Bret by her Nipple, it is very neceary that it hould contain in it
uch a ubtance as may give it atisfaction. And as the more noble part thereof doth come from the Succus nervous; o alo ought it mot properly to be derived from hence for the Infant's nutriment: but thus much as touching Milk. We arrive now to that which nearer concerns our enquiry, which is the tract of a Cancer: and this by the Greeks is called < in non-Latin alphabet > or < in non-Latin alphabet > ,Its name: by us a Cancer, from the reemblance it hath with a Sea-Crab. For as the one hath expanded claws and feet in everal places, being of a livid or cinerih colour; o alo is this Tumour of a round Figure of a livid Colour, and ticketh or adhereth o cloe to the part affected as a Key to a Door, or a claw of a Crab in its griping, having in it by ome reported to carry in it exalted Veins; but this is more fabulous then true, for not in four of a hundred, as Falloppius oberves, can you ee them thus apparent. It carrieth with it a train of horrid pain and heat, hewing it elf to view both cruel and horrible, it arieth from black Choler. As Tagaultius uppoed, it arieth from the Fecies of Blood; but this is onely his opinion, for this doth more properly frame and make a Scirrhous Humour; and that which to the
whole body doth make an Elephantiais, to a private or particular part doth alo frame a Cancer: and where this black Choler is harp and hot, it maketh an Ulcerate Cancer: and by reaon of its thick Juice, it can neither be repelled, or dicued; for as it lighteth and contemneth the company or acquaintance of mild Medicines, o alo doth it like Lard or Oyl turn into a flame, rage, and fury, by the applying of any trong or vehement Medicine. The Caues of this Atra bilis are many; for firt in the Liver is bred this natural melancholick Humour, which is called the Fecies of the Blood,Caues and hence arieth a Scirrhus, o this Atra bilis is made up of the adution of the other Humours, and without flattery is the wort of all the ret, and as it groweth more putrid, harp, and malign, it doth more peedily, violently, and painfully create an ulcerated Cancer. Sometimes it arieth from a hot intemperiety of the Liver, which burneth it, and by this burning is bred Atra bilis. Sometimes as Galen aith cap. 10. lib. 2. ad Gla • c. from weaknes and intemperiety of the Spleen, it being made incapable to attract this melancholick Humour, in o much that it is kept up and burnt up in
the body. Sometimes it happeneth from a uppreion of the Mentrues. Outward caues may alo affect this, as a thick, and vicous Diet, as Onyons, Leeks, Beans,Its ubject. and the like. It may arie in any one part of the Body; ometimes it doth throw it elf forth into everal places, but the Bret being a oft looe part is mot ubject to its Tyranny, and receiving the impres of its malitious tamp. Sometimes it happeneth in the parts of the Face, Noe, Lips, Mandible, and Tongue. Sometimes in the Inguens, and Thigh; a lively example of which I had in a Gentlewoman, my Patient in Norwich when I writ this. Another reaon that a Cancer doth oonet grow acquainted with the Bret before any other part, is in repect of the great conent that there is made between the Breat and the Womb, by the Veins, through which this thick and feculent Blood is ent and dipatched; and for the ame reaon is it, that there have been een o oft times Cancers of the Womb.Signs. At its firt touch it doth appear hard in repect of its thick Humour; it is of a livid Colour, and the more malign the Humour is, the more livid the Colour of the Tumour is; and then painful, for here is made a olution of Continuity,
occaioned by much Matter ditending the Nervous parts, Heat and Inequality; it is hot like the Humour that breedeth it. The greatet matter here to be minded is the Hardnes and Thicknes of the matter; if you ee a black and livid Colour in the place, and a Hardnes accompany it, this is a Pathagnomonical Sign: if you meet with a melancholy Humour and a melancholy Habit of Body, and the Bret upected, and the Body capable of entertaining uch a Tumour furnihed with evil Juices, this giveth a fair propective to the thoughts of a Cancer. The Cancer which is Ulcerate may well be known by thee Signs: For its Ulcer carrieth with it a fetid Smell, having thick, welling, and blewlooking Lips, horrid in apect, and accompanied with great Pain.Preage: In its beginning it is hard, having a blewih Colour, and pricking Pain about it. The event howeth the ucces; for you may never expect a cure of this: if any hopes may prompt on to proceed, it will be with a great difficulty: if you extirpate it, there oft times remaineth a Cancerous Ulcer, or it maketh its reverion ome other way, and to ome other part; o that, as wie Hippocrates aith, if the Patient be thus cured,
this Cure will onely be as a means to horten his daies. We ought not to meddle with ulcerate Cancers, thee by Galen held to be altogether incurable. Cap. 5. lib. de atra bile, they coming from black Choler; neither ought we to attempt the Cure of any other without Amputation, the which way and method of cure doth carry with it great danger and hazard, as Celus offereth. Cap. Cure. 28. lib. 5. As to the Cure, thee three things are to be minded, that we have a great repect to the Patien'ts Diet, precribing convenient Medicines, and well ordering the part affected; and thee are performed by Diet, Pharmacy, and Chirurgery. And becaue the bet kind of thee are bad enough to be treated with, that it may have its great force and fury tormed, and its preading venemous Quality the better contracted and leened, we are here to begin our work with univeral order and method of the whole Body. The better to trengthen the other adjacent parts, and to allay the fury and anger of this o potent an enemy, we are firt to look to the good order of Diet, which in Quantity hould be thin, although moit in Quality; and endeavour to quell the antecedent Caue by prohibiting the generation
of this Humour; and purge gently your Patient by degrees: and in purging oberve this rule, that you often prepare the Humour; the antecedent Caue being conquered, lay Seige to the conjunct Caue with all uch Engines as may torm the force of the matter contained in the part affected; and if any furious motion hereof may either diturb the Quiet, unettle the Ret, or dicompoe the order of this princely Fabrick, ue all means to prevent the incurion of this private Enemy. And for the firt intention, it being the mot proper and ready method for hindring the augment of a Cancer and keeping it within its bounds, Purgation is as an excellent weapon. And here may you furnih your elf with many excellent Methods, being either made into Apozems, Pills, Pouders, Potions and the like.Apozeme. As for an Apozeme, take this. . rad. Faenicul. Aparag. Lapath. acut. Scrophular. Polypod. querc. Sanicul. cort. interior. Frangul. an i. Agrimon. Veronic. Cucuth. Cetrach. Fumar-Capil. vener. an. M. . fl. Genet. Sambucin. an. M. . em. Ani. Faenicul. dulc. an. i. Liquirit. raur. var, paar. exacinatar. an. is. coquantur omnia in . q. aquae fontinae ad tertiae
partis conumptionem, ad libram colaturae adde yrup. de Scolopendr. Epithym. an. is. Aqu. Cinamom. i. mice, fiat Apozema pro tribus doibus. Or this Potion,Potion: . Conf. Hamech. iij. Extr. Hellebor. nigr. gr. vj. Aqu. Cinamom. . cum q. . Decocti prioris, fiat potio mane umenda. Or this. . rad. Buglo. Aceto. Cichor. an. . Agrimon. Cetrach. Epithym. a. M. . Senn. mundat. is. fiat Decoctum ad lbi. Apozeme. fine addendo fl.
Cordial. an. pug. i. in colaturâ infunde per noctem Rhabarb. elect. iij. pulv. Cinamom. iiij. exprime Liquorem, & in hac olve yr. Violar. de Pomis an. i. mice, fiat Apozema. Some of the aforeaid Pills mentioned in the cure of a Scirrhus may well be ued and taken here.Sudorifick decoction. Sudorifique Decoctions are alo very prevalent here: as, . Lign. Sarafr. ij. Lign. Guajac. Saraperill. an. i. Cinamom. . coquantur omnia in . q. aquae fontinae addendo em. Ani. Faenicul. dulc. an. ij. raur. Liquirit. . Of thee make a Decoction; of which the Patient may drink three or four times in a day. And as touching the part affected, Repulion, and Digetion, Scarrification, and Section according to Galen lib. 14. Meth. are very proper for evacuating and dicharging of the repletion
of Humours. As for the firt two Repulion and Digetion, Galen doth order thee to be ued both before and in the time of Purgation, and then to ue Digetives when the Body is ufficiently purged, thee being made and compoed of uch things as may not contain any corroding Quality in them: and of the Simples may be reckoned thee, Plantane, Nighthade, Knotgras, Lettuce, Sowthitle, Pomgranates, Balautians, and the like. Avicen doth much commend Tutthy being wahed and mixed with oyl of Roes. Paulus doth commend Nettles bruied. Some do admire the powder of Frogs, and others as much do praie an Unguent made of them. Others have a great value for Empl. Diacalcitheos diolved in the juice of Nighthade and oyl of Roes in Cancers not ulcerate: But for compound Medicines take thee. . ucc. Solan. ol. Roar. an. iij. pulv. Ranar. utar. & tetar. Cancr. an iij. pulv. Roar. Unguent. rubr. i. Tuth. praeparat. Lithargyr. aur. pulv. Plumb. ut. & lot. an. i. Agitentur omnia in Mortario plumbeo, & fiat nguent. Unguent: . Theriac. veter. i. ucc. Cancror. . ucc. Lactuc. ol. Roar. an. i. Vitell. ovor. no. ij. ub cineribus coct. Camphor. . agitentur
omnia in mortario plumbeo & fiat nguent. Or this.Empl: . pulv. Plumb. Ceru. Min. an. ij. Litharg. aur. i. ol. Lin. lb. Cer. q. . fiat Empl. Or this pretious Unguent o much admired by Francicus Arcaeus in Cancerous Tumours. .Unguent. ol. Roar. Omphac. lb. ev. Hyrcin. Vitulin. nguent. Roatum. Populeon an. iii. ucc. Solan. Plantagin. & Aceto. an. is. Vini granator. ii. coquantur omnia lentiimo igne ad uccorum & Vini conumptionem, potea colentur, & colaturae adde Ceru. ii. Litharg. aur. 5. Plumb. ut. Antimon. an. 10. Tuth. praeparat. i. Cer. Alb. q. . fiat nguent. in Mortario plumbeo. All thee or any of thee may be ued in the beginning of a Cancer, when it is but mall; but if it hath arrived at a greater bulk and largnes, this as Galen directeth cap. 10. lib. ad Glaucum is not to be dealt with, unles by Amputation: and this I think in no wie may be aid to come under the name of an exact way of cure; becaue it neither yeildeth the part its native Heat, but taketh away with it the ound as well as the diaffected part. And that we may proceed more effectually in this operation when occaion and neceity may command or oblige it, oberve with
me thee Rules, being as o many jut Guides which will hardly fail you in your conduct: as firt, that Cancer which doth adhere to the Bret or Brets is very deplorable. Secondly, that which doth happen in the Head, Neck or Shoulders, or alo in the Inguens, all thee are to be pronounced incurable. Aetius cap. 44. lib. 10. gives this for a reaon, becaue they creep and get in o deeply into the flehy parts, that they are not to be got out thence. Thirdly, although it be not thus adherent, yet it is not without great danger. Fourthly, a wore Symptome then any of the former, which is alo een very frequently, unles the Tumour be wholly extirpated, cured, and cicatrized, it may either grow again in the ame place, or in ome other place, and o bring a life full of greif, and a certain diolution of the whole in the end. Ulcerate Cancers do require Amputation by reaon of the great pain and heat they do carry with them. And that we may proceed methodically herein, I hall here offer what Intruments are mot proper for this work, as Inciion Knives, a Dimembring Knife, large Needles, Sponges, other Needles and the like, the which you hall have more fully afterwards,
I having there preented the young Chirurgion with a draught expreing his Intruments, and all other potures which he may ue. And before I et down the method of Amputation, be pleaed to liten to that famous Hitory of Ambroe Parrey, Hitory. relating to a Maid of Honour belonging to the Queen Mother, who being perplexed with a Cancer in her Bret which did equal the largnes of a Walnut, had applied to it Plates made of thin Lead rubbed over with Quickilver, the which although they did not cure her Bret, yet afforded her the kindnes of preventing its increae. The above nominated Lady growing weary of applying thee Leads, thinks upon a new Phyician, who coming to her, very confidently promieth her a perfect cure, and rejecting thee Plates as trifles, began his cure with Emollient and heating Medicines, and added uch things as attracted pain; upon the Application of which, the Tumour did uddenly grow to a vat bulk and largenes, and o much extended the Bret that it did break in the middle, whence iued out an immoderate Flux; for the topping of which he makes preent ue of corrofive and cautick Pouders, by the Application of which pains and Inflammation
Place this Figure Fol. <>
div.U:
o eized on her, that poor Lady, intead of her promied health he yeilded her elf to the Grave in the ight of her Phyician. This I bring in as a Caution to all younger Brethren, hoping it may direct them to ue more Reaon than Paion, Study than Ignorance in their Art; and not like Mountebanks fall on a udden upon deperate matters, but rather with Judgment and Reaon back their Art, and ecure their Reputations. I hall here breifly preent you with my methodical way of Amputation, which I ued in Norwich not many years ince in a Woman whoe Bret I amputated, the which being ablated weighed near two pounds. Her Body being prepared by Apozemes and convenient Purgations, both for hindring the Augment, and in ome meaure to prevent a Fever,Hitory. and he in every repect being made fit for the Operation, being a Woman of an undaunted courage, never did hrink at the Extirpating of the ame. Having made ready my Retrictives of Bolarmeny, Draggons blood, Matich, and the like, with convenient Buttons, Pledgets, Boulters, and Rollers, the Operation was thus performed, by drawing through two large Needles through the body of
the Bret, armed with Silks cros waies, by the help of which I had the advantage to elevate the Bret for the better extirpating it and its Radix. The Bret being amputated with my dimembring Knife, I with my Fingers expreed all the Blood from the remote parts: after this done I applied my Buttons made of Tow to the Veins and Arteries being covered with the Retrictive, whilt others were onely dipt in Acetum and o well prinkled with Calcanthum Rubrum: After thee was applied my large Pledget or Cap armed with a Defenative; then with convenient Boltrings and Rollers I performed and compleated my firt intention. Here let the young Chirurgion take notice as a jut Caution,Caution. that he attempt nothing of this Operation in a large and thick Bret, it being both dangerous and no waies afe. Within two daies after I took of my firt dreings, and then applied uch Medicines as might remove the Echar; the which being ablated, I deterged the Ulcer, filled it up with Fleh, and induced a perfect Cicatrice, and the Woman did receive a perfect Cure: But within 2 or 3 years after, whether by a blow or the like given her on her Bret I know not, but it flew out again.
A Mountebank coming to this Town promied her upon her addres to him a perfect Cure; but poor Woman he was treated after the ame manner as the Lady of Honour was, which I have already told you of, for he applying very attracting Medicines, drew both her out of her troubles by ending her into another world, and what he had into his own pocket.How an ulcerate Cancer is to be treated. If an Ulcerate Cancer might happen to our lots to be dealt with, this by Galen's authority is not to be medled with. But becaue it is cruel, and doth eem uncharitable to give no eae, if poible, to the afflicted Patient, we may ue this double Method, if any good may be epected: the firt is to be performed by Amputation or Cautick, or we are to endeavour to ee what an Iue may do being made a little beneath the Bret. By ome this Pouder is much commended, which is reported to have cured many ulcerated Cancers in the Lips, Noe, and other parts. . Atrament. Sutor. lbi. Auripigment. Sulphur. viv. an. iiij. Sal. gem. iij. cum Aceto mice omnia, & in vas impone, quod omni è parte lutatum ita ut fumus exire nequeat. Put it into an Oven, and keep it there until they be all burnt and dried; this is a Cautick, and this
he puts about the confines of the Cancer, and one part being burnt therewith, he applied it to another, o ordering it until he had burnt away all the Bret. After which he applies this Unguent. . Mel. depumat. iiij. Sev. Hyrcin. Limatur. Cupr. an. i. Lithargyr. aur. i. mice, & ad ignem fiat nguent. Fallopius doth offer this as a great ecret in an ulcerate Cancer, being onely made of two things as Arenick crytallized ublimed, whoe nature is, that being applied to a part with Lint it doth o adhere to the Cutis that it cannot be got of, unles you do take the fleh alo with it. The econd is Radix Dracunculus dried, poudred, and mixed with the former Arenick, and of thee he hath had very great experience as touching their vertue and ue; and this is his Method, if a Cancer be entire and not ulcerate, cratch it with the outward part of a reed, and apply the Medicine o as it may adhere; and he doth further advie that if this Medicine be applied without moderation it worketh little or nothing, but being put together and applied, you will find them work wonderful and trange effects. A econd Method is,A econd may. that we apply no Medicine having any biting Quality in it,
but rather uch as may make the Patient's life a little more pleaant and comfortable: and this we are to do by Lenifying the pain and preventing the preading of the Ulcer; and for this cae juice of Nighthade, and uch Remedies as I have already precribed are mot proper. I hall conclude this Tract with ome remarkable Hitories of Cancerous Tumours, as that of extirpating a Cancerous Tumour at the Eye-tooth poken of by Fabritius Hildanus. It being a Tumour equalling the bignes of a Walnut,Of a Cancer growing at the Eye-tooth. hard, livid, and inequal, adhering partly to the Gum and partly to the Lip, it had a pricking pain and other igns of a Cancer, and for cutting and attenuating the peccant Humour this Apozeme was firt precribed. . Rad. Cichor. cum Toto M. i. rad. Petroelin. Faenicul. an. ij. Polypod. Q. . Apozeme. Cort. Frangul. i. Cort. Tamarie. Cappar. an. i. Scolopendr. Veronic. Betonic. Fumar. Scabio. an. M. . fl. Borag. Buglo. Rorimar. Betonic. ummitat. Thym. Marjoran. an. pug. i. em. Ani. Faenicul. an. ij. em. Coriandr. praeparat. i. Paular. Corinth. . coquantur in . q. aqu. fontin. & Vini albi ad med. Conumption: hujus Apozematis accipe ii. in quibus infunde
& macerentur per noctem Rhabarb. elect. i. Potion: Agaric. troch. Turbith. gummo. an. ii. fol. Senn. iij. em. Ani. Crem. Tartar. an. ij. maneant per noctem in infuione in loco tepido, in the morning train them off, and to the colated Liquor add Syrup. Polypod. i. Aqu. Cinamom. . mice, fiat potio. The Body being thus purged, of the former Apozeme the Patient is to drink three times in a Day. After this breath a Vein in the left Arm, and apply Cupping-glaes both with and without Scarrification. After thee let the Patient weat for 14 daies with this decoction, as . rad. Polypod. cort. rad. Frangul. Tamaric. Cappar. an. i. Cetrach. Fumar. Scolopendr. an. pug. i. fl.
Cord. an. pug. i. em. Ani. Faenicul. an. s. fol. Senn. i. Coquantur in aqu. Fumar. & Scabio. ut colatura redeat ad iij. Potion. in quibus macerentur per noctem Rhabarb. rad. Machoac. an. i. Agaric. recent. troch. . ZZ. & em. Ani. an. i. maneant in infuione per 12 horas, & colaturâ olue Electuar. è ucc. Roar. ij. yr. Polypod. vi. aqu. Cinamom. iij. mice, mane umat. A Gargarim for the mouth was this. . Roar. rubr. M. Gargarim. i. fol. Malv. horten. M. . Cort. granator. ij, Balaut. Gallar. immaturat.
an. i. fl. Betonic. Scabio. an. pug. i. Rad. Scrophular. i. coquantur in vini rubri lbiiij. ad Tertiae partis conumptionem colaturae adde Mel. Roat. ij. Diamoron. Mel. Violar. an. i. mice, fiat Gargarima. The Body thus being prepared, and the Patient having his head omewhat placed downwards, and his mouth being opened, he comprehended the Tumour with a crooked Needle and a double Thred; and afterwards with a mall crooked Knife he by degrees did cut to the Mandible; the Tumour being cut out, for topping the flux of Blood was applied this Medicine being mixed with the whites of Eggs. . Farin. Volatil. . Bol. armen. Oriental. Terr. Sigillat. an. iiij. pulv. albumin. ovor. ole exiccat. i. Pilor. Lepor. minutiime inci. i. Coral. praeparat. ij. mice, fiat pulvis tenuiimus. And after this were applied the oyl of yolks of Eggs, to which was added a little Safforn for a Digetive, the Ulcer being digeted the mouth was oft times wahed with this Gargarim. . fl. Betonic. Roar. rubr. Alchimill. Sanicul. Pyrol. Scabio. an. pug. ij. coquantur in aqu. ad lbiiij. in colaturâ olue Mel. Roar. iij. mice, fiat Gargarima, about the end of the Cure he
applies this pouder to the Wound, and over this a thin peice of Lead, . Tuth. praeparat. pulv. granator. Alumin. ut. an. i. By this order and Medicines was the Patient perfectly recovered. In Schenkius lib. 1. de fac. fol. 225. is related of a noble Matron,Hitory: who having the right ide of her Face eaten away by an ulcerated Cancer, and when many other Medicines had been precribed and applied and took none effect, he was afterwards cured by applying thin and broad peices of a young Chicken to the part affected, the which were to be very oft times renewed, by which onely Remedy he recovered her perfect health, as Cordaeus annoteth Comment. 7. Hippocrat. lib. de Mulier.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI.
Of a Carbuncle.
div.p:
THIS by the Greeks is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , by Avicen Ignis Pericus: for it burneth like a Coal, and carrieth with it the lively reemblance of a burnt Sinder; for it is much burnt, and hath a black Crutines with it. It is a Dieae compoed both of a Tumour and an Ulcer, and is bred of hot Blood, that is the thinner part thereof, which is turned into yellow Choler, whilt the more thick doth turn into black Choler, and hence doth arie this Carbuncle. Or if you pleae, the thinner part is like to a Flame which acends from this Fire, whilt the thicker doth more aptly reemble a quenched Coal. The Putles ometimes are many, and mall as Millet-eed, the which being rent you will find a Crutines. The Humour which doth excite thee Putles, by Avicen is aid to be thin and Cholerick. Now there is a double pecies of this Carbuncle, the one not being Petilential, the other being Petilential. The igns of the firt are an Ulcer with a Crut, which ometimes is ahey, ometimes blacker, ome-ometimes
very much burnt.Signs. The inflamed part in its Circumference is painful, for the Patients do think they are girt up in the part affected, and as it were do carry a heavy burthen in it by reaon of want of natural Heat, and Spirits. This Crutuous fleh is circled with a livid Inflammation, and doth appear much like pitch. It occaioneth very much itching about the part by reaon of the corroding Vapours of the burnt Blood, which doth excite an incredible deire of cratching. A Fever very oft doth accompany it by reaon of its fervour, and vehement pain, and watchings. Signs of a Petilential Carbuncle are thee.Signs. A Petilential contitution of the Air, as in the time of the Plague; A lender and as it were an unperceivable Fever, and the Patient doth ofttimes walk while he falleth down dead; Thirdly, los of the natural colour of the Face; Fourthly, the Tongue doth grow black or yellow; Then the Urine thin and troubleome; Beides thee Liquid and Cholerick dejections; Seventhly, a protration of the Appetite and vomiting; Eightly, much hot or cold Sweats; Ninthly, a grevious perplexity of Mind; Tenthly, difficulty of breathing and a raw Urine. Eleventhly, pain of the
Head and Vertigo; 11 ometimes deep leeps ometimes great watchings; 12 Syncopes, epecially when Death doth come to eize; 13. the Crut which formerly was cinerih doth now grow blacker; and latly, that which was formerly blew is now quite coloured with black.Caues The immediate caue hereof is the Fluxion of a mot vehement Blood to the part affected, which is thus excited by a redundancy of the whole.Preage: Gal. Com. 12. lib. 3. Epidem. doth call the petiferous the wort. The other are alo dangerous, becaue they do arie from vitious Humours, and do produce a trong Fever. The part inflamed doth never uppurate but by the exut Heat; and by how much the more the larger and greater in number they are, by o much the more tedious; and by how much the nearer they get to the Heart or any other principal part, by o much the more dangerous. If it eizeth on the Membranes of the Brain, it caueth Delirium; if the Brain it elf, it proves mortal. In the Cure hereof the Fervour of the whole mas of Blood is to be minded, and a good order of Diet to be oberved, and this redundancy of Humours wholy evacuated;Cure; and this to be done by Phlebotomy. And here you may
afely breath a Vein until your Patient be ready to faint, according to Galen's authority Aphorim. 23. Sect. 1. For in a Carbuncle is a very large Inflammation. Cap. 1. lib. 2. ad Glauc. Here arieth a great dipute about the mot proper place to bleed in: for Gulielmus Placentinus will have us bleed on the oppoite ide for Revulion; and Guido doth join with him. Falloppius offereth, as there is a double Humour in a Carbuncle
• lowing and already flown, o alo hould there be propoed a double evacuating Method; The fluent Humour to be dicharged by Revulion, whilt the Flux is to becarried of by Derivation. But becaue as it for the mot part happeneth, that when the mas of Blood doth flow, apart of this melancholick Humour doth flow therewith, for this reaon alo are we to ue Pharmacy, as by ordering Manna, Caia, Diacatholicon, Confectio Hamech, Electuar. è ucc. Roar. and the like. Decoctions made of Scabious, Sorrel, Cichory will do well here, ued or appropriated as I have already hown and directed in melancholy Tumours. As touching Topicks, we are to mind thee three things in the part affected, as the Crut, the Inflammation tending to blacknes, and
the Symptoms about the Crut. Paulus will have us here to make deep Scarrification, that this melancholy matter may the better be got out, and either to apply Sponges or Pledgets dipped in pirit of Wine and Aegyptiacum, Niter or Salt to the part; thee and the actual Cautery are to be ued in the great and virulent Carbuncle. But if it be not of o great a moment, I take two Eggs and boyl them on inders until the white be hard, then I take out the Luteum of the Egg and mix Salt with it, and o apply them hot; and thus are you to erve it for four daies: if it requireth tronger ue, Aegyptiacum: if it yeilds not to thee, ue the actual Cautery; and for ablating the Echar, take a little Butter, Axungia, or Dialthaea or the like, let it be deterged with Mel Roarum, Unguent •
Turpe • tine or the like. Or with this. . ucc. Ap. i. Mel. Roar. i. farin. Fabar. ij. mice, fiat
• guentum. Or apply to the part this Cataplam made of Bean meal, of Lupines, French barly, Scordium, Ru • , Wormwood boiled in Oximel reiting putrefaction. Upon the Carbuncle apply this. . Calc. viv. i. Sapon. moll. q. . fiat nguentum, Unguen •
and let it ly upon the Ulcer for two or three hours. You need
not fear pain, for dead fleh is ever void of that; and for the removing of the Cautick you may apply this. . Butyr. non alit. i. vitell. ovor. no. ij. nguent.Unguent: Roat. Bailic. Aurei an. i. Theriac. Andromach. ij. fiat nguent. to be applied upon the Echar, and then mundify it with nguentnm ex Apio, then fill up and cicatrice. As touching a petilential Carbuncle,The Cure of a petilential Carbuncle: Antidotes are to be given with Scordium, Rue, and the like in them. We are here alo to upport the Heart againt the invaion of this malign Enemy with Cordials; as, . Aqu. Theriacal. . Tinctur. Croc. ij. Vin. Hipanic. ij. Spirit. Lavendul. Aqu. Mirabil. an. i. Aqu. Angelic. Rut. Borag. Meli. Calendul. Cardu. benedict. an. i. Conf. Alkerm. . cum yr. Meli. Caryophillor. q. . fiat Cordiale, cujus umat patiens cochlearia 2 vel 3 in languoribus. And for defending its adjacent parts apply this Defenative of Chalmaetius. Catapl. . Bol. armen. ij. Terr. igillat. i. Corn. Cerv. ut. Roar. rubr. Ebor. an. i. Camphor. ij. Cer. i. ol. Roar. lb. Acet. ij. Aqu. Roar. i. Albumin. ovor. no. mice, fiat Cataplama. Phlebotomy here is very proper and ueful; Let the Medicines you apply to the part affected be very
potent and attractive, having in them an Alexipharmick Quality, to which you may add Mithridatum, Venice Treacle and the like. Cupping-glaes applied here with deep Scarrifications are very beneficial; and if you be neceitated, unlaked Lime put upon the part will effect the ame.Hito ••
Riverius obervat. 9. writeth of one of four years of age who was afflicted with a Carbuncle in the middle of his Forehead, with a red Tumour accompanied, being black in the middle, and the whole Face tumefied; to which was applied a Cautick to the black part; and for removing the Echar an Unguent made of Bailicon, to which was added ome Treacle, oyl of Scorpions and the Yolk of an Egg; and to the whole Tumour was applied a Cataplam of Arnoglous, purging and bleeding being afterwards precribed, a Veicatory to his Neck, and a Cordial ordered for upporting of his Spirits with Confectio de Hyacinth. &c. the Fever abated, the Inflammation grew more remis, and every thing did eem mitigated. In this cae the Veicatory did perform the greatet part of the Cure by deriving a great part of this virulent Humour. And to every Carbuncle I think it very proper to apply it to all
the neighbouring parts, and not to ue
nguentum ex bolo o generally ued in thee Tumours; becaue Repellers applied to the Face in its Inflammations are more generally ubject to the doing more harm than good. And thus hall I conclude this Chapter of petilential and not petilential Carbuncles.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII.
Of Epinyctis.
div.p:
PALS and Celus do write this to be a very bad Putle, having in it an ahy or black Colour, about which doth grow a vehement Inflammation with nocturnal pains joined to it.Caue. The parts affected herewith are the outward parts of the body, which may eaily be perceived by the Humour imprinting its Colour wherever it taketh. It is made of burnt Blood: The Putles arie of their own accord with a reddih Colour omewhat tending to a lividnes, ometimes to a blacknes; They are mot commonly een in young Children and aged Perons; they bring no great danger without they be ill treated. There is three Intentions required
in this Cure, a good order of Diet being cold and moit; a dicharge of the peccant Matter, and here both Bleeding and Pharmacy are conveniently to be precribed according to the age and trength of the Patient; and then in applying convenient Medicines to the affected part.Unguent. As, . nguent. Bailic. ij. Vitell. <…> . 2 Axurg. Huma. Caprin. an . ol. Roar. iij. Croc. s. mice, fiat nguent. Or this Unguent.Another . nguent. Roat. ij. Vitell ovor. no. i. Cer. all. parum, Acel. paul. fiat nguentum. This ue if Inflammation; if you be to mundify, ue
nguentum Aegyptiacum, or ex Apio; fill up with Aureum, or Bailicon, and skin it with Diapalma or Deiccativum Rubrum. A Hitory. A Wine-Merchant being troubled with black and ublivid Putles, about which was a vehement In • lammation and nocturnal pains, when as he could receive no eae or benefit by other things precribed him, by the advice of a Woman he was ordered to anoint them with oyl of Juniper, by the help of which he reted very well, and had more eae by this than he could ever obtain by all his former Medicines both inwardly taken and outwardly precribed, and at length was hereby perfectly cured.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII.
Of Herpes Miliaris, and Herpes exedens.
div.p:
THIS by Avicen is called Formica. It arieth from a cholerick Humour; and when as this cholerick Humour is made preternaturally thin and hot, it frameth Herpes exedens, or that Dieae by Celus called Ignis ac • r, by Avicen Formica corroiva, becaue by its corroion it doth pread it elf. This preternatural Choler mixing it elf with Flegm it formeth that Herpes which hath many mall Putles in the skin, like to Millet or Hyre-eed, and thence is called Herpes miliaris. And ince as we may apparently find that there are two orts, the one from Choler mixed with Flegm, the other ariing from a dut Choler; our preent dicoure hall onely reach to the firt, the latter more properly ought to be reckoned amongt Ulcers.Signs: The Signs of the firt are many mall Putles like Millet-eed, in the upper part of the Cutis, and ariing from the mixture of Flegm; then they encreae in their number, the former growing old; and when they are
opened or rent, the Matter which cometh forth from them is between Sanies and Pus, partly reddih, being omewhat of a mixt Colour between red and white.Caues: All the Caues may be related to thoe of an Eryipelas, ave onely that this Tumour is made from a redundancy of preternatural Choler; an Eryipelas coming from natural.Preage. Celus doth propoe, that as Ignis acer hath little danger, o amongt uch creeping Dieaes its very hard to cure; for ometimes there is an Intemperiety of the Liver, which may be another Caue of this difficulty. This cure may be performed by having a repect to the whole habit of body: and ince it doth not much irreemble an Eryipelas, I do commend you thither to • etch convenient Medicines both inward and outward, which may do you great ervice in this Cure,Herpes exedens. The econd ort Herpes exedens is o called from Erodendo; for it doth not onely erode the Cutis, but doth alo depopulate the ubject Fleh. Celus Cap. 28. de acro igne lib. 5. doth decribe its nature, when he aies it is made with an Exulceration of the Cutis, not very deep, large, ublivid, inequally planting its elf in the extream parts.Signs. As often therefore as we ee an Ulcer
to grow and increae, and to make mall Ulcers, and many mall Cavities penetrating no further then the Cutis, this we may properly call Formica Corroiva. It is to be cured with Cholagogicks, Cure. as the former: and whereas it is a Dieae ariing from a preternatural hot and harp Choler proceeding with Putrednes, Phlebotomy is no waies proper here, for it very oft times doth arie from Cacochymy, purging with Senna, Damask Roes and the like in Whay, or good, Caia, Manna, or
• e • itive Electuary, or a Decoction of Saraperilla, China, and Guaiacum. And as touching the part affected, thee are very proper here to be ued. . ucc. Tabac. iij. Cerate: Cer. Citrin. ij. Rein. Pin. is. Terebinth. venet. i. ol. Mirtin. q. . fiat Ceratum molle . Camphor. Album. ovor. no. iiij. ucc. Plantag. Solan. an. i. Plumb. ut. Ceru. alb. Lithargyr. aur. an. ij. pulv. Troch. alb. Rha. Unguent: ine Op. i. ol. Roar. iiij. Pomat. ij. fiat nguentum. With this let the Patient be anointed three or four times in a day. Or this, . ucc. Plantagin. Lapath. Unguent. acut. Solan. an. i. ucc. Polygan. ij. Lithargyr. aur. i. Tuth. praeparat. Antimon. an. . Alo. citrin. iij. Cer. alb. ol. Myrtill. ol. Roar. an.
parum, mice, fiat nguentum, both for deterging and drying up of the Ulcer. I hall conclude this Chapter with this Hitory of a young Gentleman who was burnt from his foot to his knee, but very lenderly that it did carce hurt the Cutis, coming to an Emprick who from the firt ued Empl. Hitory. ex Argilla Bol. armeny, with the whites of Eggs, mixed with the Juices of Nighthade and Houleek, dipping clothes therein and applying them to the part affected, the pain which was but mall grew into a great degree by the ue of thee; he became vexed with a Fever, diquiet, and afflux of Humours to the affected part, and In • lammation of the whole Thigh, even to the Hip; and at length a Herpes exedens correpted the whole Thigh o vehemently, that ome Chirurgions thought to have made Amputation; but at length was thus cured: having firt precribed him this Potion. . rad. Scrophular. Cort. interior. rad, Frangul. Fomentation. rad. Polypod. an. . Herb. Fumar. Cueuth. Scabio. an. M. s. fol. enn. iij. mice, fiat Decoctum in aquâ ad iiij. in quibus olue Conf. Hamech. ii. yr. Roar. olutivar. i. mice, fiat potio; the day following he was bled in the Bailica of the ame ide the Herpes
was, and the Humour prepared with a purging Apozeme againt Melancholy already precribed in a Scirrhous Tumour. The body being thus prepared, we arrived at Topicks: and here, becaue the Cutis was already made hard by the ue of cold Medicines formerly applied by this Quack, there was firt ued this Emollient Fomentation two or three times in a day, with which the part affected was fomented. . rad. Bimalv. cum Tot. Lapath. acut. Screphular. an. ij. fol. Malv. Violar. fl. Melilot. Sambucin. Melilot. an. M. i. em. Faenugraec. . coquantur in aquâ ad 3 partis conumptionem. The part affected being herewith near half an hour fomented,Catapl: cover the parts with this Catapl. . farin. Fabar. Lupinor. an. lb. em. Fenugraec. Lin. an. ij. rad. Alth. recenter coct. & cribrat. iiij. pulv. fl. Chamomel. Roar. Melilot. & Abynth. an. i. mice, fiat Cataplama. With this being applied for fourteen daies, and the Fomentation continued, the hardned Skin grew oft, the Pain allaied, the ichorous Matter which flowed out of the Ulcer was prepared and brought to a fair Digetion, after this was prinkled upon the Ulcer Precipitate in pouder, being wahed in Plantane
and Roe-water, and over thee applied this Empl.Empl: . Empl. de Mucilaginib. Diapalm. an. iiij. De Ran. cum Mercur. i. Alumin. ut. Calcanth. an. . ol. Roar. q. . fiat Empl. molle. And about the end this Unguent. . rad. Scrophular. Lapath. acut. cort. Frangul. an. iiij. ucc. Fumar. Scabio. Acet. an. lbi. Pinguedin. Porcin. lbij. conquaentur Radices, & cum uccis ad eorum conumpt. coquantur, colentur, & colaturam erva ad uum. . hujus pinguedinis colatae lbi. pulv. Alumin. Vitriol. opt. farin. Lupinor. bacc. Laur. Ciner. fuligin. an. is. Argent. viv. extinct. ij. Theriac. i. fiat nguent in mortario. With this anoint the whole Leg keeping his Body open with Conf. Hamech. &c.

div.div:
CHAP. XXIX.
Of a Gangrene and Sphacelus.
A Gangrene is that which doth feed on the fleh, and poyoneth it, and imprints a trange unnatural Quality in it. By the Greeks it is called
< in non-Latin alphabet > from the verb < in non-Latin alphabet > , that is, Exedere: What a Gangrene is. But there are more eential Definitions hereof; by ome it is aid to be a change from a natural to a preternatural Colour, and by thee it is called Mortificatio; Galen doth call a Gangrene the beginning of a Mortification in the part affected, the which doth o trouble and infet the neighbouring parts, that without the bet of Medicine be applied by a very skilful hand, it does peedily run it elf into a Mortification. Inflammation by him alo is accounted as a very great Intrument hereof, and here beginneth a change of Colour, decay of Sene, a turning to Mortification. We more properly allow and decree it the beginning of a Mortification, and that it very oft times happens, the which I have very frequently found in my practice experimentally to follow or ucced large Inflammations,
and thereby do corrupt the oft parts as the Mucles,What a Sphac • lus is. Cutis, Veins, &c. A Sphacelus is wore than the former, for under this name we may comprehend Syderatio, Putrefactio, Corruptio, and Mortificatio.
< in non-Latin alphabet > by the Greeks is held to be a mot intene Dieae, o is a Gangrene by the Arabians. A Gangrene is a Dieae conequent to the effect not to the caue: Sphacelus is a Dieae exeding and compreing the parts: It is a perfect Syderation and Mortification, for a Member being corrupted with a Sphacelus is found plainly cold and dead. While the member is in a dying poture and not quite dead,The di • ference between a Gangrene and a Sphacelus. it is called a Gangrene; this for the mot part remaineth in the upper uperficies, and doth onely poes and affect the Mucles and oft parts: in a Sphacelus not thee onely, but the Bones themelves become affected. In a Gangrene the Skin groweth red, by reaon of its companion Inflammation; in a Sphacelus it firt groweth pale, then livid, and afterwards black. In a Gangrene you have no very ill mell; in a Sphacelus never expect a good mell. In a Gangrene your greatet deign mut be to prevent the preading of the Humour, and if it hath got place,
to prevent its growth: in a Sphacelus its lot labour then to act or treat any other waies than by Amputation; for there is no hope of bringing a dead part to life. It gains its Name of Syderatio from that of Plants, being a proper paion of them; when they loe their natural moiture, the which doth afford them their full growth and beauty, this affect is called Syderatio, as if they were truck by the Stars.3 Caues of a Gangrene. The immediate Caues of a Gangrene are three. Intemperiety of the part, when the tranpiration of the Spirits are obtructed, and when both the Heat and Spirits of the part are uffocated. Sometimes it cometh by cold, and then is to be dicharged by heat; in Gun-hot Wounds it doth frequently happen by reaon of large Contuions; it is ometimes alo bred by the carelenes of Phyicians, who in the curing of an Eryipelas in the beginning do order and precribe cold things, o being in Act and Power, that they are made capable to detroy the natural Heat; oft times by defluxion of Humours, or venenate Putles, which are left uncured; ometimes out of immoderate Drines; other times ariing out of the Interception of the vital Spirits, and very often out of Obtruction
in the beginning of the Nerves. And ince there is a Mortification and Extinction of life, and Detruction of the native Heat,The univeral Caues both of Gangrene and Sphacelus. let us conider which way, and out of what univeral Caues this may happen. Mans innate Heat cannot be upported without a radical Moiture, and its Spirits jutly and in their order implanted in all the parts of his body; o that conequently upon hurting or offering any injury to this radical Moiture its Spirits alo will be reolved, diipated and conumed; and therefore firt there is an Intemperiety occaioned out of the vehement alteration of the manifet Quality: Secondly out of the occult Quality a malign and virulent Subtance is contracted in the Body: and thirdly the Parts are thus mutually affected with an Interception and Suffocation of the vital Spirits. As to the firt,To the firt: Galen doth oberve and offer, that every thing is kept, preerved, and propagated by its natural Heat and Temper, o that nothing can alter or detroy this ooner than a contrary preternatural Temper and Heat; thus a Gangrene doth happen after a long and tedious continuance of an Inflammation, made either by Affluxion or Congetion of ome anguinary or cholerick Humour, the natural
Humour being dried up by the preternatural.To the econd. It may arie econdly, either from a concomitant Malignity either brought outwards to the Body, by the biting of ome venemous creature, or by adhibiting of Septicks. Signs of a Gangrene from a hot intemperiety. In a hot Intemperiety the Pain and Pulation which formerly were concerned with the Pulation is much more remis, and the red Colour of the Inflammation doth begin to change into a Lividnes; here alo do arie Putules filled with an ichorous Matter, thee being all Forerunners of its tending to Mortification; and both Heat and Blood do perfectly run to the Center, whilt the other parts thereof do uffer Putrefaction. It ariing from cold doth caue and make a great and pricking Pain.Signs of its coming from cold. Soon after this it changeth its red Colour into Lividnes, and maketh it mot cold; afterwards ending the Blood away by its Coldnes, and dipatching the native Heat, and diipating its Spirits, doth make the affected part perfectly void both of ene and motion, a horrour and trembling attending it much like the fit of a Quartane Ague. There is generally held five Signs of a Sphacelus. 5 Signs of a Sphacelu • : Firt, the affected part is much more heavy and dull than formerly it was. Secondly, the Floridnes
and Rednes of the part do turn into a Lividnes and Blacknes. Thirdly, the part which was oft in a Gangrene groweth hard in a Sphacelus. Fourthly, the Cutis being taken up is een with eae to eparate it elf from the Fleh. And latly, there is no exquiite ene or perfection, but a perfect Mortification remains. We are, if we intend to cure a Gangrene aright, to tudy and find out the Antecedent Caue thereof,Cure. and from thence to take our firt Intention,1 From the Antecedent Caue. as thus; If it happen from a fiux of hot and moit Humours, let the Patient's Diet be cooling and drying for purging; nothing is more proper here than Chologogicks, as Electuarium Diaprunum, Diacatholicon, Lenitivum, Syrup of Roes and the like. Phlebotomy is very neceary alo, to prevent the further growth of Inflammation, for opening the paages, and making a more free Tranpiration: but in all orts or kinds of Gangrenes this is not to be ued; For in a Cholerick and bilious Humour we are not to attempt it, Blood being as the bridle to check and command this Choler.6 Intentions in applying of proper Medicines. In the cae of applying of Topical Medicines oberve thee rules. The firt is taken from the Caue; for if the afflux be cold and flegmatick, evacuate
more powerfully, and warm the Humours with Defenatives. The econd is taken from the Age of your Patient; for in a young body the Fleh and all its parts are oft and tender, and therefore are you to order and precribe milder Medicines than to thoe of a fuller growth. A third arieth from the Sex; a Child being to be treated with more mildnes and Gentlenes than one of an elder age, and a Woman more tenderly dealt with than a Man. The fourth is from the Strength of the Patient; for you may powerfully exercie your operations on uch as are of a good and trong contitution, whereas you are more paringly and tenderly to ue uch perons as are weak and ickly. The fifth arieth from the part affected; for the Eye, Mouth, Pudenda, Anus, Vertebre, and other uch enible parts are not to be dealt with, as you may deal with an Arm or Legg. Sixthly the greatnes of the Dieae is to be much minded and regarded: If it be new done, and the Putrednes not much,A particular Cure of a Gangrene coming from Inflammation. nor made any deep impreion, to carrify the part lightly, and to apply Aegyptiacum alone is enough; If it be more powerful and do threaten a Sphacelus, here is to be made a deep Scarrification, and you are
to mix Spirit of Wine with Aegyptiacum very hot and often: Thee are your general rules. I come now to the proecution of a particular Gangrene ariing from Inflammation;1 Intention. and here the firt Intention is to be performed by Atringents or Deiccatives as, . Bol. armen. iiij. Unguent: Terr. igillat. ij. Corn. Cerv. ut. & praeparat. raur. Ebor. an. ij. Camphor. iij. Cer. iij. Ol. Roar. lbi. Acet. iiij. Aqu. Roar. iij. Albumin. ovor. no. ij. mice, fiat nguentum. A Cataplam for the ame is this. . farin. Hord. Catapl. iiij. Bol. armen. ij. pulv. Gallar. virid. nuc. Cupres. Cort. Granator. an. Second Intention.
