i. Camphor. i. cum Oxymelite q. . fiat Cataplama. The econd Intention is to revel the Humours and to end and dicharge them into other parts. And here this Bolus is proper Ca. recentèr extract. ij. Elect •• r Diacatholic. . cum Saccharo q. . fiat Bolus.
<…>
The third Intention is to retore the part to its former health, and this is to be performed by evacuating the Blood, and other compacted Humours from the part affected and therein concluded. And ince I have given you the general and particular Method of curing a Gangrene in general, I hall till illutrate it with ome examples: It being
a thing of great import as touching the Life and Limb of many a Man. And for brevities ake, becaue I do not deire to well up my book with Tautologies, or commit to your reading here any thing you hall elswhere find parallel, I will preent you with a Hitory of a vertuous maiden Gentlewoman in Norfflolk near Norwich, Hitory. who after a long and tedious Sicknes had a very large and great Inflammation eized her Foot, the which very peedily pread her Legg, and got upwards into her Thigh, with a great Dicoloration, Pain, Heat, and Fever accompanying. My never to be too much eteemed Uncle being ent for to this Lady, could not go to her; I being by Sir Thomas Brown's order ent for, and finding all thee already written ymptoms upon her, conulted with my elf and reaon, what might be the mot afe way to quit her from the enuing danger he without peedy help might fall into: with this Method and Almighty aitance I got her looed from her fears and perplexities which threatned a Gangrene. I firt anointed her parts affected with this mixture.Oyl. . Ol. Roar. Aueth. Chamomel. a • . ij. Acet. Acer
• i • n. i. mice, and having finihed this
Embrocation, I applied to all the inflamed parts this Cataplam.Catapl . farin. Fabar. lb. farin. Hord. Lupinor. an. iij. pulv. Roar. rubr. i. pulv. fl. Chamomel. Melilot. Sambuc. an. i. farin. em. Fenugraec. iij. Croc. i. Bol. armen. ij. Corn. Cerv. ut. . Camphor. i. pulv. herb. Rut. Scord. Abynth. Scabio. Virg. aur. Agrimon. Veronican. i. pulverientur omnia & miceantur cum Vin. & Aqu. fontan. an. q. . his addendo Acet. Roat. ij. & coquantur ad Cataplamatis formam, fine addendo ol. Roar. Aneth. Chamomel. an. ij. By the application of this Cataplam within three or four daies the enemy began to take his leave of her. I continued every day anointing and applying this Cataplam to her. After this upon the back part of her Foot a new flux of Humours began to make their incurion, and there they made two Ulcers, in which were contained a great quantity of thick cold indigeted Matter lying very deep, and there preading it elf, much reembling a Coar or Echar, for the removing and taking away of which I ordered this Fomentation, with which the whole Foot was fomented eight or ten times one after another, for three Weeks or a Month
together. . fol. Rut. Scord. Abynth. Veronic. Melis. Betonic. Salv. Hyperic. an. M. i. Tormentill. Chamaedr. Virg. aur. Laur. Rorimar. an. M. . fl. Roar. rubr. Chamomel. Melilot. an. M. . coquantur omnia in Aqu. fontanae lbvi. Vini albi lbvi.. ad med. Conumptionem, fine addendo Alumin. Roch. . With this was bathed the Legg and Foot very oft times every day. The Ulcers I dreed with this.Decoction. . Spirit. Vin. ij. Aqu. Abynth. compoit. i. Aegyptiac. . pulv. Myrrh. Aloes an. . Camphor. i. mice. With this Decoction were they wahed very often: after this was applied nguentum ex Apio for deterging it. By thee means I dicharged thee preternatural Matters; and then I digeted the parts with this Digetive. .Digetive: Tereb. venet. lot. in aqu. Roar. iiij. mel. Roat. iij. farin. Lupinor. Lolii an. ij. Ol. Rhod. i. pulv. Myrrh. alo. an. i. vitell. ovor. no. ij. coquantur lentiimo igne, fine addendo Theriac. Andromach. ij. Croc. . mice, fiat nguentum. Sometimes I applyed this Cataplam. . farin. Fabar. iiij. Ca • apl. Sal. marin. i. pulv. Scord. Rut. Abynth. an. i. pulv. Roar. em. Faenugraec. an. iij. farin. Hord. i. Camphor. . pulv. fl. Melilot. Chamomel.
an. i. coquantur lentiimo igne in Oxymelite q. . fine addendo pulv. Myrrh. Aloe. an. iij. mice, fiat Catapl. This being as excellent a dicuive Cataplam as may or can be ued. After I had deterged it, I filled it up with new Fleh by applying nguent. Bailicon . Aurei ij. his addendo pulv. Myrrh. Alo. an. . And o I continued until I perfected the Cure by producing a Cicatrice with nguent Diapompholigos with a little nguentum Rubrum mixed. Dodonaeus in his 53 Obervation doth report of a Child of ix years old having both his Hands and Feet correpted with a Sphacelus coming up to his Knees, and reaching each Elbow, upon whom death peedily did eize. Albucais lib. 2. cap. 87. doth relate a very trange tory of one who having a little blacknes appearing in his Toe,Hitory. did very peedily over pread his whole Foot; and eeing it extend it elf o much with pain and adution, for the prevention of its further growth, topped it by taking off the Foot at the Ancle. Sometime after the ame Patient complained of a Tumour which happened in his Finger, who coming to ask his advice about the ame, and having followed all directions as was thought mot proper to be
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
ued, as cleaning the Body, and purging the uperfluities by a good order of Diet and habit of Body, and the like, yet none of thee took place, but this Curruption till pread until it got him hold by the Hand: he being by the Patient deired to make Amputation of it for fear it might erve him as did his Foot, he refued it, hoping by other Remedies, and advantage of good Medicines, to put a top to its increae, and to quell its fury; but thee were pent to no purpoe: the Patient being both of a Cacochymick Body, and weak, and perceiving no help by thee, was willing to have his Arm taken of, the which being performed, the Patient perfectly recovered and grew very well. Another pious peron, a Gentleman of good decent, having been let blood in his right Arm by an unskilful Chirurgion, was perplexed with a Gangrene and Sphacelus: and here advice was given that he might abtain from trong Remedies, the Nerve being pricked, for this would onely ubject it to the increae of pain; and therefore uch mild Medicines were ordered, which might have a drying Quality in them to parch up this erous Humour, uch as this. . Terebinth. venet. lot. in
aqua Plant aginis ij. Bol. armen. pulv. ij. imul incorporentur. In this cae alo our Balom is accounted a mot excellent Remedy, thus compoed. . Ol. Roar. i. ol. Terebynth. iij. uce. Plantag. . em. Hypericon. contrit. M. s. Tuth. praeparat. iij. Calc. decies lot. in aqua Plantaginis ij. Antimon. i. evi Hircin. Vitulin. Verm. terretr. in vino lot. i. coquantur imul; dempta Tuthia, in Cyatho decoctionis Hordei ad conump. & Vini & aquae, colentur, rurumque igni admoveantur, addendo fine Tuthiam, & fiat Linimentum cum Cer. alb. & Croc. an. . & erva ad uum. Thee I produce as Introductions to my future Dicoure as touching the order of Amputation, which is very material in the true and methodical proceedings in Chirurgery, and the onely Remedy left to ecure the whole, by ablating of the diaffected part. And that I may ue all the weet Methods to procure the young Student into a fair compliance and affection of his Art, and that he may quit the repute of a Quack, and defend himelf againt the calumnies that daily do hroud themelves under the pretences of ignorances and mitakes, let him with me oberve this my oft experienced Method,
both ued in the Wars in his Majeties ervice at Sea, and not onely in England, but alo in France and other places, with good ucces and credit. I have alo in this Chapter et down what Intruments the Chirurgion ought to have in readines to perform this office of Amputation, what Method he ought to proceed in, how he ought to be furnihed, how prepared with Rollers, Bolters, Pledgets, Buttons, Retrictives, Sawes, dimembring Knives, dividing Knives, actual and potential Cauteries, Needles, Sponges: and after thee have been all made ready and fitted for your intended purpoe, you are to make ready your Retrictive, with which you are to arm your large Pledget, which is to cover the amputated part with, being made of Bolarmeny, Amber, Dragons blood, Matich, red Roes, Powder of Hares hair, with Flour, Vinegar, oyl of Roes, and Roe-water; with this you are both to cover your large Pledget, and alo to pread your Chin-band (as it is generally called) which is to be laid above as a Defenative to hinder the Defluxion of Humours; and then to arm your Buttons with Calcanthum or calcined Vitriol; then to have Cordials in a
Place this Figure Fol: 20 •
readines. A lively Portraict of this operation you have here expreed in this Figure. And uppoing the Legg was to be amputated, having all your Intruments and other things made ready, you are firt to make a trict Bandage by Roller four Fingers beneath the Knee, and a little below that with your dimembring Knife divide or cut the Mucles and other parts from the Bones, by guiding it round with all expedition; then having your dividing Knife in readines, eparate the Membrane which lodges and keeps between the two Foils; and then with your Saw divide the Bones. And while you are going to perform this Operation be ure you be furnihed with two Aitants at leat, one to hold the Legg which is to be amputated teddily, whilt the other doth contract or gripe the upper part to prevent a large flux. And that your Patient may not droop, you are to have in readines uch like Cordial as this, . Aqu. Cinomom. Spirit. Menth. aqu. Mirabilis an. Cordial:
ij. Aqu. Theriacal. . aqu. Meli. Aceto. Calendul. an. i. Confect. Alkerm. . cum yr. Caryophyllor. & Lujul. an. q. &. fiat Cordiale. The Legg being taken of, you are next to apply your Buttons being armed with
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
Calcanthum; over thee lay your large Pledget covered with the Retrictive; after thee your Bladder to incloe the former; and then with convenient boltring and Rollers perform your firt Intention, oberving that your Patient be preently committed to his Bed; and after this endeavour to correct all inuing accidents. On the third day you may looen your Patient, and open it; then apply uch things as may remove the Echar, as nguent. Bailicon, Aureum, Dialthea, Axungia or Butter; Then cleane the part with Spirit of Wine and Aegyptiacum, if occaion require; Then diget with Aureum, or Bailicon, adding to them a little powder of Mirh, Aloes, the Yolk of an Egg, and a little Turpentine, fill it up, and Cicatrice it with Bailicon mixed with Rubrum Deiccativum, or Diapompholigos, or the like. By the ue of thee Medicines within a very few years I cured a Child of about five or ix years of age at Wootton in Norfolk, Hitory. who by an unhappy michance had a Gangrene, and afterwards a Sphacelus correpted his Arm above the Elbow. The Child by a fall fractured both the Radius and
lna, a Country man being ent for to reduce it, after he had finihed his
Operation, whether by two trict Bandage, or another fall occaioned this, I cannot certainly jutify, but the poor man being much amazed at the ight came to Norwich for me; where eeing how far it had pread, we had no other way to ave the Patient's life but by Amputation, the which being performed, and the ame Method being oberved, the Child was perfectly cured, and till remains in health. And thus much of preternatural Tumours in general.

div.head: OF Preternatural Tumours IN PARTICULAR And firt of thoe of the Head.
CHAP. XXX.
Of Artheroma
div.p:
I HAVE omitted everal other Tumours, which by mot Authors have been ranked amongt Generals, and have them contracted amongt others in their particular places, where they generally or for the mot part are reputed to take their abode: and of thee I begin with uch which frequently do poes and inflict the Head, and o then gradually uher in all uch as do affect the ret of the parts of the Body even to the Foot and Toes. Of thee which do afflict the Head are reckoned Artheroma, Steatoma, Meliceris, Ta •
pa, or Tetudo, Hydrocephalos, Tinc • , Pydracium: all thee being mot commonly allowed to border and inhab ••
upon the outward,What Artheroma is. and inward, and upper part of the hairy Scalp and Cranium. Of the firt of thee is Artheroma, which is an Abces containing in its Citus or bagg Matter much reembling that of Pultice, ariing from mixt Humours, in which is Flegm as its cheif Agent, from whence it gaineth its white Colour. It is alo accompanied with other Waterih qualities, eroding the parts, being much like Whey. It is a longih round ublated Tumour, being preed with the Finger not readily yeilding, nor yet making retrogradation the fingers being taken off. The Curative Intentions here are the ame with thoe of all other Abcees:Oberva. Yet here is to be oberved, that the Curation of all Abcees is contained in the Dicharge and Evacuation of the Matter, the which is either Senible or Inenible; the Inenible to be cured by Digetives, the Senible to be ablated by Section.Care. Thee being propoed, we are to cure Artheromaes by Septicks, as Verdegreae, Chryocolla, Arenick, Orpiment, Lime, Chalk and the like: or this. . Calc. viv. ij. faec. Vin. combut. Nitr. liquid. tost. ij. Min. i. Lixivio terantur, & ad mellis ubtantiam reducantur. If it yeildeth not to thee, or you find it
ripe for the Intrument, ue this Method, place your Patient in a good form for your Operation, let his Head be haven about the place where the Artheroma is; 'then mark with ink how far or long you intend to make your Inciion, which hould be quite through the whole Tumour, the which ometimes doth require a cros Inciion, as that you pas it as far the other way, if it be large. Here ue your Inciion-knife, it being for this purpoe the mot proper and convenient Intrument;Oberv. and here are you carefully to oberve that you only divide the upper Cutis, and that you perform this o dexterouly, that you do no ways touch the Citus of the Artheroma; and that you may do this more promptly, you are to have Spunges in readines to dry up the Blood, that the part may better hew it elf. The Section being made, eparate the Citus either with a Probe or ome other convenient Intrument, the which for the mot part you may do with eae: eparate it from the Cutis with your Inciion-knife; but in the lower part, that you may divide the Vein or Artery that gave it its being, origination, and growth. After you have dicharged the Matter, and the
Citus, apply this following Digetive . Terebinth. venet. i. pulv. Thur. i. Myrrh. i. Ol. Hyperic. i. Ol. de Vitel. Ovor. Hitory q. . fiat uguentum. In this City of Norwich I thus cured A French Mans Wife of everal Artheromaes which poeed her Head, one of which was very large and oft, the which I opened with making a cros Inciion, having well prepared and purged her Head with Cephalicks, as Extractum Rudii, Pillulae Aureae, and the like: After this I opened the Abces, and dicharged the Matter, ablated the Citus; and this being removed, I perceived a mall Capillary Veel upon the taking away of the Bag to pin and pend its Blood which treamed out, the which I peedily topped by the application of ome of his Majeties Stiptick water, which I applied to the part by dipping a mall Pledget of Lint (the which anwered my expectation) and o bound it up: The Day following I dret her again with Spirit of Wine, & Elixar Proprietatis, by the application of which within few days the Woman was perfectly cured; her large Abces dicharged; her other mall ones, which were ix (the which I believe were fed and nourihed by the ame mall Arterial
Branch) were by degrees dipered, and at length vanihed. Coming to the ame Patient not many Weeks after to enquire how he was, I found the ret perfectly were gone, which gave me atifaction of my conjecture: for upon the echarotizing of this Branch not only their growth were hindred, but alo a perfect banihment procured of the whole, and (to the praie of the Highet) he remaineth very well without any fear of a new growth of the ame.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI.
Of Steatoma.
div.p:
THIS is an Abces having in it the ubtance of Fatt or Sewet, mall at firt, but in proces of time growing larger: It is a Tumour round, not elevated, but depreed; and Aetius doth add, it adhereth firmly to the Skin: Its ubtance is not fluid, but compact and coacted: It is not therefore contained in one Bag, as the former, but is lodged between two Coats. And when
it is in the Head, it doth contain in it a Matter reembling Sewet, a large Bais, and doth not yield to the touch; when it is in other parts, it is een to contain in it Matter much like Fatt, more like this than Sewet; neither is its colour there o white: It is generated, as is Sewet, by reaon of the Intemperiety of the place, or by reaon of ill Blood. They are carce ever cured, but by manual operation. If the Veicle be broken, and you do not draw all out, it will leave either a Fitula, or a foul Ulcer. As touching its Cure, in repect of its hardnes, broad Bais, multitude of Sewets, it is only to be handled as other Abcees; this Sevum is to be wholly eparated from the Pericranium, let the Abces do make a freh return. Here may you make a cros Inciion, if it be large, and take care of touching the Veicle, let you make a faetid mell and ulceration: This being performed, pres out your Citus, cut off the branch that fed it, and have a care that the leat particle remaineth not: this being done, cleane it, and ue your greatet care to produce a Cicatrize. There was a Gentleman, who was troubled with a Steatoma in his Inguen,Hitory. weighing near forty pounds, his
whole Body redounding with pituitous Blood; a good and thin Dyet being precribed, ordering him to abtain from all vicid and thick food, as Milk, Cheee, and the like, and precribing him a Honey-drink, in which Ginger and Time were boyled, and outwardly applying uch Medicines as may dicus this Flegmatick matter, as Fomentations and the like being every Night and Morning repeated, and preparing the Humour with Oxymel of Squills, and then by intervals ordering him to take ome of thee Pills of Aloes Roatae 5. Troch. de Agaric. ij. Turbith. gummo. . Squinanth. rad. Aar. an. gr. 5. ZZ. s. Cinamom. i. Rhabarb. . Troch. Alhandul. gr. 15. cum Oxymelit. Scillitic. q. . fiat maa pillul • rum. dois a ij. ad i. And this Oyl being outwardly applied as . Ol. Philoophor. Latern. l. Thur. Matich. gum. Arabic. Terebinth. venet. an. iij. pitentur, & per alembicum ditilla, & fine ditillationis addatur Sal. ex ciner. Cerr. & iterum ditilla, quod pro uu reerves. By thee this great Tumour was diipated and digeted; this you may read of in Langius Epitol. 4. lib. 3.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII.
Of Meliceris.
div.p:
THIS Abces hath a Matter contained in its Citus much reembling Honey, and is thus by Aetius decribed; It is an Abces encloed in a Nerveous Coat, containing a Matter like Honey, wanting pain, having a round Figure, eaily yielding to the touch, and the finger being taken off it doth as peedily turn into its former condition.Its Caue. The caue hereof is a mixt preternatural Humour. And although every Abces contained in a Bag hath Matter going along with it, yet are thee divided into four Modes or Forms: hence in a Meliceris, becaue it is oft and thin, its Flegm is mixed with a greater quantity of Choler than in an Artheroma, or Flegm, out of which is made this Meliceris.Cure: This is to be cured three ways, by Digetives, Cauticks, or Amputation. As touching the Septicks or Cauticks, we have already treated in Steatoma: we hall here more properly treat of Digetives, the which becaue they do dicharge this Matter perporos
cutis, they ought to be powerful and trong, and to exceed in their vigour more than in thoe Abcees which are encloed in Bags. Whence in mall and moit Melicerides a Decoction Pulegii, Calamenthae, Hyopi & Meliae made and applied hot with a Sponge is here accounted very proper: but if tronger be required, you are to make a tronger Lixivium, in which boil the aforeaid Herbs, and apply it to the part affected: or for the ame you may ue this of Aetius, which he hath in his 15th Book, . Sal. armoniac. Spum. argent. li. Cer. Terebinth. Galban. Opoponac. an. i. Rubric. Synopic. .vi. Acet. heminam. mice; Or this, . Diachyl. 12. pul. Irid. ij. mice. or Diachyl. cum gummi, to which may be added a little powder of Ireos. Empl. Emplatrum Alexandrinum here alo is much commended, thus made . Sal. Armoniac. Litharg. Ceru. an. i. Galban. Opoponac. an. iiij. Sem. Sinap. . Ol. veter. iiij. Cer. Terebinth. an. i. mice, fiat Emplatrum. If this Method ucceedeth not, we are to come to the ue of Suppuratives: And of thee ome may erve for the prohibiting the egres of Vapours, and not only obtructing, but alo keeping in the inward native Heat:
others do not only obtruct, but do alo heat, and by the calefying quality do rarefie and thin the parts; of the ame qualities hould our mot proper Medicines be framed, as this of Rhais. . Farin. Sem. Lin. ij. Faenugraec. . pulv. Sem. Caul. i. Mucilag. rad. Alth. q. . fiat Empl. In the lat place I take crude Figs, and beat them in a Mortar, and to thee I add a Snail, and beat with them, and order this Medicine to be laid on, and o kept on, until it falleth off of its own accord. After you have made it fit to open, dicharge the Matter, as I have directed you in the other two Chapters; then apply Digetives, convenient Deterives, Sarcoticks and Epouloticks. Amongt all thee three Tumours I mut acquaint you, that it is not very frequent for the putrid Matter to exalt it elf in thee Tumours of the hairy Scalp; and therefore Cauticks are the mot proper Intruments to occaion this, but here not to be ued. Langius lib. primo Epitol. 38. Writeth of a Woman, who having an Ulcer in her Matrix had alo a Meliceris accompanying it; and when it gave the greatet hope to the Chirurgion of its conolidation,Hitory. a new Ichor began afreh, and forced it elf out; he being thought
to be bewitched, by good Prayers and divine Ejaculations the Woman had her Ulcer pontaneouly conolidated and cured.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII.
Of Pydracium.
div.p:
THIS is a yellowih harp Putle, out of which, if it be preed, cometh a Moitnes according to Celus. Galen eemeth to place it ometimes amongt the Tumours of the Eye-lids, ometimes he will have it a Tumour of the Head.Whence its Name: It is called Pydracium, either becaue it is een to appear harp in the Head, or ele becaue it doth contain in it a great quantity of a waterih humidity. Thee do arie from mixt Humours; and by how much the whiter they are, this hows they have more Flegm in them, the harder come from Choler, and the harp and mall from Water.Cure. The Cure is to be performed by moderate Coolers, and Dicuives; Coolers as for allaying and tempering the heat of Choler, and
Dicuing in repect of Flegm: here alo are to be oberved a good order of Dyet, a good repect to the habit of Body to keep it open, and by purging it from its Flegm and waterih Humours as this. .Pil. Extr. Rud. i. Pil. Coch. . Rein. Jallap. Pil: gr. vi. mice: or this, . Pil. ine quib. aur. Indic. an. . Rein. Scammon. . mice for two does. The part affected is to be treated with Coolers and Dicuives, as are Mallowes, with Barley Meal and Cicers being made into a Decoction, or ome of my dicuing Cataplam already precribed, or this .Catapl. Farin. Fabar. i. Hord. ij. coquantur pocâ ad formam Cataplamatis, in fine ebullitionis adde pulv. Roar. rubr. . pot unam ebullitionem ab igne remove, tunc mice album. & vitel. Ovor. no. Ol. Roar. parum, mice, fiat Cataplama. If the Pydracium be ulcerated, and a moit Humour cometh from thence, apply this . Litharg. aur. i. Ceru.. Alumin. ij. fol. Rut. cum Aceto & Oleo imul mixt. fiat nguentum, with which anoint the Skin; and having well embrocated it with this, you may conclude your Cure with this Liniment. . Lithargyr. aur. Ceru. pulv. an. ij. Sulphur. i. Ol. Roar. q. . fiat Linimentum: And latly, aqua
Scahioa is by many held to be mot excellent here Alome being added to it.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIV.
Of Hydrocephalos.
div.p:
THIS is a proper Tumour of the Head, ariing for the mot part from Water, and hence doth it take its name. This is a Ditemper which doth very oft come into the World with young Infants, being either bred with them in the Womb, or ele o as they are bringing into it. It may alo be occaioned by a careles, or ignorant, or unhappy Midwife. It may well be called a Cephalick Dropie, for it doth contain in it a proper Waterih ubtance, known by its indolency, oftnes, its eaie yielding to touch, but chiefly from its inundation of Water running out of one place into another in its compreion. Thee Tumours do often times vary;its differencies. for in ome they are mall, whilt in others they do appear very large; It is a peculiar Dieae in
the Head of young Children, the which arieth from too much Humidity of the Head; for which very Caue they which are much troubled herewith, do eldom live long, as both Galen, Aetius, and Paulus do oberve. This Tumour by Galen in Libr. Its Definition. definitionis is thus deigned, as being a collection of waterih Humours, or feculent Blood in ome parts of the Body, which doth force it elf up to the Head. And here is a double meaning to be explained; the one, whereas he calleth it not only a collection of a Serous Humour, but alo of a feculent Blood, as when the Head & Cranium uffers an outward Contuion or Colliion, and the Veins by this Colliion do prinkle their Blood between the Cutis and Pericrane. This Blood here thus putrifying doth make a mot oft Tumour; and if a erous aquoity were collected, the which by dayly experience may well be offered to happen, from a Contuion thus happening it may frame a Hydrocephalos. Aetius lib. 6. cap. 1. will have that a Hydrocephalos may be generated from a Feculent or bloody Matter, the which being changed into a thin ubtance. A econd of Galens is, that a Hydrocephalos is a collection of an aquous Humour in ome part of thoe Bodies, which have a forcing quality towards the Head; out of
which it may be conjectured, that Galen doth offer, that Hydrocephalos to be a Dieae of ome part of the Head, not a Dropie of the whole Head; and this is confirmed by Aetius and Paulus, who treating of Hydrocephalos do allow four pecies hereof: Firt, when this Humour getteth between the Brain and Membranes: Secondly, when it lyes between the Membranes and the Skull: A third between the Bone and the Pericrane: And Latly, when between the Pericrane and the hairy Scalp.Signs: I have already hown you part of its Signs; that it is a Tumour oft in touch, whitih in colour, indolent, turgid, much like a Pillow to other parts, eaily yielding to touch, and as peedily filling up its former made vacancy, the Finger being removed. If it arieth from a Contuion, it doth appear firt red, and doth carry pain with it, as Aetius doth write; but being afterwards changed into a thin ubtance, it doth pread it elf without pain. In thoe where it happeneth between the Pericrane and Bone, they anwer plainly the ret; for here it is hard in Tumour, and very painful, by reaon of the ditention of the Pericrane; If it happeneth (as ometimes it doth) between the Membrane
of the Brain and the Skull, it will be a Tumour, but not yield to compreion, nor oft to touch. Here it maketh the Infant oon to give way to it, and to yield up its Ghot.Caues. Its Caues may be aid to be ometimes outward, ometimes inward. One of the outward may be aid to be that which is mentioned by Paulus in Children newly born, who had their Heads but ill bound up by their Midwives; Another is contuion, or colliion, or ruption of one or many Veels; Another caue is a cold Air, or too much Water, or thinnes of its paages or Veels, out of which this Serum or matter do recide, as Aetius hath it; or alo too cold or waterih Milk, which it may uck from the Nure: thee may be aid to be the inward Caues hereof, as when the Brain is too much cooled, or the matter being here firt collected, and hence ent to the Brain. Every Hydrocephalos is very low in its motion, as Aetius doth prove. Lib. 6. Cap. 1. For it hath a cold Brain inwardly from its beginning, ariing from its inward Caue, and alo an outward by and from its outward Caue, by reaon of its delay and contaction.Two Species of a Hydrocephalos. To draw all thee to one head, there is to be allowed two Species of a Hydrocephalos:
One in which this waterih Humour is contained and made by an inward Caue, that is out of an abundant collection of this erous matter in the Body: The econd doth not contain the incere Serum, but as it were a mixt feculent Blood, the which doth eat it elf out of the lacerated Veins, ariing from Contuion or ome other outward Caues. As to its Preage,Preage. Paulus Aetius and Galen do offer, that if this Humour be collected between the Brain and its Membranes, it is mortal; in other parts it may admit Cure, by curing its Caues, and removing its Effects. But here, as well as in other parts of the Body, the Rules of Celus and Galen are to be oberved; every Dieae is o much the more dangerous, by how much it gets into a greater bulk and bignes. As touching its Cure,Cure. we hall begin with that which is extant between the Hairy Scalp and Pericrane: And herewe are to oberve, that every Hydrocephalos is to be cured by dicharging of this waterih ubtance, which is to be performed by purging the whole, and cleaning the affected part. And with this we are to begin with general Cephalick Purgings; in which Cae may be ued thee and the like for Pils: as . Pil. Coch. . Rein. Jallap.
. Cambog. gr. iiij. mice. Thee are to be given to uch as have arrived at Manhood; Children may be precribed Syrup of Roes olutive, Syrup of Cichory with Rhubarb, Syrup of Buckthorn Berry and the like, either by themelves, or given with a Decoction made of Betony, Fennel-Seeds, Anic-Seeds, Aparagus, Liquorie, and the like. Sweating here alo is very proper, for which you may make a Decoction of Sarafras, Saraperilla, Guaiacum with Seeds, &c. Hence are we to warm and trengthen the cold and moit Brain: and this is to be performed by Inenible Evacuation, the which I much better approve of than of a enible; becaue it is neither o afe nor o ecure, for oft times times here, as well as in making a Paracentheis, the Patient dyeth in few days after the Operation, if not at the Operation. For dicharge of this contained Matter, by reaon of the thicknes of the Cutis, this is to be rare • ied and oftned; and for this purpoe this Fomentation is very proper, in which we may dip Sponges and apply to the part, as . Malv. Melilot. Aneth. an. M. i. Rad. Alth. i. fl. Chamomel. Decoction: Melilot. Roar. rubr. an. M. . coquantur omnia in Vino albo q. . & fiat Colatura, in hac colaturâ im • uatur
Spongia & parti admoveatur. In uch which are large, to thee you may add Roch Alume or Sal Armoniack, and boil with them, and o apply them. Gulielmus Placentinus doth offer Dicuives as to be here mot proper,Oyl. and doth order this. . Ol. Aneth. Chamomel. an. . pulv. Sulphur. . mice. Fallopius on the contrary doth as much eteem of Repellers, wherewith he doth declare he hath done very trange things, and aith, that only by the help of Oyl of Roes and of Oyl of Myrtils he hath cured everal Hydrocephalick Tumours in four days pace. Sometimes he doth add to thoe two Oyls green Cypres leaves and Wormwood bruied, and with this he frameth a Liniment.Hitory. Amatus Luitanus writeth, that he cured a Child of a Hydrocephalos in three days with this following Unguent. . pulv. Abynth. fl. Melilot. Chamomel. an. ij. Butyr. recent. Unguent. Ol. Chamomel. an. iiij. Cer. flav. q. . fiat nguentum. Or here alo may you afely ue this Unguent. . Ol. Laurin. Cotin. an. ij. Ol. Spic. de Laterib. an. i. Sulphur. Sal. commun. Alum. Unguent: ut. an. , Terebinth. ij. mice, fiat nguentum: Or this Cataplam, . pulv. Abynth. Origan. an. i. Mell. l. Empl. Sal. . mice, fiat Cataplama: Or
this Emplater of Empl. de Bacc. Laur. Sulphur. & Ammoniac. of each equal parts. If it yieldeth not to thee, but you be forced to Section, be ure your part be ripe enough and fit for your Knife: and when you make it, let it not be made too deep, but make it through the middle, as Paulus doth order, if it be mall; if large, then are you to make a tranvere Inciion like the Letter X, and afterwards get out all the Matter, cleane it, and follow its Cure, as I have directed you formerly in Artheroma, S • eatoma and Meliceris. But before you proceed to this operation, conider with your elf thee Inconveniences, which may follow and enue, that whilt you let forth this Serous Matter, you do let in Cold and Air, which do extinguih the native heat of the Brain. I rather aent in uch deperate Caes to the opinion of
• abritius, by letting out this matter by degrees, by making a mall Orifice, and therein placing a ilver hollow Pipe, which is hut up with a Silken Stopple, by the drawing forth of which you may let out as much or as little as you pleae, in the ame method and manner as you ue it in a Paracentheis; through this Pipe alo may you inject any convenient Liquors, or Decoctions; And this partly enibly,
partly inenibly this Humour may both with eae and afety be drawn forth. And if it hould arie from any Rupture of the Veels, in which not only the Serous Humour, but alo feculent Blood is contained, thee are to be both dicharged, dicued, incied and attenuated; and for this you may dip a Sponge in Poca, or Wine and Vinegar, and apply it. Barly Meal and Oxymel well mixed together may be very properly applied here. I hall here give you ome trange Examples, by which you may eaily perceive, how oon our natural Fabricks may be pulled down and wahed away, even at our firt appearance on this mundatory Stage.Hitory. Vealius writeth, that he aw a Girle of two years old, whoe Head was larger and greater than any Mans Head, occaioned thus by this ort of Tumour, and the Cranium not bony but membranous, and that there was nine pound of water did run out from this Tumour.Hitory. Leonellus de Morb. Pueror. Cap. 14. aw a young Child, which had its Head o much welled with Water, that one might ee through its outward Scalp the utures of the Skull; the caue of this great quantity of Water thus expending it elf out from the Skull was occaioned by the Midwife and Nure, the one in the extracting of the Child
from the Womb, whilt the other did econd it by compreing its Head too trictly, whence the Commiures were cut and opened, and the Humidity it elf, which was in the Brain, came to the outward covering of the Head, and thither preed out its Humidities; and this was the occaion of this tumeied Head. Rhais doth write, that he aw a Child, whoe Head did o encreae in length and bulk, that its Body could not carry it: and it ceaed not its augmentation, until the Child ceaed not to live. This you have Cap. 3. Lib. de morb. Pueror. Foretus relateth of a Child being brought to him, having a very great Head occaioned by this Ditemper, and this was his Curative Method: He commanded the Nure that he might have a drying Dyet, it was oft times purged with Pills of Hiera Picra, and was anointed with this Unguent. . pulv. Abynth. Chamomel. Origan. an. iij. pulv. Unguent: Myrtillor. Roar. rubr. fl. Melilot. an. i. Ol. Chamomel. q. . fiat cum Bntyro & Cera q. . ad formam unguenti: After the anointing with this, thee Powders were prinkled on its Head, made of Myrtils, Cloves, Roes, Cinamon, and Chamomile, by the benefit of which it was perfectly cured.
And to conclude this, Montanus de Infant. pag. Hitory. 8. relateth of a Smith, who had his Head tumeied to that greatnes, that it did exceed the bulk of an Oxes head, and that it obcured the whole Face with the Noe; he ordered a tick to be put into his Mouth, that he might obtain a free breathing, and by keeping every kind of a thin Dyet, and jut Methods to carry off and remove the Humour, this Tumour at length abolihed and vanihed.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV.
Of Talpa or Tetudo.
div.p:
THIS Dieae is thus o called from the reemblance it hath with a Mole, which dwells and inhabits in the Earth; for this is a creeping Humour, and gets between the Cutis and Pericrane. It differeth a little from Ficus, becaue as that is a Tumour ariing from mixt Humours; So is this elevating the Skin into a Tumour. It oft times doth o cloely adhere to the Cranium, that it fouleth it. It differeth from a Ficus, in that it is larger and bigger, and therefore is longer in its coming to uppuration; for it is made of thick Humours. Its Caues are various,Its Caues as alt and nitrous Flegm mixt with Choler, or a putrefactive Water. In Children it doth breed mot from weet Flegm. Sometimes it doth breed of Flegm and Blood together, but eldom of Melancholy. We ought to be very careful and circumpective in Adminitring our Medicines here, becaue here we meet with both Humour and Fluxion; the Body therefore is to be prepared and purged, the Humours corrected,
and the Peccant Matter dicharged: and for thee Pil. Aur. Coch. Aggregativ. Extract. Rud. Pil. ine Quibus, thee or any of thee are very ueful and profitable. Maticatories, and Sternutatories, are here very convenient: and to the affected part we are both to ue Emollients, and Digetives. If in the beginning of the ue of Emollients the Humours may any wie rebel, quell their fury by Digetives, as by mixing Diapalma and Minium with a little Betony together. Stronger are Lilly-roots with Honey, Narcius, Ireos with Honey, or the like applied. If it yieldeth not to thee, it doth how it elf tending to Suppuration; the which when you perceive, you are not to diturb it, but rather help it forwards in its operation, by applying Empl. Diachyl. cum gummi Mucilagin. Flos nguentor. In other Caes we are to ue Digetives; as . Caepar. Digetive. coct. ub cinerib. no. iij. Vitel. ovor. indurat. no. iij. Mucilag. Alth. Faenugraec. Lin. an. i. Ficuum contu. no. 10. Farin. Fenugraec. Lin. an. iij. fiat Cataplama, ub finem addendo Axung. Porcin. q. . then let it be opened, and dicharge all the Matter; then cleane it with Meal of Lupines and Honey, or nguent. ex Apis, and generate
Fleh with nguentum Bailicon or Aureum, and dry up with this or the like:Unguent. . Tuth. praeparat. Roar. rubr. an. i. Balaut. Bol. Armen. an. . mice cum unguento Diapompholigos, & fiat unguentum. Guido in his Chirurgick Tract.Hitory. 2. Doctr. cap. 1. relateth of a Man who had an ulcerated Talpa upon the Muculous part of the Head, the which corrupred, and fretted the Cranium o far, as might with eae be perceived the motion of the Pannicles: more of which you may read in the aforeaid Tract.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVI.
Of Tinea.
div.p:
THIS is a Dieae of the Head,Three orts hereof. poeing the hairy Scalp. Of this there are three orts, The firt hereof by Galen aid to be furfurous or quamous, for upon cratching it there do fall off many quamous Dandriff fleaks: A econd called Ficus, it omewhat reembling the inward part of Figs: A third by Galen called Achor, and this commonly is called corroive and ulcerous. All thee pecies do arie from a corrupt Humour, erring more or les in quantity or quality. The firt cometh of the mildet ort, the econd is more corrupt, and the third is more putrid than the two former. If this Dieae do forbear to how it elf, until the party which is therewith perplexed is arrived at the Age of Man, he may both purge and bleed;Cure. and for this effect uch Pills and Potions, as I have already precribed in an Eryipelas, may with advantage be ued here. As touching Topicks, let them be emollient and dicuive; as Marhmallows, Lilly-roots and the like; a dicuive Fomentation
and the like: Scarrification and applying of Leeches, are here alo very profitable: and afterwards anoint the part with this
nguent of Guido. Unguent. . Ellebor. alb. & nigr. Atrament. Sutor. Latharg. aur. Calc. viv. Vitryol. Roman. Alumin. gallar. virid. fuligin. Ciner. faec. Vin. ust. Argent. viv. extinct. an. iij. Aerugin. Aer. ij. fiat pulvis, incorporetur in ucco Borag. Scabio. Fumar. Oxylapath. Acet. an. quart. i. Ol. antiq. li. coquantur uque ad uccorum conumptionem, in fine decoctionis adde Pic. liquid. . Cer. flav. q. . fiat nguentum. This is by all Authors held as a mot excellent Unguent in call'd Heads. The Cruteous or Ficous is to be fomented o long, as until the cruts do fall away, and for this Naturtium tritum cum Axungia Porcina do make all fall off in 24 hours. Or this of Ambroe Parrey. . Pic. nigr. ij. pulv. virid. Aeris, Vitryol. Roman. an. i. Sulphur. viv. . coquantur omnia in aceto acerrimo q. . fiat nguentum. This is to be laid on for three days, and afterwards to be removed, this being our general way ued in St. Thomas Hopital in London, the place from which I took my Firt-fruits of Chirurgery, under that Worthy Mater Hollyer, by
all allowed a mot excellent Lithotomit and Operator in London. As to the third, deterge it with nguentum Aenulatum cum Mercurio, Aegyptiacum, of each . Vitriol. alb. ut. pulv. i. mice, fiat unguentum. And when the buines hath been thus ucceively treated, for eaing of pain, and moothing the Skin, anoint the parts with this following Unguent. . Camphor. . Alumin. Roch. Vitriol. Roman. Sulphur. viv. Fuligin. an. vi. Ol. Amygdal. dulc. Axung. porcin. an. ij. mice, fiat nguentum. Hitory: Hercules Saxoniae relateth in his Obervations of a Woman troubled with a Dieae poeing the Hairy Scalp, called Tinea, who by frequent wahings of her Head recovered her health, but in the interim he endured a continual pain thereof, and Fever, the which were not to be conquered by any Revulives, Derivatives, or Purgatives, and in thirty days after he dyed; and upon opening the Cranium, the half of the Brain with its Membranes were found putrid, and filled with a yellowih Ichor much reembling Urine.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVII.
Of a Ficus.
div.p:
THIS hath its Name from the reemblance it hath with a Fig, for it carryeth in it as it were the Seeds of a Fig. This ometimes doth arie from the Head, and doth decend into other parts; ometimes it is wholly in the Head. Our preent Dicoure hall be only of that which doth poes the Head, the which being rent will yield a fair propective of the Seeds of a Fig. It is by Paulus called an ulcerous eruption, hard, and red; with pain. Hyppocrates doth number it amongt Tumours. It is therefore a Tumour, becaue it doth oon degenerate into an Ulcer, as Galen hath it. 5. De Med. per Locum c. 4. It is a Tumour generally in the Head, epecially of Children. It is made of mixt humours,Caue. as thick Blood, Flegm, and Serum, becaue it is a red Tumour, round in the Head, and by its Flegm mixing with it cometh this eroity; and hence it is that thee ort of Tumours do o uddenly run into Uucers, if not uddenly and well cured.Cure In its Cure are we to prohibit its Ulceration, for it
oon exulcerates, if not well cured. And here we are to begin with purging and cleaning the Body from thee Humours by Pil. Coch. Aggregativ. Sine Quibus, and the like, and by Diaphoreticks to dry up this moiture; the part affected is to be dicharged of this Serum, and prohibiting uppuration. And therefore to Children troubled with uch a Dieae you may ue uch a Medicine as this, . Aqu. Marin. vel aqu. fontan. in quâ imponatur Sal M. j. in his coquantur herbae Saliv. Roar. rubr. Abynth. an. M. . cola. In this you may dip Sponges, and apply them warm to the affected part, and afterwards lay this Plaiter-wie, Take Figs being boiled in Water to the form of a Pultice and apply them. If you require tronger Medicines, . Alumin. Roch. Calcanth. ut. an. part. aequal. qam. Aer. dupl. Glut. in Aceto diluatur, & cum reliquis imponatur. If it be exulcerated, apply Ceratum Citrinum, Sem. Lin. trit. cum aqua. Let it be deterged with the pulp of Figs, to which may be added a little burnt Alume: and kin it with Deiccativum Rubrum or Diapompholigos.
•• tory. There was a Miniter of forty years of Age, who was much perplexed with a Scirrhous Tumour at the great corner of his Eye,
the largenes of a Chenut, being of a livid colour, intertexed with many capillary Veins. The Body being well purged, and a good Dyet ordered, and being let Blood on his left Arm, the ame ide where this Tumour poeed, the Tumour was extirpated with a pair of cutting Forcipes. After which was applied the white of an Egg mixed with Roe water: then following were applied Anodine, Abterive, and very drying Collyriums, oft time • repeating the Purgations, and Adminitring cupping Glaes to the Neck and Scapulaes; and to the Forehead was applied this firt being Anodine, and afterwards this econd being very drying. The firt was this, . Mucilag. em. Cydonior. & Plantag. cum aqu. Roar. extract. Lact. muliebr. an. ij. Camphor. Croc. an. mice, apply i •
warm. The econd this, . A • u. Plantag. Roar. an. iij. Tuth. praeparat. <> . ut. & praeparat. Ceru. lot. an. <…>
fiat Collyrium. By the benefit of thee, and oberving his precribed Direction he was perfectly cured.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVIII.
Of a Cataract.
div.p:
I NOW proceed to Tumours of the Eyes, and under this Head I hall comprehend Suffuio, Hordeolum, unguis Oculorum and Encanthis. Suffuio or Cataract by the Greeks is called
< in non-Latin alphabet > , and this is an affect of the Eye, whoe caue is as it were a concreted glay Humour gotten between the Cornea and the Chrytalline Humour, clouding it and obcuring its Species of Objects, ometimes covering the whole Pupil, whilt at other times it is een only to cloud but half thereof. And according to its more or les preading, it doth either in proces of time wholly abolih, or partly diminih the ight. And as Platerus doth oberve, it groweth in length of time to the thicknes and hardnes of an excocted Egg. It is oft times made by a concretion of a Flegmatick Humour,Caue. bred either between the Coats of the Eye, or its Pannicles or Spots: It arieth alo from an influx of Humours; or is occaioned by ome outward Action, as a Blow, or Fall; or thick and fumid Vapours ariing from the Stomach, and o
getting into the ubtance of the Brain, are from thence ent and diffued into the Eye, and at length do there contract its concretion. It may arie alo out of weaknes and cold. Celus lib. 7. cap. 7. aith, that there is a pace or ditance between the Cornea and the vea, and in this empty pace, as he does imagine, lodgeth this Cataract or Suffuion, and there takes its Origination. Paulus lib. 6. cap. 21. aith, that a Suffuion is a Concretion of an idle or edentary Humour in the Cornea near the Pupilla; but this carrieth not o full a meaure of truth as the former. Galen 10. de uu partium cap. 1. & 4. offereth that this Humour doth grow between the Cornea and the Crytalline. Yet Fabritius ab aqua pendente doth affirm, that in the three perons which he hath couched, and that in all People which he hath een ue the ame Operation, the Needle hath been applied backward under the vea before the Suffuion would appear: and therefore it is probable, as he mentioneth, that behind the Foramen of the vea this Humour hould conit, becaue if it did grow in its Circumference, it could not be dilated. Where this Cataract is confirmed, and comes to maturity,Signe. we may with eae perceive the
thin Membranes viited with a trange Species of a thin clouded Pupil, variouly coloured according to the diverity of Humours, as ometimes with white, or black, or blewih, yellow, red, or green; and by thee or any of thee the Eye is oft times clouded and deprived of its ight. If it do poses half the Pupil, it takes away but half; but when it creeps and overcats the whole, it doth caue perfect blindnes.Cure. Its Cure is to be begun with a good order of Dyet, and convenient Medicines, and Intruments artificially precribed and applied: Abtaining from Wine and uch hot things, as may diturb the Brain; Shunning flegmatick Dyet, and uch as is of a flatulent and pituitous Juice. If the Patients Bread have ome Fennel-eed put into it, it will be o much the better; for this is generally reputed not only to help the ight, but alo is very advantagious for diipating of cloudy Vapours. Bleeding, Purging, Frictions, are here very ueful; Maticatories chewed in the Mouth are proper; Cupping Glaes and Veicatories applied to the Neck and Shoulders are here alo very requiite for Derivation; Pills and Potions for purging the Head of thee flegmatick Tumours are wonderfully helpful. For Purging
Means or Methods take ome of .Pil. Pil. Sine Quib. i. Pil. de Cynoglos. is. Ol. Faenicul. gutt. iij. cum yr. Betonic. q. Pil: . fiant pillulae. Or thee . Alo. optim. s. Turbith. gummo. Hermodact. Agaric. recent. trochicat. an. ij. Diagrid. i. ZZ. Caryophyllor. an. s. Croc. Sal. gemm. an. gr. vij. pulverientur & cum Syrup. de Staechade q. . fiat Maa pillalar. hujus umat à s. ad ij, Potion. &c. A potion for the ame. . Sen. s. em. Ani. Caryophyllor. an. s. fol. Menth. Betonic. an. M. s. Summitat. Thym. Paraly. Anth. an. pug. s. coquantur ad iiij. colaturâ infunde Agaric. recenter troch. ij. Cinamom. . mice fiat potio. For outward Medicines there are innumerable by mot Authors already mentioned: amongt the bet of them all may be reckoned this, very oft times ued by my elf with good ucces. .A Medicine of the Authors. Succ. Haeder. terretr. Chelidon. Bellid. an. s. Aqu. Roar. albar. i. pulv. Sacchar. condit. albiim. s. Mix thee, and being made lukewarm let the Patient wah his Eye oft times in a Day. it both attenuateth, diolveth, and penetrateth. And thee are the mot powerful intentions in this propoed cope. But if all thee hould fail, and this Cloud do till encreae and grow
thicker, leave off the ue of external Medicines, and let it grow until it be full ripe for manual Operation, and this you may gain by oberving this Method; the ound Eye being hut, if the other be well rubbed with the Finger, the Pupil will preently dilate, and diffue it elf, and will very peedily return into its place, figure, colour, and State, and this by ome is reputed to be ripe enough for manual Operation. Thoe Cataracts are by mot Authors held to be incurable, which do arie out of a harp and tedious Dieae, and having with them great pains of the Head, or that which cometh by a vehement blow or troke; uch as are black, green, livid, yellow, or of a Quickilver colour are hardly curable. On the contrary, uch as have a Chenut colour, or reemble that of the Sea with ome White, are cured without much difficulty. And ince it is not uch an eaie Operation, but may and hath puzled the bet Oculit and mot exact profeor of this Art, conider that this Cure by couching is not always uccesful: But as it oft times happens well, o alo hath it its intervals of bad ucces; for by thee the Grapy Coat is too much diduced, ometimes rent, whence follow its amplification; or ditorted, often after
Place this Figure Fol. <…>
this do follow inflammations and los of ight. Therefore how careful, faithful, and diligent ought the manual Operator be, who undertakes this o curious an Art, the only piece to be admired of all Chirurgery? And here ought we to conider and undertand the Coats, Mucles, and Humours of the Eye, o that not one part of the Eye may be injured by your operation: We ought alo to conider and oberve, how thee parts are connexed together, while we move the Needle upwards and downwards. And having given you this as a Caution or monitory Introduction, I come now to teach you the way of performing this Chirurgick Operation, a lively Protraict of which here you may ee expresed, with all its neceary Chirurgick Intruments belonging and appertaining thereunto. Your Patient having both his Body and Head well cleaned, and all other accidents which may yield any appearance of obtructing your Operation, you are to remove, and then bind up the contrary Eye, and place the Patient to the bet advantage, both for his eae, and your better ight, and executing your Operation; and having your Needles both harp and round pointed ready fixed, and fitted for your ue, and
your other Dreings fit to be applied, then with an intrepidant Hand and undaunted Courage thrut through your Needle, o as that it may enter the Ad
• ata in the middle, charging your Patient to turn the Eye towards his Noe, thruting it near half a trawes breadth from the Iris into the Cornea; and having got it afely in, you are to work it unto the hollow of the Eye; and when the Needle hath touched the Cataract endeavour to pres it gently with the Cataract downwards, and this you are to do o often until you ee the Pupil quite dicharged of its Cloud, and with that trength as to keep it down, that it may not rie up again; and order your Patient not to tir his Eye; for if it ticketh below, and returns not again, you may be confident of a perfect Cure. Then is the Needle to be brought up again, not to be taken out preently. Upon which done, and your Needle taken away, cloe up the Eye with all peed, by applying to the Eye ome linnen Clothes dipt in Roe water, the White of an Egg, and a little Alume mixed together, taking as an Obervation, that you beware of hurting the Crytalline Humour, and the ound Coats in the Operation,Oberv: and with convenient
Bolters and Rollers compleat the ret of your Operation; after this get your Patient to Bed, and order him to ly high with his Head, from all Noie; and let your work be done with obriety and carefulnes, acquitting your elves of all Mountebank getures and impotures. Let his Diet be Barley water, Ptyans, Gellies, poached Eggs, and the like: At the eight day you may remove your Dreings, and then wah the Eye with Roe water, being made lukewarm before you apply it to the Eye; and for ome eaon, order your Patient to wear a piece of green Silk over his Eye, that it may not have the full Air come to it, but by degrees; and let this erve for your couching Method. I hall conclude this Chapter, wihing all ucces to the manual Operator, leaving this alo with him to have in his remembrance, that it is the Eye alone which is Mans greatet Guide in this World, and therefore let Concience and Charity perwade all Men that tender any thing of good, not to meddle with this Cure or way of curing, unles he be well Skilled and exercied in the Art, and undertandeth the Parts and Coats very well, let he comes off with no more Credit than that Mountebank, of whom Montanus Conil. 81. writes
the Story, I will here give you as a jut example of impudence in thee Locuts. A Peron being troubled with an Opthalmy in part of the Cornea of the Eye againt the Pupil,Hitory. the which being but very mall and carce dicernable, an Emperick coming under pretence of giving eae, applies an Apple which had been roated on hot Embers thereunto, and ordered to let it remain on until the next Day; that Night the pain ceaed, and the Patient lept well; Upon which the Mountebank began much to praie his Skill, and himelf with hopes of a peedy Cure; but taking off his rare Medicine, the Waterih Humour followed it, which preceded the Crytalline, o that contrary to his boating expectation, the Patient was made blind in this Eye. A Day will hardly uffice to reckon up thoe michiefs and injuries, which are dayly done by thee Quacks and Mountebanks. A Woman of thirty years of Age (as Riverius in his 100.Hitory. Obervations writeth) having a confirmed Cataract, and being for a whole year blind, recovered her ight, her Body being well purged and cleaned, by the benefit of Quarcitanes Opthalmick water; for the ame I have oft times ued the Juice of Celandine, Daiies, Roe water & Sugarcandy with very good ucces.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIX.
Of Hordeolum •
div.p: THIS is a mall extuberance, by the Greeks called < in non-Latin alphabet > from the reemblance it hath with Barley, and (as Celus aith) this is included in a Husk or Coat, and doth contain in it omewhat which is hard to uppurate. This Tumour by us in England hath generally given it the Name of a Stiony. It generally groweth in the upper part, and in repect of its malnes it may ometimes be dicued, ometimes digeted: Dicued by laying hot Bread or Wax to it; when you have digeted it, open it with an Inciion knife or Lancet, and let out every part of the Humour which is contained.

div.head: CHAP. XL.
Of nguis.
div.p:
ALTHOUGH this by the Greeks is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , yet this is not o eaie by us undertood or decribed: for if we may conceive the whole Fibrous Membrane ariing in the greatet Angle of the Eye, and produced above its White to the Cornea, and ometimes extended as far as to the Pupil, we may view and perceive this lively expreed adherent in this part. Celus doth oft times ay, that it arieth from part of the Notrils, and ometimes from part of the Temples, and where it toucheth the Pupil it adhereth to it. Paulus affirmeth this is without much difficulty to be dicused, as by applying thereunto white Wine and White Wine Vinegar mixed together, or Eye-bright and Sugar, or Fennel-water, Niter or Salt. If it hath had a long time to grow, and cometh to any perfection, as Celus directeth, it is to be cut out,Celus Method. for which he ueth this Method: Let the Patient be placed in a convenient State with his Head omewhat downwards on one one ide,
that you may come the better at the Tumour, and let him be o held and placed, as that he do not diturb your Operation; and then with a harp Hook, being a little bent or made crooked, apprehend the Unguis, and with a mall Needle and Thred draw through it, and o by compreion eat it off.Paulus's Way.
Paulus's way is thus: He ues a trong and long Hores hair, and with this he doth comprehend the Unguis, and o in a hort time doth eat it off. And here ought we to take care how we apply our Silk, or Hair, or any other thing, with which we do or may intend to eat of thoe, let when we come to the Angle, the Caruncle it elf benot cut off alo, and o there happeneth another Michief by the Greeks called < in non-Latin alphabet > , out of which a Humour doth always flow. After it is clean taken away, Paulus would have a little fine Pouder of Salt prinkled on it, mixed with the White of an Egg, and o applied upon Cotton or Lint; We rather approve of Pompholix being poudred both for deterging and drying, and over all to put a little Sheeps Wool. Celus doth put over his Liniment, being made of Honey; but the true and more proper way is, to ue more drying Medicines, uch as have
no corroding quality,Hitory. or do tir up any Inflammation. A Girle of ten years old being much perplexed with a tedious and troubleom weeping at the right Eye, to which convenient Medicines not being applied, the Humour that made its coure thither grew harper, after which followed an Inflammation, and an Eroion of the Pupil; hence the Pupil grew into a great, thick, hard, and white Cloudines, which depraved the Sight, by its long continuance, there being but little hopes left of doing good to this Patient; yet by the requet of her Friends, and perwaions, by thee following Medicines, he following directions recovered her ight: to the Front was applied this Defenative. .Defenative. Farin. Hord. ij. pulv. Roar. rubr. nuc. Cypres. Gallar. Cort. granator. an. iij. pulv. fl. Betonic. Euphrag. an. i. mice in mortario cum aqua Betonic. Euphrag. & Acet. & Abumine ovi, fiat defenativum. Into the Eyes was intilled this Collyrium. .Collyrium. Mucilag. Sem. Cydonior. cum aqu. Roar. extract. j. Aqu. Foenicul. Euphrag. an. ij. Mel. Roar. s. Tuth. praeparat. & Corn. Cerv. ut. & praeparat. an. . Camphor. gr. iiij. With this Collyrium and a good Diet, with
a good Order in purging being oberved, and by the benefit of a Seton he recovered her perfect ight. If the Collyrium be not trong enough, you may add Extract of Celandine to deterge the thick and vicid Matter which ticks to the Pupil.

div.head: CHAP. XLI.
Of a Polypus.
div.p:
WE come next to the Noe, where we may meet with a Polypus, the which by Paulus lib. 6. cap. 25. Is aid to be a Preternatural Tumour ariing in the Notrils; o called from the reemblance it hath with the Fih Polypus, as Galen hath it, and alo from its ubtance, it being made of a Flegmatick and vicous ubtance. Its proper place, wherein it inhabits, is the Notrils, where it both obtructs the Notrils Repiration, and in ome meaure doth hinder the Speech. Celus doth add, that where a Polypus is thus produced as that it reacheth the Fauces,
they which are correpted herewith are oon uffocated.What a Polypus is. This Tumour is like White fleh oft, filling the Notrils, not uniform, but doth appear as many Caruncles knotted or joyned together, or hanging one on another, ome coming to the Cartilages, ome to the Bones either of the Noe, or Spongy Bones. Albucais lib. 2. aith, that it arieth from a flegmatick matter, and hath no Veins for its nourihment. Whence it is mot likely it is made of pituitous Blood, which floweth to the Brain,Caue. and is thence ent through the Notrils. There are many Differencies hereof,Differencies as Paulus Albucais and others do own, for ometimes it is hard, adherent, livid, painful, and cancerous, not to be cured with Intrument. Another ort is oft, looe, white, indolent, bordering only on the Cartilages of the Noe, or to the Bones, or to its Spongeous Roots, being pendulous. It is o pendulous, as it oft times is een to hang out beyond the Noe. Sometimes it is drawn upwards, ometimes it paeth the other way to the Fauces. Hyppocrates doth decribe all its Differencies, de Polypo, and the manner of curing.Celus's way.
Celus doth order us to put up a harp Iron through the Notril, made in form of a Spatula,
and with this to reolve the Polypus from the Bone, taking all care that the Cartilage be not hurt, and being cut with this draw it out.Paulus's way.
Paulus openeth the Notrils and delateth it, and with a Spatula made in form of a Myrtle leaf, doth cut it out orbicularly: But I hall not hang on either of thee. Thee do hew the Notrils to be free from a Polypus, if breathing through the Notrils be free, and without any Obtacle. I rather with a great atisfaction admire and approve of Fabritius de Aqua Pendente, whoe Method and Intrument is both afe and harmles, which Operation is made with afety and with repute; for this Intrument doth apprehend, cut and draw forth the Polypus, the which are the three chief intentions in this Cure. And beides thee advantages it keeps and defends all the other parts of the Noe in afety and harmles. It apprehends and draws it out without effuion of Blood, for it neither cuts nor divides no other Veins or Veels, than uch as are pread or interwoven into thee Caruncles, of which this Polypus is made. I hall, after I have preented you with its commodities, hew you the exact Figure of this Intrument; it cureth uddenly, afely, without pain, and
danger. This Intrument doth perform thee Four Intentions, it apprehends, cuts or eparates it, eparateth its reliques, and doth induce a Cicatrice. It hath an edge to cut, and apprehends like Forcipes, and therefore is to be made like a pair of cutting Forcipes: It apprehends and draws forth like Forcipes: it preently eparateth the Polypus from the Bone; and for the lat we only blow up retrictive Pouder: And thus have I hown you its Four Intentions. It cuts inward to prevent all trouble and danger, and it bringeth this commodity with it, it howeth to every one apparantly what it hath done. In the Cure of a Polypus certainly could there be never a better framed.

Falloppius hath an Intrument made of Silver like a Pipe for this purpoe, into which he puts a Wire, with which he doth apprehend the Polypus, and with this he draweth it to the root thereof, and by a cloe contraction of this Wire he divides and draws forth the Polypus; but if the Polypus be too hard, he draws it forth with this, and cuts it with an Inciion Knife. I have here alo et down its Figure, o that if any deire to ue it, here may they ee its hape and form.

Johannes Paulinus in his his Obervations doth relate of a Countryman,Hitory. who had uch a large Polypus decending to his Palate, or in the Glandule hardned in the Larynx, that he was almot uffocated, & could carce peak or wallow. Baynius in lib. Hitory. 5. cap. 3. aith, that he
cured the Secretary of a Reverend Cardinal of a Polypus, which not only topped the Notril, but alo at ometimes hanged out beyond it, by this Method of applying a Cautick at the end of a leaden Intrument, the which being made hollow at its end for receiving the Cautick, and not bigger than to put up into the Notril, with which the Patient himelf was to hold it with the Cautick next to the Polypus for the pace of one whole hour; and then this being removed, he applied Butter, until the Echar was ablated or removed alo; and thus he as oft renewed the Cautick, and afterwards applied a convenient Medicine for ablating the Echar, as until he had quite extirpated the Polypus. A true Figure of Falloppius Intrument you have here expreed.

div.head: CHAP. XLII.
Of Parotis.
div.p:
WE arrive now at a Tumour of the Glandules of the Ears called Parotes: And before we explain any further hereof, it will be here neceary that we undertand what a Glandule is. It is a Spermatick Parenchyma included in one common Membrane,What a Glandule is. and with many private. And thee may more properly be aid to be Spermatick than Sanguinary, they being furnihed with four kinds of Veels, as Veins, Arteries, Nerves, Lymphaducts. And ince we have hown what a Glandule is, let us further inquire into the nature and ubtance of this Parotis.What the Parotides are. Thee are Glandules eated behind the Ears, and do fill up the whole ubtance thereof in the back part; they are more hard and vicid than the Mamillary Glandules. It is from thee do come the Salival Ductues: and by Falloppius are aid to be ordered for receiving ome uperfluities of the hard branch of the fifth pair, and to end them into the Veins refocillating the inward and outward Ear by its Heat, and to explete
the ame in its Circumference. This Tumour, which preternaturally gets into the Glandules and thee Emunctuory parts, they being looe and pongeous, and o the more capable for the reception of Excrements) hath inflammation generally as its companion, both harp and painful. As it is alo oft times een to arie from a vicid Humour; o alo doth it very frequently ucceed a long and tedious Dieae, the which ometimes doth terminate hereby, throwing ome of its Venome hereinto. It is tedious in cure, it ariing from a thick and vicid Humour.Its Cure. It is to be cured by good order of Diet; and if plethory appear, ue Plebotomy, and then to dicharge uch peccant Humours as do occaion it. Galen advieth us not to ue Topicks here, as we do in other parts; for it is not to be repelled in its beginning, let hereby you give the Enemy a deep impreion into your Patient, and o encreae more Pain and Danger; but rather to attract and draw forth the Humour: But if Fluxion be large, Pain harp, and thence Fever and Watching follow, here may we ue Repellers; and by Galens Authority we are to ue Digetives mixed with Repellers:Catapl. as . farin. em. Lin.
Hord. Fabar. an. ij. coquantur cum decocto Melilot. Chamomel. fine addendo Ol. Roar. Chamomel. q. . fiat Catapl. Or . Butyr. ine Sal. ij. Ol. Chamomel. Aneth. an. i. Dialth. . Cerae parum, Unguent. mice, fiat nguentum. The pain being ablated, come to the ue of trong Reolvers, uch as this; . rad. Alth. Breon. an. i. fol. Rut. Scord. Origan. Veronic. an. M. fl. Melilot. Chamomel. an. pug. 1. Coquantur in Hydromelite, Catapl. trajiciantur fine addendo farin. Hord. Fenugraec. Lupinor. an. i. pulv. Irid. iij. Ol. Rut. Chamomel. an. i. mice, fiat Cataplama. A Woman of thirty years of age being perplexed with a Parotidal Tumour behind her Ears,Hitory. in which beginning was no Fever, neither did he keep in; but about the fourteenth day of her Dieae her Tumour grew to a great bulk, and the matter was plainly prepared, but by reaon of the toughnes of the Cutis, it was kept in longer than it ought to have been: At length being broke, the Woman fell into a few wounding vomitting Watchings, with pain of her Back and Kidneys; yet little or nothing came out of the Abces, neither did he pit up any: Within a few days he dyeth. Hence may a Chirurgeon learn that Abcees
be either in the Emunctuories, or their neighbouring parts, that they do not break them, until they of their own accord break.

div.head: CHAP. XLIII.
Of Epulis and Parulis.
div.p:
THIS is a Hyperarcois, or flehly Excrecence of the Gums, gathered at the roots of the Teeth, and doth Tumefie with Pain, Heat, and Rednes; it poureth fourth a aline and fetid Sanies, and oft times runneth into a Cancer, which ought to be undertood out of the property of its extraneous Heat; and that which is not painful may be revelled, the manner of which may be this way acted and performed, by tying a double Thread about it, and bringing the ame every day traiter, until you have wholly eaten it away: when it is off, you are to burn the place by applying a Cautick thereunto, being ent thither through a Pipe, but o afely that it hurts none of the adjacent
parts. Parulis is a Tumour of the Gums with Inflammation, which is very often reolved, and ometimes uppurated; It is made of hot Blood. This may be cured by precribing in the beginning convenient purging, bleeding, and cooling and repelling Gargarims, as Plantain, Roes, Adderstongue, Nettles, Sage, and the like, being boiled in Water with Alume, to which add ome Syrup of Mulberries and dried Roes; If it tends to Suppuration, further its progres by putting in here Marhmallow roots, Figs, Mallows, and the like. And being made ripe, open it with your Inciion Knife or Lancet, and cleane the Ulcer with Mel. Roarum, Wormwood or the like: If it be cirrhous, and proves very tubborn, draw out a Tooth where it fixeth: and by this means you will both dicharge it from its root, and have no reaon to fear a new growth. Placentinus Chirurg. Hitory. lib. 5. cap. 20. cured a Gentlewoman of a very large welling which was in her Gums in the upper Mandible, the quantity of which Fleh was very much above the Teeth welled to the bignes of a Gooe Egg. He removed this in four times applying an actual Cautery, and removing ome of
the Teeth about it with ome part of the Mandible: He let it bleed in a great quantity, at length he topt the Flux with Vitriol applied on Cotton or Lint, preing out all the clotted Blood with his Fingers, and o perfectly cured her within eight days.

div.head: CHAP. XLIV.
Of Ranula.
div.p:
THIS Tumour by the Greeks is called < in non-Latin alphabet > , by the Latines Ranula, it lodging under the Tongue: It is occaioned by a moit, pituitous, gros, and thick Subtance, falling from the Brain into the Tongue, much reembling in it the Subtance of the White of an Egg, being omewhat of a more yellowih Colour. And here oberve, if the party be plethorick, breath a Vein under the Tongue, and ue proper and peculiar Gargarims for this purpoe, and anoint it with ome retringent Unguents, or rather open it with ome red-hot Iron Intrument
being harp, the manner of which is thus: Get a bended hollow Ironplate which hath a hole in the midt; making the Patient to hold open his mouth, you mut o fit it, that the hole is to be jut upon the part which you intend to open; with the Intrument open the part, o as you may hurt none of the circumjacent parts; when you are ready to burn it, thrut your Thumb under the Patients Chin, that you thereby may omewhat elevate the Tumour, and hereby you may open with more certainty. Being thus opened, throw forth the contained Matter; after which wah the Patients Mouth with Barleywater and Sugar of Roes; and thus may the Ulc • r be afely cured. Gulielmus Placentinus doth order only Aqua Aluminoa to be held under the Tongue, in which hath been boiled a little Myrrh. Gener in Hitor. animal. lib. 2. pag. 51. writes,Hitory. That a Phyitian related to him, that he aw a Tumour under the Tongue the breadth of two Fingers, which hindered the peech, and that this Tumour was cured by drawing a Needle through it, and afterwards opening it with a harp Intrument; the which being done, came out matter from thence much like that of an Artheroma, reembling
coagulated Milk to the quantity of as much as would fill two hands; the which being dicharged, he ordered the Patient to gargarize his Mouth with Aqua mula, and ent into the Ulcer of the ame by a Syringe, and the Body being well purged, and by the ue of Retringents the Patient perfectly recovered.

div.head: CHAP. XLV.
Of Strumae and Scrophulae.
div.p:
THIS Tumour doth arie with much
• ae from too much fibroity, thicknes and vicidity of the nutritive Succus, and for this caue only is it that this Juice is o difficultly depered into all the parts of the Body, and therefore mut confidently redound in ome place, and with eae lay its firt grounds and Foundations of a Tumour. There is held a great difference between Strumae and Scrophulae; and by Dr. Wharton in his Book De glandulis, the one of thee is called by him Wenns, the other the Kings evil: Scrophula
ignifying the firt, and Struma the latter: Scrophulae are oft, Wenns hard: the firt pale, carrying in them the colour of the Skin, the econd having a rednes turning to lividnes; Scrophulae oft and not much penetrating, Strumae immovable and deeply fixed: the Kings-evil wellings generally encreae into a great bulk and magnitude; and beides their glandulous Flehes they do carry in them everal orts of Juices in their little Bags, the which do help much forward their growth and bulk. It is credible that thee concreted Juices are as ome rejected Excrements thrown from the glandulous Fleh in its nutrition; for thee Glandules have no excretory Veels, and therefore necearily they hould carry their Excrements in their Bags: And this is one reaon of their growth. Secondly, the Blood effued from hence through the Arteries is more plentiful, than that which is reduced through the Veins; and hence therefore may there arie another reaon of its growth. Thirdly, The Nerve which keepeth here is but mall, and that makes them o dull; and hence is it that, were the parts pricked with Needles, the Patient would not much complain of pain. Now as touching Strumaes, thee
are not always een to run into a bulk or magnitude,Decript • on of Strumaes. but ometimes they encreae, ometimes they leen, and at length do vanih. Thee Tumours do receive their proportion from the reductory Veel, and are dicriminated from its firt genus, here is nothing found beides Nerves V • ins and and Arteries. And by how much the Veins are better capacitated and enabled to convey and carry off that which is ent them from the Arteries, by o much alo are thee Strumatous Tumours les capable of running into bulk, than uch as are Scrophulated. And how thee Tumours are tranlated from one place into another, I attribute chiefly to the Nerves in their Operations, thee being mot proper Meengers to carry to and fro. Now if there be any matter carried to the Emunctuory Veels or Glandules, and be there excerned, the Struma doth oon leen, and ometimes doth wholly vanih, and is very often een by applying of Hydrargyrical Mêdicines or Salivation to conume and wate away, thee having in them a very powerful influence of making the Nerves pit forth their Humidities into the Emunctuory Glandules. And hence by Paulus and Celus thee are aid chiefly to arie in three
places more epecially, as in the Inguens, Axillaries, or about the Neck or Throat, but mot chiefly about the Neck and Throat, becaue here they be nearer the Head, their Fountain, from whence they draw their flegmatick Matter to their conglomorated Glandules.Signs. Some of thee Strumaes do ucceed other Ditempers, whilt others do breed of themelves: Sometimes an outward Caue may occaion them, as by applying too hot reolving or too drying Medicines.Preage. As to their Preage, we ought here to conider their different places where they make their abode; for thee are alo either mall or great, looe or fixt, few or many, painful or without pain, ariing from Flegm or Melancholly: Some being in the inward part of the Neck, whilt others do border on the outward: Some terrifying young Children, whilt others do lay their imprees on people more aged: And by how much they are more movable, by o much are they with les difficulty cured; yet take them at the bet, the Chirurgeon will find work enough to get well off, & clear them with repute. Such as adhere to the Bones are incurable; there are three ways of eradicating them:Three ways to eradicate them. Either when the Radical Moiture, which is carried and reerved
in their everal Cytuses or Bags, is ucked up by the Nerves, or the affluxed Blood reduced by the Veins, or a free tranpiration brought to the part affected. The firt and main caue of this tranlation is the Nerve, which doth bring and breed the firt rudiment of a Struma out of its matter, and to help forwards this work, both Veins and Arteries are as its Aitants. The curing alo of thee Dieaes are very difficult, in that mot generally uch as are troubled with thee wellings outwardly, they alo have them inwardly.Cure: As to the Cure, the thick Lympha is to be incied, tempered, and evacuated; the Glandules oftned; the Humour, if poibly, either to be dicued or uppurated, and at length, if no otherwie to be overcome, is to be treated with Echarioticks. And firt let the Body be well purged with Phlegmagogicks.Pil. As . Alo. lot. cum aqu. Majoran. Agaric. troch. an. i. Matich. Cubebar. an. gr. vi. Troch. Alhandul. s. cum Syrup. de Betonic. q. Pil. . fiant pillulae. Or thee, . Pil. Coch. ij. Aurear. i. Troch. Alhandul. gr. iij. cum Oximelit. q. . fiant. Pil. Or . Turpeth. optim. Zinz. Hermodactyl. Diagrid. Sacchar. an. partes aequal. mice, fiat pulvis, of which the
Patient may take from a Dram to a Dram and a half with Oximel once in a Week,Pouder. in the Morning. Or this, . Turpeth. Zinzib. Sacchar. alb. an. i. detur cum vino. If the Patient be of a pretty good Age and trong, he may take this. . Pulv. Turpeth. s. Hermodact. i. Zinzib. condit. . mix them for ue. Pil. Cochiae, Sine Quibus, Trochic. Alhandul. and the like, are here very good and proper. Sweating alo here is very advantagious, and taking inwardly of acid things is good: Or you may precribe this Pouder.Pouder. . Ciner. Spong. marin. O. Saep. Piper. long. Cinamom. Sal. gem. Pyreth. nuc. Mochat. Cupres. Gallar. cort. Querc. fl. Roar. rubrar. an. s. mice, fiat pulvis, dois a ij. ad i. Or this, . Lap. Spong. iij. Sal. gem. ij. Tartar. vitriolat. j. mice, fiat pulvis, dois is. vel ij. And to the part affected uch things as are proper for a Scirrhus, are here alo as prevalent; but uch things here are more peculiarly to be added, which may more powerfully reolve, as thee which have been applied with mot excellent ucces.Aqva. . Ol. Philoophor.

Chamomel. Melilot. Roar. rubr. an. iij. Ol. Irin. nguent. Dialth. an. i. ucc. Rut. s. Catapl. mice fiat Cataplama. Or . farin. em. Lin. Fenugraec. iij. farin. Orob. i. fl. Melilot. Chamomel. Sambuc. an. iij. fl. Antho. iiij. pulv. Irid. s. coquantur in vino mulo, tunc adde ub finem ol. Lilior. q. . fiat Cataplama. Or this,Catapl. . rad. Alth. iiij. rad. Lilior. ij. flor. Melilot. Chamomel. an. pug. s. coquantur, pitentur & percolentur, potea adde pinguedin. Gallin. Dialth. an. i. medul. 'Pomor. ub. cineribus coct. iij. Ol. Chamomel. Lilior. an. Catapl. q. . fiat Cataplama. And for
this alo the reolving Emplater in Scirrhous Tumours is here very excellent, it being by me very oft times applied with good ucces.
