Barbett writes of a Maiden of fourteen years of age,A Hitory. who was very much afflicted with many and grievous Dieaes, as welled Lips, and everal ulcered Glandules in her Neck and Parotidals, and much tumefied with Scirrhous wellings, o that he could carce move her Neck, and by this following Method he recovered her: Firt ordering her a Decoction of Guaiacum, prepared with attenuating and opening Ingredients, of which he took three Ounces for Four days, into which was dropped of Spirit of Sal. Armoniac. eight drops, and once in a Week he took this Pouder. . pulv. Jalap. s. Tartar. vitriolat. gr. 5. Ol. Faenicul. gutt. ij. This wrought with her three or four times: outwardly was applied Empl. de Ranis cum Merc. Ol. Rutae & Fuligin. malaxat. And to the ulcered Glandules
nguent Bailicon: then Balamum Sulphuris: and he within three or four Months was retored to her perfect health. Or this Emplater may be well ued. . Empl. de Ran. cum Merc. s. Gum. Galban. ij. Sacchar. Saturn. Sal. volatil. Armoniac. an. s. malaxentur
Oleo Rutae q. . fiat Empl. Sometimes thee Strumaes will not yield to Reolution, but do much rather incline to Suppuration; that is, when any other Humour is mixed, which gives it a greater Heat, as Blood and Choler: and when it takes its coure this way, we are to help forward with uch Suppurating Medicines, as may peed it in its operation; uch as be Marh-mallows boiled in water, Diachylon cum Gummi, De Mucilaginibus, and the like: or intead of thoe take ome of thee following compounded Suppurating Medicines.Catapl. . Bdell. Ammoniac. an. . diolvantur in Lixivio, adde Calc. viv. cum Axung. contrit. i. Sulphur. viv. . Alumin. . Mel. optimi i. Ferment. veter. ij. mice, fiat Cataplama. Catapl. Or this; . Caepar. & rad. Lilior. albor. ub cinerib. coct. an. iiij. farin. Tritic. ij. Axung. Gallin. Aner. an. q. . vitell. Ovor. n.. 1. Croc. . mice, fiat Cataplama. Catapl. Or this; . farin. Fabar. Tritic. an. i. farin. em. Lin. Foenugraec. an. ij. Ficuum contu. i. Axung. veter. ij. Croc. i. mice, fiat Cataplama. Being uppurated it is to be opened by a Cautick or Inciion: and for a Cautick there's none better than ublimated Arnick; and upon applying it defend its neighbouring parts with a Defenative,
dicharge the Matter, & remove the Echar, fill up with Fleh, and then skin it. I hall conclude this Chapter with one Patient of my own (though on this ubject I could offer many, having had the honour of obtaining the Touch from His Majeties hand) for many, mot of which I have had afterwards to conclude their cure: amongt the ret in this City of Norwich was one Mr. Rootees on, much perplexed with Scrophulous Tumours, which tended after His Majeties Touch to Suppuration, who after having his body well purged, and the Humour well prepared, his Neck from his Ears was environed with thee mall filled bags of Flegmatick Matter: over thee I applied Emplatrum Diachylon cum Gummi ij: De muci • aginibus i. Emplatrum de Ran. cum Merc. . nguent. Dialth. vj. mice. With this or the like Emplatrum was his whole tumefied part covered, and having brought it to Suppuration, I drew forth all its matter which was contained; then I mundified, digeted, and incarned all the parts, and the Patient (I bles God) remains in perfect health to this day.

div.head: CHAP. XLVI.
Of Bronchocele.
div.p:
THere is a Tumour (as Celus calleth it) between the Cutis and the Wind-pipe, which the Greeks call
< in non-Latin alphabet > . This is not a Tumour in the Glandule, but ariing upon the Apera Arteria. It's thus called < in non-Latin alphabet > , which ignifies Apera Arteria, and < in non-Latin alphabet >
Tumour; and therefore by Celus is aid to be a Tumour ariing between the Cutis and Wind-pipe, and by him is numbred amongt Abcees, whoe Matter is lodged in a Bag or a Coat, which is dull Fleh omewhat like Honey or Water. Celus doth here alo propoe two orts of Medicines, as Cautick and Intrument, by burning Medicines, o as that the Cutis and Bladder may be burnt, and thus the Matter dicharged: but this is a great deal of trouble to a little purpoe; and therefore he more readily comes to Inciion. And here he orders a direct Inciion to be made into the Coat, o as the vicious matter may be eparated by the Finger; after which let it be well mundified with Vinegar, to which adde ome Salt or Nitre: and in every Abces we
are to take notice, that there is a mall Vein or Artery that doth feed it, and its Membrane whereto it doth adhere to the ound part; in the other part it is free. If any Patient hould come to your hand with uch an Abces, be always careful of thee four Intentions, as in the ordering your Patients Diet, in preparing and purging the antecedent Matter, in removing the Matter contained in the Tumour, and in applying convenient Topicks. Let his Diet be thin, his Air hot or temperate: for purging thee may erve.Pil. . Pil. de Agaric. Pulv. Hier. Colocynth. an. ij. cum yrup. de Stechad. q. . • i • nt pil. do. a i. ad i. In this cae Sweating is alo good. And as to Chirurgery, you may ue this Ungu • nt and Emplater:Unguent. . Sulphur. Sandarach. an. . Euphorb. i. cum Cerae & olei q. . fiat nguentum. After anointing herewith apply this Emplater: .Empl. Rad. Ireos, Sal. Gem. an. i. Terebinth. q. . Diachyl. cum Gummi Apotolor. an. i. mice, fiat Emplatrum. If thee will not do, Rogerius does advie us to make a double Seton, o as that the Humour may low out by degrees. In old people very commonly the Larynx is o attenuated, and the Mucles as it were o dried up, and as it were dicharged of their
Flehy Subtances, that it happens frequently in chewing, that ome part of the Apera Arteria is een to fall: and this was verified by Oualdus Gabelchoverus de obervationibus uis, Hito • y. who writes of an old Gentleman that could not take down any liquor, as Beer, Wine, or any liquid ubtance, but a great part of his Apera Arteria would lip; yet he could take and eat his meat very well without any hindrance. The ame I knew of one Mr. Goodman a Miniter here in Norfolk, a man of about 40 years of age, who could eat his meat very heartily without any lett or diturbance; but when he hath had occaion to drink, was forced to bend himelf forward, and by degrees let his liquor pas down very moderately, let a part of his Wind-pipe hould lip out, and o prove very troubleom to him. I have been oft in his company, when I have both een him ue this Method, and alo taken all care to prevent the falling down or relape of his Apera Arteria.

div.head: CHAP. XLVII.
Of Angina.
div.p:
IT is called Angina from < in non-Latin alphabet > , which is all one to S • rangulo, the which doth ignifie every Affect both of the Jaws and Throat, whereby Breathing is hindred; or if you pleae, it is that Affect of of the Throat, the Larynx being overtraitned by ome inward occaion, o cauing Suffocation. It is a very acute Dieae, and is an Inflammation of the Fauces. Of this there are two orts, one Legitimate, the other Illegitimate. To the one a Feaver is a continual companion; but it hath nothing to do with the other.Three pecies of a true Squiney. There are three pecies of a true Squinancy: one with Inflammation, and not in the Fauces, neither apparent in the Neck, but in the Throat; and this bringeth peedy danger of Suffocation. A econd accompanied with a manifet Phlegmon, with no Tumour or Rednes in the the Neck. A third, when the Neck eemeth to be inflamed with the Fauces, having along with it Tumour, R •• nes, Heat,Ca • es. and Pain. The inward Caue is Blood abounding, and oft times peccant; the which doth not alone raie this, unles
more vitiated by a harp and four Lympha. The outward Caues are evident, Cold, Fih-bones being received the wrong way, cold Drinks, and too much Repletion. A Batard Squinancy is made by a pituitous Ditillation falling upon the Fauces and Mucles of the Neck, exciting a Tumour, without Rednes, Heat, and Feaver.Signs. Of thee are •• de three Differencies by ome Author •
and thee they chriten with three <> names, as Cynanche, Paraynanche, <> che: but thee are but of mall moment towards our encreae of Knowledge. The Diagnotick Signs are, when the Patient cannot move his Neck, and breatheth with difficulty, neither can he well wallow, and finds a pain and heat in his Jaws. That is accounted mot dangerous,Preag • . which with the mot peed doth threaten Suffocation, and yet is neither perceived in the Cheeks, neither doth it any ways appear in the Neck, yet there is felt a vehement pain, and the Spirits carce eem to be drawn; for oft times this Suffocation doth happen the firt day. There is no Squinancy with afety, and the leer the Tumour, the greater the danger: and Hippocrates lib. 4. Aphor. 34, 35. aith, if the Humour of the Angina be carried to the Lungs, it maketh its exition before
the eventh day; otherwie the Patient grows in danger of Suffocation. And if it hath made its efflux without leaving any evil ymptom in this time, the Flux being converted into Matter, this is to be uppurated and not kept here; for where it is not cleaned from hence the Patient doth very readily run or fall into a Conumption. This Lympha and Bilis is to be tempered in the Bloud,Cure: and to be very peedily revelled and derived; and therefore are we firt to breathe a Vein in the right Arm; and this is as oft to be repeated as neceity may offer. And if this will not do, breathe a Vein under the Tongue; but this is to be performed at the beginning: then cool the body with Clyters or Purges, and let your Patient have convenient Gargarims prepared for him:
• argarim: as, . fol. Roar. rub. Balaut. an. pug. 1. cort. Granator. . fol. Querc. m. 1. Alumin. ut. i. coque ex aqua ferreata
< in non-Latin alphabet > . adde yrup. Diamor. iiij. mice. In the end you may order this dicuive Gargarim:Gargarim. . rad. Liquirit. cort. Granator. an. ij. fl. Balaut. fol. Roar. rub. an. pug. 1. Jujub. no. 12 Ficuum no. iij. Paular. Corinth. iij. coque in aqua Hord.
< in non-Latin alphabet > . in his olve yrup. cap. Vener. Mel. Roat. an. i. mice. This following alo in the beginning is very proper.
. fol. Ro. rub. Sambucin. an. M. j. coquantur in Cerviia tenniore q. . fine addendo Alb. graec. j. colaturae
< in non-Latin alphabet > . adde Sacchar. Saturn. . Sal. Prunell. i. Or this Cataplam: Catapl. . rad. Alth. Lilior. albor. an. j. Nid. Hirundin. no. j. Ficuum Dactylor. an. no. iiij. Caepar. vj. coquantur ex aqua Hord. & colaturae adde farin. Tritic. em. Lin. an. i. Faenugraec. Alth. an. i. vitellor. Ovor. n.. ij. Croc. ij. ol. Chamomel. ij. mice, fiat Cataplama. Galen doth report of one troubled with a Squinancy,Hitory. after having ued many proper Remedies, and thee failing, this at lat recovered the Patient; he ordered the Excrement of a Boy well dried and powdered, and mixed Honey therewith, and with this he anointed the Jaws of the Patient, and in the pace of half an hour the Abces did break, and the man was retored to his perfect health. Aetius cap. 5. lib. 6. aith, that Agarick doth uck up hidden Abcees, and doth draw them outwards. And Jacobus Dovonetus apolog. lib. 3. cap. 2. writeth, that having a young Gentlewoman much troubled with a Squinancy, he cut a little Agarick in pieces, and put them into a Decoction made of Marhmallows, Figs, with a little Ginger, and a fourth part of Wine and Water, to which he added a
little yrup of Marhmallows: this Potion he gave to the Patient, and ordered her that he might not wallow it, but hold it for ome time in her mouth; he following his directions, whilet he was but dicouring with another, a great quantity of white Matter came out at her mouth, and after this ome putrid; this being dicharged he came to her perfect breathing, and got off from her Fever and all other bad Symptoms, and perfectly recovered.

div.head: CHAP. XLVIII.
Of a Tumour of the Tonils.
div.p:
THee Tonils are by the Greeks called
< in non-Latin alphabet > , amongt the which is reckoned the Columella. And Nature hath placed two Glandules at the root of the Tongue, much reembling in figure and hape an Almond, and therefore by ome thee are called Amygdals. And before we proceed any further in this Dicoure,What the Amygdals are, <> how made. let us take a more curious view of them, and ee for what ues they were framed; and then if being either hurt, tumefied, inflamed or ulcerated, how they ought to be cured. They are as it were framed out of a cold, concreted, oleaginous, and malleous Subtance, ave onely that it is thicker and more firm, they being of a yellow colour, oft in touch, but in being boiled hard, pongeous, and porous. They have belonging to them Veins, Nerves, Arteries, and proper Cavities: Veins and Arteries from the Jugulars; Nerves from the third and fourth pair. Each hath its proper Ductus allowed it, opening into the Mouth, and very many mall Glandules dipered from thence about the whole Root of the
Tongue. Through all thoe Foramulaes is our mucous Subtances expreed, and thence dipoed through the Root of the Tongue.Ues? Their Ues are various, as being firt the chief Organs of Tating;They being the chief Organs of Tating. for the ame Membrane which covereth all the parts of the Mouth, doth alo take this Glandule into it. Secondly, it is the Excretory Iutrument, for its office is to eparate the Mucous or Pituitous Matter which falleth from the lower part of the Brain, epecially through the Nerves of the third Pair, and o to refund this into the Fauces and Mouth. Thirdly, this moiteneth and keepeth oft the Jaws, Larynx, Tongue, Oeophagos, and maketh the Tongue o voluble, and the Oeophagos the better capable to perform its office of Deglutition. Fourthly, in plentiful Catarrhs of the Brain, the Notrils being obtructed, they do imbibe into their pongeous ubtances the Matter, which might otherwie have been dipoed the other way. And latly, they help towards the Concoction of the Ventricle by their Fermentative Faculty; for thee with much eae do contract Acidities, which is the great Agent in Fermentation, and its chief caue. All thee are worthily allowed by the curious hand of Dr. Wharton, in his Book De Glandulis.
Now if this Saliva be pent or conumed by violent Fevers, the Patient does oon begin to grow impotent and weak, unles the Tongue and Mouth be kept moitned by ome cooling Decoction or other; for thee Glandules are planted in a hot and moit place, and therefore the ooner ubject to Inflammation. Into thee alo with Blood do flow a pituitous Matter, crude and vicid; and this being condened by Cold, does elevate them into a Tumour. Aetius telleth us, it may happen in a young body by drinking too much harp Wine, and by eating very often of too harp Meats. With thee Glandules do frequently their neighbouring Glandules of the Larynx joyn in Tumour, and then the Patient is ready to uffocate. It is very apparent both to ight and to feeling.Cure. This eminent danger may be both prevented and reited by Purging and Phlebotomy, Cupping glaes, Veicatories, applied to the Neck and Shoulders, then wah the Mouth and Throat with this Gargarim:Gargarim. . Roar. rubr. Plantag. Balaut. an. i. ummitat. Papaver. Myrtin. an. i. Bol. armen. i. fiat Gargarima. Another. Or this: . fol. Plantag. aceto. Hyop. an. M. i. gran. Sumach. . Cort. Granator. Roar. rubr. an. pug. i. fiat decoctum ad lbi. in quo olve yrup.
Moror. i. Lap. Prunell. i. mice. Or,Another. . fol. Salv. Plantag. Roar. rubr. an. M. . Cort. Granator. Balaut. an. pug. 1. Santal. rubr. Bol. armen. an. i. Betonic. M. i. coquantur in aqua fontana ad lbi. colaturae adde yr. Myrtin. Sambuc. an. i. Sal. Prunel. i. mice. Thee Trochichs are alo very proper to moiten the mouth and parts with,Trochic. and alo to allay Heat and Inflammation. . Spec. Diatragaganth. frigid. Diapapaver. an. i. Bol. armen. praepar. ij. Amyl. ucc. Liquirit. an. . Sacchar. candit. ij. cum yrup. Papaver. erratic. q. . fiant Trochici, to be diolved in the mouth. Or this: . Aqu. Prunel. Plantag. Roar. rubr. an. iiij. fol. Roar. Cort. Grantor. Balaut. fol. Plantag. Ophi • glo. an. M. em. Cydonior. i. coquantur omnia imul, & colaturae adde yrup. Diainor. i. Granator. q. . ad aciditatem. To the outward Region of the Neck apply this Cataplam:Cataplam. . rad. Alth i. Scabio. Sambuc. Roar. rubr. fl. Chamomel. Melilot. an. M. . em. Alth. i. coquantur ad mellis conitent. pitentur & his adde farin. em. Lin. Foenugraec. an. s. ol. Roar. Aneth. Chamomel. an. i. mice, fiat Caplama. Pills proper for purging the Patient may be thee:Pil. . Pil. aur. i. Extract. Panchymagog,
Croll. . ol. Cinamom. gutt. ij. Diagrid. gr. i. cum yrup. Roar. q. . fiant Pil. A very convenient Electuary may be this: .Electuary. Stercor. canin. alb. aq. Roat. lot. & pulv. i. Sacchar. Roat. . yrup. Violar. Moror. an. i. ol. Amygdal. dulc. recenter extract. . pulv. Irid. i. pec. Diatragagant. . ol. Foenicul. Ch. gut. ij. mice, Hitory. fiat Electuarium. Dodonaeus Oberv. cap. 16. telleth of a young Child two years of age, who was troubled with an Inflammation of her Glandules; and whereas he could have nothing applied to her by reaon of her youth, Nature found out a way to dicharge this Matter. There are bred in the Neck under the Ear imple Tumours, the which being opened with an Inciion Knife, this Matter flowed out, and thus was he freed and dicharged from this Abces of her Tonils. Forestus hath alo another Hitory of a Woman, (lib. 15. Oberv. 27.) who having wallowed the Back-bone of a Fih, and ticking in her Throat, o that it had near uffocated her, the which could neither be removed, neither could he eat or drink without great difficulty; upon precribing and taking of this following Eclegma he recovered. It was made of Figs, Marhmallow-roots, Mallow-eeds, Currants, Sebetens, and Jujubes,
mixed with Syrup of Violets, the which he ordered her to have continually in her Mouth; and by applying uch a Cataplam as you have already precribed outwardly, he peedily got dicharged of this Bone, and recovered.

div.head: CHAP. XLIX.
Of Empyema.
div.p:
THis is mot properly called Empyema, when there is a collection of purulent Matter got into the cavity of the Thorax: and if this within 40 days be not expurged by Spitting, Urine, or the like, it does either produce Suffocation or Phthiis. The Matter which filleth the cavity of the Thorax, and does o frame it fit for Suffocation, is threefold, it being either Flegm, Water, or purulent Matter. If this Matter be collected either in the Thorax, or in any other part, and be tranmitted from the Head, and o flegmatick; from the Liver, and o erous; and rom the Thorax, and o purulent; as alo from the Squinzy uppurated from the Fauces: but if it proceed from the Thorax, it does always come from an Abces, and maketh Repletion.
This may alo arie from the Pleuriie, if the Apera Arteria hath not perfectly dicharged its Matter.Signs. Its Signs are an obtue pain, with Commotion of Humour contained in the Thorax with Fluctuation. And as a mot certain Sign it hath ome Humour appearing outwardly, lodging between the Ribs and the Exteriour parts. Or if you will, this Humour is dicerned by its Tumour, accompanied with Pain, Heat, Weight, Noie, and Fluctuancy: for it welleth, and appears with a certain bluihnes in the place outwardly where this Matter is collected; this is an infallible Sign, as clear as the Day, the which I have een very often never to fail. The Native Heat being corrupted is the occaion of this change of Colour. It does rend and fret its Mucles by its Matter, and it breaks into them; the which Matter being dicharged, the patient findeth ome eae, but there remaineth a mall and inous Ulcer, which is very hard to cure. Such perons as are herewith perplexed, when they lie on their contrary ide, the other part does eem to be very heavy and depreed, and are very apt to cough, and be oon weary of this poture. There is a manifet Noie and Fluctuation apparent in the Side affected when
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
the Patient does turn himelf, unles the Matter be thick, or o plentiful that it filleth up the whole capacity of the Thorax, and does thereby hinder it. And here are we to oberve, that this Dieae at the bet is not eaily to be cured, neither can the whole Matter be dicharged by Salivation; therefore does require more than an ordinary help. Out of Hyppocrates Counel the Patient is to be nourihed with Milk and Euchymick Meats, and the Matter mut be digeted, and to deferr for fifteen days from Ruption; the which fifteen days being expired, it is to be peedily opened either by Inciion or Cautick, let it do injury to the Vicera, and do weaken the Faculties. When you make your Section, let it be between the fourth and fifth Rib, tending from the lower parts upwards; and by this Method may you prevent all fears of injuring Nerve, Vein, or Artery. Make neither Inciions, nor apply any Cauticks right downward, but according to the Fibres of the Intercotal Mucles. This being performed, you are paringly or by degrees to let forth the Matter, both for keeping in the Spirits, and preerving vigour and trength in your Patient. The Matter being thus educed, the Wound is to be healed with all convenient
peed, for keeping afe of the inward parts. For which purpoe uch a Decoction as this is very excellent. . Herb. Decoction. Sanicul. Veronic. Pyrol. an. M. j. Conolid. major. Sarracenic. Botry. an. pug. ij. fl. Borag. Buglo. an. pug. j. em. Ani. Foenicul. dulc. an. ij. Cinamom. iij. Jujub. no. 6. Sebeten. no. 4. Dactylor. no. 4. coqu. omnia in aqua Hord: Hujas umat iiij. cum pulv. ocul. Cancr. ij. mice. Another for the ame. . rad. Chin. iiij. Symphyt. Tormentil. Irid. an. j. Capil. Vener. Tuilagin. Scabio. Marrub. Hyop. an. M. j. flor. 3. cord. an. pug. j. fl. Paraly. Betonic. an. pug. ij. fl. Auth. pug. is. Caricar. pinguid. iij. Liquirit. ij. cm. Ani. Coryander. an. vj. infundantur omnia per noctem in aquae fontanae lbjj. & coleniur: colaturae adde Mellis lbj. mice, hujus umat omni mane. Trochichs made of Saccharum Roatum and Diacodium Tabulatum do very well here. When your Echar is out, and you have procured a mall Oriice, you may inject into the part uch a Decoction warm as is this: . fol. Salv. Hyperic. Scabio. Veronic. Virg. aur. Centaur. Abynth. an. M. . Roar. rub. pug. j. Alumin. Roch. ij. coquautur omnia in . q. aquae fontanae, colaturae adde Mel. ij. mice. You may meet with an Obervation
of a pleuriie turned into an Empyema in River. Hitory. obevat. 79. centur. 1. of a young man about 20 years of age, who fell into a pleuriie, o painful that he could not lie on either ide of his Bed, but onely walk upwards. Many Remedies were precribed in the Conultation of three phyicians, and the patient was let blood above ten times; yet the Affect perevered. Although the pain of the Side ometimes eemed to ceae, yet both his pain returned and a Fever with it. This Fever continued to the five and thirtieth day, then the Side began to well, and proved painful to the Touch, uffued with rednes; it was judged a pleuriie turned into an Empyema; and for this reaon uppurating Cataplams were ordered, by which the Tumour might encreae its bulk, and the peccant Matter endeavour to dicharge it elf. But the opening of this Side being procratinated too much, the Abces broke inwards, and the Patient did pit out ome of this Matter with eae by coughing, which appeared very laudable, and not at all fetid; and this he did for many days in a great quantity. After the Abces brake outwardly, it was with eae converted into either Side, becaue he found and felt a great pain in the pained Side:
which thing is noted by Hippocrates in Prognostic. Having pat the eighth day of its running, this purulent Excretion ceaed, and he onely vomited up Flegm: then he perceived the pain again in the ame Side, o as it turned not to the ound: then was conjectured that there was a new Collection of Matter in the Side, and he being prepared for the dicharge of the ame, the Empyema was opened by a Cautick being laid on the Side, and Matter for a long while came from the Side, and at length the Patient perfectly recovered.

div.head: CHAP. L.
Of a Tumour of the Diaphragma.
div.p:
THE Diaphragma hath two orts of Tumours belonging to it, and either of them do bring the Patient in danger of death; the one long, the other hort: for by the Excrements forcing here they may make a Tumour both with or without a Fever. If without a Fever, from the beginning pain and difficulty of breathing, a mall and a hard Pule, and thee Excrements we are to allow to be thin and crude, and thence do follow a Tenion of the Bowels, becaue the Mucles are extended to the Diaphragma. And if a Fever be joyned to thee Tumours, Experience does atisfie, it is not harp; and it arieth from the too long contention of Excrements in the part affected. An Inflammation of the Diaphragma beginning, there necearily does follow a Fever; and in repect of the Affect, becaue the Tumour is made of hot matters, and in relation to the part affected by reaon of its near bordering upon the Heart, there do generally follow from this Inflammation, Pain, and Difficulty of Breathing: and therefore,
as Galen aith, Breathing here in this cae is mall and frequent, (lib. 5. de loc. affect.) ometimes Convulions do ucceed thee Inflammations. When uch a Tumour of the Diaphragma is offered to you for cure, let your firt Intention be to dicharge the Matter or Subtance that is lodged. And becaue the Origination of this does generally arie from Fluxion, this alo is to be prohibited, and this is done by dicharging the fluent Matter. If you take them in the beginning, they may give ome hopes of Cure: but if they be of any long continuance, they admit of no Cure; becaue they generally hurry the Patient into a Conumption, and will not be taken hold of by the bet of Medicines.Cure. As to the Cure, the firt Intention is to dicharge this Matter by well purging and clearing the Body of its Excrements: and here uch things are mot proper as can dicharge both Flegm and Water; uch as is Elaterium, Radix Sambucinus, or the like. Phlebotomy is no ways proper here; for the peccant Matter is cold, and therefore Dicuives are here mot convenient. And thee may be aid to be of two orts; ome to be adminitred inwardly, whilet others are outwardly to be applied: and thee ought to be both emollient and relaxing, as
Butter, Fats, Marrows, and the like; and thee are to be ordered according to the Humour and the Strength of the patient; firt beginning with milde Medicines, and then proceeding with uch as are tronger, as Oyl of Chamomile, Dill, and the like. Here alo you may ue Emplaters and Unguents, as of Mallows, Marhmallows, Lilies, with Lineed, Fenugreek eed, &c. preerving and deending the inward parts with uch things as can dicus, as Treacle, Methridate,Hitory. Saraperilla, &c. I once aw in a Gentleman a Tumour bred in the Diaphragma out of crude and thin blood, in which pain and difficulty of Breathing, a hard and mall pule were preent, the Matter and Humour was cold, and tough, and crude, and this hewed it Mortal, for it brought him into a Conumption, and the Abces breaking he did pit up Blood and much indigeted Matter. Thee Tumours, although they are bred of a thin and cold Matter, yet in the place affected they thicken; and for the performance of this there is required pain, difficulty of Breathing, a hard and a mall pule, little or nothing changing it elf, no apparent Tumour hewing it elf: and if to thee Tumours a Fever do joyn it elf, as Experience does oft times hew it doth,
it is not harp, yet they bring Death with them; and when they perevere, and are not reolved, they bring the patient into a Conumption, and o lay him even with the dut, as it did the aforeaid Gentleman.

div.head: CHAP. LI.
Of Exuberancy of Milk.
div.p:
MAny Women in their firt days, after being delivered of their Burthen, have a great redundancy of Milk, becaue much Blood is ent thither, and not taken away or ucked out: for the helping of which it is thought by ome, that Repellers are very proper to be applied before uch Women be delivered, and o to hinder the addres of Blood thither; for after this much Milk being received, it cannot afterwards be o well repelled, but ought to be dicharged by the Breats, or drawn out by Sucking, or otherwie. It may be prohibited, if the Blood do not flow violently, by thee Medicines following;Liniment. as, . Bol. armen. j. Sangu. Dracon. Oliban. an. ij. Ol. Roar. ij. Cer. acet. an. parum mice, fiat Linimentum. Or my Emplater oft times ued in this cae with good
ucces.Empl. . Emplatr. Diapalm. ij. Ol. Roar. . pulv. Sangu. Dracon. j. mice. Or this;Another. . Ol. Myrtin. ij. Amygdal. dulc. . Terebynth. Venet. ij. pulv. Matich. Bol. armen. Corall. Sangu. Dracon. an. j. pulv. Myrtil. Balaut. Roar. rubr. an. ij. pulv. Salv. Betonic. an. j. mice, & cum cerae citrinae q. . fiat • mplatrum. A Schirrus does oft times proceed from coagulated Milk in Women;Hitory. as it fell out in a young Woman, whoe left Bret, while he was giving her Child uck, was wholly correpted with an Inflammation; the which being allayed, a large Tumour and Hardnes remained, which gave me upition of a Scirrhus. Her Body being well purged with a lenitive purgation, the Bret and its circumjacent parts anointed with Oyl of Roes, to which was added a little Vinegar, and this for ome days was ued, afterwards the whole Bret was anointed with this Liniment:Unguent. . Empl. de Mucilaginibus ij. ol. Lilior. Amygdal. dulc. pingued. Gallinae an. j. Gum. Amoniac. olut. in Acet. cillitic. & colat. . mice, fiat nguentum. Over which was applied this Cataplam:Cataplam. . fol. & rad. Alth. q. . incidantur minutiime, potea coqu. in aqua, & mortario pitentur, fiatque cum farin. Fabar. Axung. Porcin. Gallinae & proprio
decocto Malvar. Cataplama. By thee Medicines, and the Body being well purged, and a good order of Diet oberved, the hard Tumour grew oft and reolved; and to the Ulcer I applied powder of Precipitate, and over this Empl. de Ranis cum Merc. And with this method beyond expectation he recovered her perfect health.

div.head: CHAP. LII.
Of a Caruncle in the Yard, and its manner of Extirpation.
div.p:
AMongt the mot dangerous and frightful Affects which do eize on Humane Bodie,The Caues of a Gonorrhaea. this of a Gonorrhaea may be well reckoned: and this is excited by many caues; for Acrimony and Thinnes of the Sperm may be one caue o that it does continually flow. An Imbecillity of the Teticles does give another great upicion hereof. Another Caue amongt ome is attributed to Coition with a Mentruous Woman. Oft times it happens by overtraining the inward parts; a thing very frequent in nch who being in their Drunken fits do act beyond their power of Reaon. If the Seed therefore which is thus thrown forth be pure, and is not in any repect tinged with any trange quality, and is void of all fetid mell, this either does hew and expres a plenty thereof, or a weaknes of the Retentive Faculty, or Convulion of the Spermatick Veels. But if it be accompanied with any other vitious Humours, and furnihed with thin ill Juices, and appears with another colour
trange to its own proper nature, and yieldeth a mell which heweth no good Concoction, this firt of all does calefie, and by its acrimony does corrode, pricketh, and invadingly ulcerateth. And this Ulcer does much differ from that which exercieth it elf in the Bladder, and thus may with eae be ditinguihed: where the Neck of the Bladder is ulcerated, the pus or Matter does as it were compactly precede the Urine it elf; and the pain between making water is mot mightily harp about the ulcerated part. On the contrary, the Bladder it elf being ulcerated, there is no pain felt, nor Matter pied forth, ecreted by the Urine, but cometh along with it. The Urine does yield a trange trong mell where the Bladder is affected with an Ulcer. When the Urinary paage is ulcerated, the Yard is very painful and heavy, and bendeth downwards. An U •• er contracted in the Neck of the Bladder, or in the cavity of the penis, unles it be both peedily and knowingly cured, does convert it elf into preternatural Caruncles, by which the Urinary paage is obtructed: For as out of mot pure Blood the bet Fleh is generated; o alo vicious Juices enwrapping or keeping company with the Ulcers, there is oft times een a pongious
Fleh to grow and breed. And therefore when we have arrived at the ure knowledge, that this unnatural Guet hath made his entrance into thee quarters, which we may peedily find out by the earch of a Candle, and to gain advantage of this Diturber of the Humane peace, we ought, if Plenitude be a main wing of its vigour, to dicharge this by Evacuation. And here let the Patient ue a thin Diet; if the Juices be harp and thin, thicken them, o as that they may give trength to the Spermatick Veels; if we do here find or meet with any weaknes, trengthen them. And for clearing this Method, oberve with me thee Curative copes. Firt, looen the Body with emollient Clyters made of Mallows, Violets, Pellitory, Lettuce, French Barley, and the like, adding thereunto Caia in the end: After this breathe the Bailick Vein <> the right Arm. Thee two being premied, let the Thighs be wahed with a Decoction of Red Roes, French Barley, Violets, red Poppies, and the like. Let the Kidneys, Spine, and Teticles be cooled with this. . nguent. Roat. Refriger. Galen. an. j. ol. Violar. . pulv. Roar. rubr. Santal. Citrin. Spod. an. j. Camphor. gr • iij. Acet. Roat. gutt. aliquot. As to the part affected,
deterge it firt with a Decoction of French Barley, in which have been put ome Mel Roarum: this being made lukewarm is by a Syringe to be injected into the Yard. Then produce a Cicatrice with this following.Injection. . Aqu. Roar. Plantag. an. iiij. Sacchar. candit. j. Ceru. Lithargyr. aur. Alumin. Roch. an. i. Camphor. s. mice, fiat injectio. Trochici albi Rhais do here alo very well; but if you have a mind to dry more powerfully, adde to the former a little Aegyptiacum. Shun all trong Diureticks, which may force or drive the Humours to the ulcerated parts; and uch things are epecially to be ued, which have a quality in them to leen the pain. For this purpoe Lac Amygdalatum is very good. A Hypoarcois in the Neck of the Bladder, or in any part of the Urinary paage, may be collected out of the great difficulty of Urine, the which comes not onely out by drops, but by forcing, and endeavour to perfect this: So that ometimes upon a great training, while the Patient makes water, he hath a Laxity joyned with it. Neither can that Urine come right, which hath its paage obtructed by a Carunculous Fleh: Neither doth it eaily come forth, unles it be compreed with the Hand. Oft times
there is een uch Obtruction, that unles the Catheter be called in ue, there's no coming forth of Urine to be expected. There is a twofold Method in curing of a Caruncle of the Yard;A double Method in its Cure. the one is performed by Intrument, the other by Medicine. A Fomentation for this purpoe may be this:Fomentation. . fol. Malv. M. j. rad. Alth. Ap. Faenicul. an. iij. em. Lin. Cydonior. Foenugraec. an. j. fl. Chamomel. Staechad. Melilot. Puleg. Origan. an. pug. ij. Caricar pingu. i. coquant • r omnia uque ad radicum diolutionem, & cum hoc foveatur radix penis. Or ele dip Sponges herein, and apply them to the part affected. After it is thus fomented, it is to be abterged with uch an Unguent as this:Unguent. . nguent. Dialth. Agrip. Oeyp. Butyr. an j. ol. Amygdal. dulc. Lilior. albor. Chamomel. an. ij. Ammoniac. i. Succ. Ap. iij. Mucilag. emin. Foenugraec. rad. Alth. Lin. an. ij. boil them all untill the conumption of the Juices, then adde the Fats, and train it off, and to the trained Matter adde a little white Wax. Here alo are you to make ue of earching Candles made of white Wax. And for this Affect a Leaden Probe is excellent good, for that whereas beides that it is an Anodyne, o alo hath it a very drying faculty. When
thee fail, we come to the ue of a Catheter, but this without a very repective care and teddy hand does very often occaion trange Hemorrhagies, and o thereby doth frequently bring fear both to the Phyician and the Patient. But hould uch a Flux as this appear, this may with eae be topped by injecting into the Paage with a Syringe ome Plantane water and Roe water, to which the White of an Egge hould be added. Here alo are you to mind, how upon applying your Candle, what part thereof is either bent, or bruied, or compreed; for upon this part is to be applied your Medicines you intend to ue: and for this purpoe Philips Emplater is reputed to be a mot excellent and overeign Medicine in this Affect, becaue it healeth the adjacent parts, and keepeth them whole and afe; but that which grows with the Ulcer it taketh away without pain. This is its decription:Empl •
. Aerugin. Auripigment. Chalcat. Alumin. Roch. an. ij. his adde Acet. acerrim. perfu. inter duos marmoreos & fiat pulvis ubtibiimus, exponantur Soli. Then put it into freh Vinegar again, after dry it as formerly: let this be done for 8 or nine times, untill it hath lot all its Acrimony and Mordacity. This Powder being thus made, take of
Litharge of Gold ij. Oyl of Roes iiij. with which boil it, being mixed with the former, to the conitence of an Emplater. This is to be put at the end of a Searching Candle or Leaden Probe, o as that it falleth not off. This is in much eteem for this Affect. But becaue all Bodies have not one and the ame contitution and temper, therefore are Medicines to be changed accordingly: and after the Application hereof you are to inject into the part affected Goats Milk, or other Milk, or Roe water; to which may be added a little Camphire; and thee to be applied untill the pain ceae. You may know when the Caruncle is extirpated, when out of its inordination it is perceived about the ulcerated part, and alo out of the copiounes of the effluent Matter; the which alo, whilet it is extracted, the Candle does appear as if it were wholly imbued with it: and after this, if the Urine flow liberally, freely, quickly, and copiouly, and in its right method, there will be left but little occaion of doubt, but your Patient will do well, it being dicued and extirpated. The Ulcer is to be dicharged by a Liquor ent into the part affected through the Syringe: as, . Centuaur. maj. Apii Caud. equin. an. M. . Hord. contu. j.
coquantur in aquae fontanae lbij. ad conumpt. med. colaturae adde mel ij. & utere. The Ulcer being cleaned, you are to induce a Cicatrice, as with this or the like. . Aqu. Plantag. Roar. rubr. an. iiij. Ser. Lact. caprin. ij. Ceru. vj. Alumin. Roch. Marmor. candidiim. Spod. Crytal. an. i. Camphor. j. fiat pulvis ubtiliimus. And this is the whole Method which is and ought to be ued for a Caruncle. Unto thee alo might I adde Phymois and Paraphymois; but Fabritius Hildanus has writ most exactly hereof, and thereto do I commend the curious Chirurgeon.Hitory. I hall conclude this Chapter with this Hitory of a Gentleman, who fell into a uppreion of Urine by a tumefied Caruncle in his Yard, generated by an impure and immoderate Coition. A Chirurgeon being ent for to earch him with a Catheter occaioned a great Flux of Blood: the Patient being in much pain, and thus uppreed in his Urine grew into a Fever; for prevention of which I breathed a Vein, afterwards ordered an emollient and cooling Clyter, and anointed the Perinaeum and all its adjacent parts with a cooling Unguent: after this I precribed him a Vomit of Sal Vitrioli, by vertue of which he vomited up much
pituitous Matter, and in the econd Vomit went out an Ounce or two of Urine, whereby he found himelf omewhat cheared; and thus by degrees his Bladder was altogether unloaded within 4 or 5 hours, and the part affected being cured with S • l Prunella, Injections and Clyters, uch as you have already precribed, the Patient recovered.Hitory. Riverius in his 14 Obervat. writeth that Charles the Ninth, King of France, being much afflicted with this Ditemper, was by thee following Medicines cured; for which Cure was given 200 Pieces of Gold. . Ca. recenter extr. . Suc. Liquirit. j. Electuar. è ucc. Roar. ij. Aq. Lupul. iiij. fiat potio mane umenda. And for ten days after he drank of this Decoction half a pound. . rad. Liquirit. Alth. Sebet. Paul. an. M. i. Alth. malv. Apii. Petroelin. an. . aqu. fontan. lbij. coquantur ad mediae conumpt. After which were applied thee two Unguents. . ol. Roar. lbij. Ceru. Venet. iiij. Camphor. . Tuth. aqu. Roar. lot. & praeparat. . Lithargyr. praeparat. iij. pulv. Antimon. opt. i. Op. Thur. macul. vel Oliban. Matich. Alo. Epatic. an. ij. mice, ervetur in pixide plumbeo. The econd for Conolidation was this; . nguent. Roat. & aqu. Roar. lot. nguent.
alb. Camphorat. an. j. Pomat. . mice. Keep thefe for ue. The way of applying thee is at the end of a Searching Wax Candle, it being rubbed over with Oyl of weet Almonds; and if there be a double Carnoity, then apply the firt Unguent to both of them for fifteen or twenty days; and as it eemeth to diolve, and to turn into pus, then abate the applicacation of the firt; the Urine coming free and with eae, and for eight or ten days afterwards, apply the econd, untill no further Matter come forth. Hitherto hath our Dicoure treated of the Parts as they arie from the Head even to the Penis; the next which we hall produce are the variety of Herniaes or Ruptures, and thee as they arie hall offer themelves, with their everal Forms, Shapes, and Places, their Caues, Signs, and Cures, and Differences; and hall begin with an Intetinal Rupture, and o proceed to the ret in their order and form.

div.head: CHAP. LIII.
Of Ruptures in general.
div.p:
WE arrive now to Herniaes or Ruptures, the which for the mot part do dwell on the Hypogatrick Region. And whereas other Humours have allowed them three Caues, as being bred either out of an Influx of Humours, or Decumbency of Parts, or Congetion: All thee have their lively Forms and Shapes in the Tumours of the Teticles; for Tumours are made here either by Humours flowing, as Inflammations, Eryipelaes, Oedema, and Scirrhus; or from the Decumbent Parts; or from Congetion, as from Water, or any other Humour. Thee kind of Tumours are better and oftner cured by Chirurgery than Pharmacy. And as they are various in their Places, divers in Shapes, and manifold in Forms; o do thee, and every of them, make various Intentions and Indications for the Chirurgeon. And that every thing may fall ucceive to the wih both of Practier and Patient, in this place it will be very proper to know well and undertand the Parts framing the Teticles, they being
as the chief Caues and Effects of mot of thee Ruptures. Celus lib. 7. cap. 28. does account the Teticles to be Glandulous Bodies, wrapt about and twited with various Veels, Coats, and Ligaments. By the Greeks they are called < in non-Latin alphabet > , as being two in number, and thee are the Authors and Workmen of the Seed; for they have allowed them a vernaculate faculty of attracting and educing the Spermatick Matter from all the parts of the Body. The Coats of the Teticles are four, the firt called Epididymis, immediately enwrapping the Teticles, from whence it taketh its Name: the econd Elythrois, o called < in non-Latin alphabet > , or quai rubro imilis, or vaginalis: the third Dartos,
< in non-Latin alphabet > , becaue it is eaily excoriated, and lieth next the Scrotum: the lat is the Scrotum it elf. To thee Teticles alo belong Vaa deferentia & Vaa praeparantia, the Cremater Mucles, and the like. This may erve as a brief Anatomy of the Teticles and its neighbouring parts. We proceed now to the various Differences of Ruptures, before we treat ingly of each by it elf. And here be two kinds which do offer themelves, Bubonocele & Ocheocele, to each of which is betowed its proper name, for < in non-Latin alphabet > ignifieth inguen, and < in non-Latin alphabet >
Scrotum, as alo < in non-Latin alphabet >
Tumor. Thus have we Bubonocele repreent Hernia Inguinalis, and Ocheocele Tumor Scroti. There are many Differences of either, according to the Dicriminancy of the Conjunct Caues and Tumefying Subtances. Of Bubonocele are onely properly aid to be two, Epiplocele and Enterocele. Ocheocele hath ix, Enterocele, Epiplocele, Pncumatocele, Hydrocele, Sarcoccsle, and Cirocele. Enterocele is called Hernia Intetinalis, Epiplocele Hernia Omentalis, Omphalocele Hernia mbilicalis, Pneumatocele Hernia Ventoa, Hydrocele Hernia Aquoa, Cirocele Hernia Varicoa, Sarcocele Hernia Carnoa and Hernia Humoralis, this being bred from a Repletion of the Teticles with unnatural Humours. Or (if you pleae) there are generally allowed eight Ruptures, one complete called Bubonocele, when an Intetine or the Omentum decend no lower than the Inguens; the econd a complete Hernia, when they penetrate into the Scrotum, the Tunica Vaginalis being opened, or the Peritonaeum; If the Intetine decends, it maketh Enterocele, if the Kell Epiplocele, if a Tumour be made by a waterih Rupture Hydrocele, if by Wind Pneumatocele. If a Flehy Subtance grows within
the Scrotum Sarcocele, if the Veins be repleated beyond meaure, and be dilated in the Scrotum, Cirocele. To thee Avicen does adde Exomphalos, or a Prominency of the Navel; and of thee he offers thee four pecies to follow, as Enteroepiplocele, Hydroenterocele, Hydrophyocele, & Hydroarcocele. Every Rupture does demontrate its Signs and its Caues; Preages and Cure we hall offer in their proper places, beginning firt with Enterocele or Hernia Intetinalis, an Intetinal Rupture; before which as an Introduction it will be mot proper to dicoure of Bubonocele, it being as a leading Card to the ret.

div.head: CHAP. LIV.
Of Bubonocele or Hernia Inguinalis.
div.p:
CElus and Paulus, lib <> . 18. will have this reckoned amongt Ruptures, and there does call thee Varices of the Groin, and a Tumour of Inguen. Paulus, lib. 6, cap. 66. affirms it an Intetinal Rupture of the Inguen onely or imply, that is, when the Intetine does not decend any further: by the Greeks called < in non-Latin alphabet > . And here the large Veins which are in the Groin may o well, and prove o varicous, that they may create a Rupture here, o as this proves a Chirurgical Affect. But before I proceed any further in this Chapter, be pleaed to conider thoe many Errors, which are committed by unskilful Chirurgeons, who very frequently do take Venereal Buboes for Inguinal Ruptures, and o do cut for the Intetine without either Wit or Honety, or ele do prejudice to the great Vein there ordered by Nature, and thereby bring danger of death. But that you may the better undertand the difference, conider with me, that if you perceive a oft Tumour in the Inguen, from the beginning
you may well upect a Dilation being made by the Intetine; a Bubo in the beginning being hard, epecially being Venereal. It being a Rupture, if the Patient lie on his back, the Intetine falleth inwards with eae, and the Tumour does vanih; and upon the Patients riing it returns with as much eae: In a Bubo there is always a contained Tumour. But arriving to the matter of our preent Dicoure, a Bubonocele does mot generally gain the name of being the beginning of an Intetinal Rupture more properly, than the name of a Rupture; the Intetine firt making its fall through the Inguen, before it enters the Scrotum, and o does necearily dilate it: And therefore Paulus aith, that the Intetinal Rupture of the Inguen does precede a Rupture elewhere; for if the Peritonaeum be made intene in its lower part by Wind, or any other caue, and the Intetine makes its turgid way thither, being alo filled with Wind; or by being filled with Excrements, and thereby forceth it elf, it makes this Bubonocele; the which by Paulus requireth a double method of Cure, the one being to be performed by Inciion, the other by Ution. The firt of thee by Paulus is thus performed: He cuts upon the tume • ied place in a
treight line the length of three tranvere Fingers, and o paeth through the Membrana carnoa, and then makes o deep an Inciion, untill he finds the Peritonaeum bare, and the Fat alo being ablated and removed. Celus will have this done with courage, and the Inciion to be made to the middle Coat, which maketh the Vagina; afterwards he with a Probe does depres the Peritonaeum, and o as that the Intetine be compelled inwards; and having lodged his Probe, and compreed the Peritonaeum, he by Sutures does draw the lips of the Wound together; the which being done, he takes out the Probe, and cures the remain as you do imple Wounds. This is Paulus Method, which is performed by Suture, binding up only the Cutis, as by Atriction. The econd of his, which is performed by Ution, is both cruel, painful, and terrible, contracting the Cutis by the trength and force of the Fire, and making a contracted and hard Ciccatrice, and by this means do depres the Tumour, and will not uffer the Peritonaeum to lift it elf upwards. But leaving thee, a well made Trus is much better, performeth its buines with more eae, gentlenes, and atisfaction; this having in it the faculty of prohibiting the oft Tumour, by compreing
the Ditention of the Peritonaeum, and hindering the Impetuoity of the Intetine: to which Trus we uually ix a Quilt or mall pyramidal Pillow, it ometimes being made in form of a Myrtle Leaf: and after the Reduction this being own to the Trus is to be applied to the part affected. In ome caes here this may not be convenient; as hould there happen a Varix in the Groin, and the Veins tumeie, the Veins by this being compreed by the tying of both its ends up; and if the preparing Veels be varicoed, if they be bound up, the Generation of the Seed would be hindered. And therefore in this cae Retringent Medicines are more proper, as Balautians, Cypres Nuts, Lignum vitae, Galls, Pomgranate Rinds, Red Roes, Medlers. Women for the mot part are troubled with a Bubonocele, becaue the Womb falleth from the exteriour Coat of the terus, and o doth produce Hernia terina, as Caparus Bauhinus oberveth, Lib. 2. Anatom. Oberv. 62. Fabritii you may read of a new married Woman, who in repect of an ill Dyet and bad Habit of Body was perplexed with the Itch, and not long after growing big bellied, and having a hard burthen, there followed a Prolapion of the
terus; he coming to him for advice and help, he orders her this following Bag to be applied for three or four days to the part affected, and to carry it always about her, by the benefit of which he was peedily cured. The things which were put in it were thee, and thus ordered . Fol. Plantag. Salic. Mepilor. Querc. Prunor. Sylvestr. ummitat. Roar. rubr. an. M. j. rad. Tormentil. Conolid. major. Bitort. an. j. Nuc. Cupre. Balaut. an. . em. Ani. i. incidantnr & contundantur omnia groo modo pro acculo intertexto.

div.head: CHAP. LV.
Of Enterocele or Hernia Intetinalis.
div.p:
BEfore I proceed to the Cure of a perfect Intetinal Rupture, I hall begin with that which hath the Peritonaeum relaxed or dilated. The Intetine does decend, either becaue this Coat is either dilated or rent. The Signs of a Dilation are, becaue the Intetine does not uddenly decend, but does remain in the Orifice; then it does not decend to the bottom of the Teticle, the Tumour is equal and profound. The Signs of its Coat being rent are, a udden Decent of the Intetine, an unequal Tumour, a peedy Relape of it into the bottom of the Teticle. Celus cap. 14. lib. does offer thee as Signs of an Intetinal Rupture; the Tumour ometimes encreaing, ometimes leening; encreaing, either becaue a greater part of the Intetine falls down, or becaue it is more repleted than it ought, ometimes by Wind, ometimes by Excrement. If the Tumour do encreae, becaue the Excrements are fallen into the Intetine, then Scare it is to be expected to be drawn forth again; then is there pain in the
Scrotum, Inguen, and Abdomen; becaue here is made a olution of Continuity, whereby the Stomach is affected, and thereby throws forth Choler, afterwards green or black, then Excrement, and after thee follows an inflammation of the Teticles. A econd Sign, the Tumour is not painful, ometimes it wholly vaniheth, and being compreed it with eae returneth into the Abdomen, and with as much eae falls out again with ome noie, the Tumour being light, lubricous, and round. Mot times the Ileon falls down, yet ometimes the other Guts come out with it, and do fall into the Scrotum. But this happeneth not by a imple Ditention of the Peritoneal Proces, but it mut necearily burt in all great Ruptures. This oft times happens in Children by falling, leaping, vomiting, coughing, any vehement motion, crying, concuion, or the like. The Duodenum and Rectum cannot fall into the Scrotum, this Anatomy ufficiently maketh good. The Jejunum is tied by the Liver by the Meeraick Veins, and the Colon knit to the upper parts; and here is no Rupture without diviion of thee. The Caecum, becaue it is lippery in the right ide, and eparates from the ret, does eaily fall into the right ide of the Scrotum, the Peritonaeum
being either rent or dilated; and this Galen alloweth Com. ad Aphorim. 3. ect. 4. lib. 6. Epidid. Into the left ide the Ileon alo is ubject to fall into the Scrotum, and thus there may be a double Enterocele, one of the Caecum, another of the Ileon. This of the Ileon is the mot dangerous and terrible, becaue by this is intercepted the ditribution both of the Chyle and Nutriment, and the ecretion of the Excrement, which is the neceary office of the Ileon as touching preervation of Life: beides this an intolerable pain is excited, and is oft times inflamed, whence follows a Gangrene, into whoe ympathy of affection are all the ret of its neighbouring parts drawn. Here is alo made the Iliaca Paio, after which follows vomiting both of Chyle and Excrements, this being as the Harbinger or Forerunner of Death. Now as touching Dilatation according to Avicen two things are required,How the Intetine is to be repoed. the one a reduction of the Intetine upwards into the Abdomen or Belly, the econd preventing its coming forth again. The firt is eaily reolved, if the Intetine do not much fall out, or it be not welled with Wind, or filled with Excrements, for then it may with eae be driven in by the Fingers, laying your Patient on his
Back, with his Legs omewhat elevated, and a little aunder: but if it be filled with Excrements or Wind, then are we to ue another Method, by uing of hot Baths, Cataplams dicuing Wind, and by precribing lenifying Medicines, for which ue and purpoe take thee as proper Engines to work this; . rad. Alth. ij. Cataplam. Lilior. albor. j. fol. Malv. Violar. Parietar. an. M. . fl. Chamomel. Melilot. Roar. rubr. an. pug. ij. coquantur omnia in aquae q. . Colaturae adde farin. Fabar. Hord. an. ij. farin. em. Lin. Fenugraec. an. j. ol. Roar. Chamomel. Aneth. Axung. Capon. an. j. mice, fiat Cataplama. This is to be applied when the Excrements are indurate. When the Wind wells them up ue this Unguent: .Unguent. ol. Chamomel Rut. an. j. ol. Aneth. Lilior. an. vj. Spirit. Vin. ij. Cer. flav. q. . fiat nguentum. And for a Bath ue this as very excellent: . Bilingu. Plantag, Polygon. nuc. Cupre. cort. Catanar. German. Hypocyt. cort. Granator. Capular. Gland. rad. Symphit. major. an. M. ij. Gallar. M. j. aqua fabror. in quo ignita extinguuntur lb 20.Decoction. infundantur per horas 24. & deinde lento igne redigantur ad 3 partis conumpt. & ante ab igne removetur, adde Acet. Optim. lbiij. erva ad uum. This Fomentation is mot
proper when the Intetine does lodge in the Inguen; a Cerate for the ame of a Venetian Phyician:Cerate. . Theriac. opt. Bol. Armen. Sangu. Dracon. in gutt. Alo. Succotrin. an. . mice in mortario cum Terebynth. Venet. vel cum pice navali pro Cerato. For purging in this cae Electuarium Diacatholicon and Powder of Rhubarb are very proper Medicines. Here alo may you order Manna, Syrup of Roes, with convenient Decoctions, and the like. The Intetine being repoed, you are to ue all retringent things after the applying of the former Bath, and uch as have an agglutinating and drying quality, uch as are Rupturewort, Betony, Compfrey, Solomons Seal, Plantane, Balautians, Red Roes, Pomgranate Rinds, Cypres Nuts, Bol. Armen. Dragons Blood, Matich. Amber, Coral, Olibanum, out of which may be framed Powders, Electuaries, Pills, and the like. A Decoction of Saraperilla, Guiacum, and Sarafras, are here alo proper. The outward Topicks hould alo have the ame aculties and vertues, being made of Galls, Cypres Nuts, and the like. Here alo Empl. Adherniam is very good. Avicen does praie this;Empl. . Nuc. Cupre. acac. Balaut. Gallar. immaturat. an. j. Myrrb. Thur. Sarcocoll. Tragaganth.
Gum. Arabic. an. iij. Sangu. Dracon. Mummiae an. ij. terantur cum Aceto. Or this accounted better:Empl. . Malicor. Bol. Armen. Sangu. Dracon. an. j. Tegul. pulveriat. ij. pulv. Bilingu. ij. cum albumine ovi modico aceti & Colophon. fiat Emplatrum. Empl. Or this Empl. . Empl. Adhern. Grat. Dei an. j. pulv. Sang. Draco. Omund. Regal. pulv. Oliban. Guaiac. an. i. cum parum Ol. Myrtillor. fiat Empl. A purging Apozeme to give the Patient may be this:Apozem. . Omund. Regal. Hernar. an. M. j. rad. conolid. major. Bistort. an. i. Hypericflor. M. j. em. Ani. ij. conquantur omnia in vino rubro, & colaturae lbi. adde yrup. conolid. major. iij. vel 4 pro Apozemate. Thee two Emplaters of Hollerius are much commended applied outwardly:Empl. . Matich. cort. Thur. Nuc. Cupres. Myrrh. Sarcocoll. glutin. pic. Icthiocoll. an. . olvatur Icthiocolla in Aceto & fiat Empl. uper corio extendatur. Or this:Empl. . Balautian. i. Gallar. . rad. Aphodil. rad. Narci. vel rad. Arnoglo. & Betar. an. i. coquantur in vino, fiat Emplatrum. All things being performed, the Patient conveniently purged, the part affected well fomented, and proper atringent Medicines being applied, after the repoition of the
part, we are after this with convenient Bolters, and Trues to finih our buines, and thee are to be kept on o long, untill the lacerated Peritonaeum be o firmly united either together again, or to the Mucles of the Belly, that there can be no fear of any more Relape. A general example of all Trues I will hew you at the end of this Tract, their various Forms and Fahions for ingle or double Ruptures.Hito • y I hall conclude this Chapter with an Hitory of a Proctor, whoe Intetine falling into his Scrotum, he afterwards fell into an Iliaca paio, the Intetine being o filled and tuffed up with dried Excrements, that hindered its •• poition and after many Remedies had been ued for nine days in vain, he ordered the party to be opened to the production of the Periteuaenm, where the Intetine was choaked up, let the Continuance of this Ditemper might create a Gangrene; and following Celus Opinion when he offereth, Satiùs et anceps remedium experiri, quàm certo exitio aegrum exponere. Upon which Conultation it was agreed, the Patient being conveniently placed, to make an Inciion even to the production of the Peritonaeum, after which was ent in a mall Silver Pipe, round at one end, and hollowed at the other, and into the
Cavity whereof this Inciion was made to that length which was requiite; after this was the Intetine reduced, and ent into the Belly, then was the Proces own up, and the Wound of the parts healed up by Gatroraphia, and with Conglutinating Medicines the remainder of the Cure was performed, and the Patient perfectly cured.

div.head: CHAP. LVI.
Of an Intetinal Rupture, the Peritonaeum being rent.
div.p:
HEre are required the ame Scopes as were dicoured in the former Chapter; the Intetine is to be repoed, and care taken that it cometh not out again, the which is performed if the Rupture be united and agglutinated. Pure drying Medicines for this purpoe alone take no place, but uch as have a glutinous and vicid quality, mixed with a drines; thee are mot operative and ueful, as uch as was in the lat Chapter precribed by Hollerius; or for this Affect take ome of thee:Cerate. . Oliban. Sang. Dracon. Bol. Armen. Matich. an. vj. Alo. Epatic. Thur. alb. Mumm. an. iij. lento igne fiat Emplatrum. Or thee of Aquapendens: Empl. . Terely. • th. i. Cer. Thur. Myrrh. Icthiocol. carn. cochlear. an. j. gluten triduo in aceto macerat. inde in mortario plumbeo levigetur ac conteratur, pot igne liquecat, ac caeteris miceatur. An • ther. Or this: . Rein. arid. Ammoniac. Thur. Bitumin. Sulphur. vin. an. part. aequal. terantur terenda, lique. fiant liquanda, deinde Sulphur adjiciatur,
applicetur vel linteo vel corio; and let it remain on o long untill it pontaneouly fall off.Oyl. An Oyl for the ame: . Sarcocoll. Thur. Matich. Sangu. Dracon. an. ij. Terebinth. Venet. vel Rein. lb. Gyp. pulv. lbj. tent in fimo equino per dies 40, & tunc ditillentur, & ex hoc locus inungatur. A Bath for the ame is very excellent, uch as is this: . fol. Myrtil. Roar. immaturatur. Biling. Conolid. major. an. M. . Balaut. Plantag. cort. Granator. an. iij. Caryophyl. i. coquantur omnia in aqua fontana à lbviij. ad lbiiij. & coletur After this apply ome of the former Emplaters, and then trus your Patient up. And this is the Methodical way of ordering your Patients. And in your Proceedings you ought alo to take repect to the Habit of your Patients Body, by purging all uch Humours as may eem to diturb our Undertakings; and here may be ordered inwardly everal orts of Medicines, as either Bolus, Syrups, Pills, Electuaries, or the like, being ordered according to the trength, capacity, age, and contitution of your Patient; for which ue you may take ome of thee: . Electuar. Linitiv. ij. Spec. Hier. picr. ij. mix them with Sugar, and order it for a Bolus for your Patient to take ome every morning. This Syrup is alo excellent:
.Syrup. Syrup. Betonic. Mel Roar. an. ij. Decoct. Betonic. Biling. Cichor. an. iij. mice. An Electuary for the ame: .Electuary. Limatur. chalyb. praeparat. decies cum aceto lot. & totidem cum aqua Roar. iij. Matich. alb. ij. pulv. Rad. conolid. major. Piloell. an. iij. Sacchar. Roat. lbj. cum yrup. è ucc. Plantag. q. . fiat Electuar. hujus umat . per dies 30. Pills here alo very proper:Pil. . Alo. uccotrin. Agaric. praepar. Rhabarb. Piloell. an. ii. cum Terebinth. Ven. q. . fiant Pil. Let thee erve for a Tate of inward Medicines; for outward Medecines avail but little, if there be not well oberved a good order of Diet, in which we are to take care both for the Patients quiet and ret. But if thee fail,A econd Method by Adution. and will not anwer expectation, Avicen advieth us to ue a econd Method, which is performed by Adution, making a trong impreion by the hot Intrument, which may hereby contract the Cutis, and alo hinder the decent of the Intetine. But in this Operation take pecial care of not touching the Intetine with the Iron; for hould this happen, it would or might bring danger of Death to your Patient. This is to be performed by many mall pungent red hot Intruments, keeping alo all the Seminary Veels afe and ecure from injury, the which
being any ways hurt, the Generation of Seed would conequently be impedited. Some of thee hould be emicircular, whilet others ought to be more pungent, having a very harp point, ever beginning the Ution from the upper part, o decending through the whole Region of the Rupture.A third Method is Inciion. A third Method is Inciion, and this is two fold, the one performed by the Chirurgeon, of which we will firt treat; the other of an Emperick: the firt Cure being performed without extraction of the Stones, the econd with it. In the firt let the Patient tand and hold his Wind, that the Tumour may more evidently appear; and when you intend the Operation, you are firt to mark the place, with Ink where you intend to open or incie, then are you to make your Inciion through the length of the whole dilated Vaginal Coat, the Vagina being elevated either with the Finger or mall Hooks, then with an Inciion Knife you are to make a Diametrical Inciion, both to the Membranes and Vaginal Coat rent or dilated, then with a firm, thick, and crooked Needle, you are to make a Suture according to the length of the whole Dilatation in the dilated Vagina, drawing a thick and trong Thred (the inward Veels of the Seed inwardly remaining
afe and entire) through, the Coat is to be agglutinated, without extraction or hurting of the Teticles; then let the Patient be put to Bed, and after this apply uch things as are agglutinative, then induce a Cicatrice, and keep your Patient well trued.The fourth Method. The fourth and lat Method is performed the Emperical manner, and this is with Extraction of the Teticle, a way very ueles and dangerous. It is thus repeated by Paulus, cap. 65. lib. 6. The Patient being placed with his Head downwards, the Intetine being reduced, part of the Abdomen being compreed by an Aitant, and the Patient being bound make an oblique mark in his Groin, after this make a deep Inciion, o that the Teticle may come forth with the Spermatick Veels, the which the Chirurgeon having in his hands, let him eparate all the Coats, and draw forth the Teticle through the ame Orifice, all the other parts being taken aide with mall Hooks, let them be own together or tied, after this above the place tied take them off, and with an hot cauterizing Iron being there intantly ready, cauterize the mouths of the Veels, hereby hindering all Flux; beides which you will find the parts ooner agglutinated: the which
being done, they leave a long Thred remaining, applying Digetions inwardly. After this they make a Cavity in the Scrotum, and there applying a Digetive, they ue Butter, to which they adde Frankincene, the Yolk of an Egge, and a little Turpentine; then they tudy the generation of Fleh with Bailicon, Aureum, nguentum de Betonica, or the like, and induce a Cicatrice with dried Lints and Unguents, Diapompholigos, Diapalma, Deiccativum rubrum, Hitory. &c. I hall conclude this Chapter with a Hitory of Hildanus, who writes of a Gentleman, which for many years was troubled with an Intetinal Rupture, ditended by Wind, having a great pain of his whole Belly, continual Vomiting, Watchings, Retlenes adjoyned to it; for whom this Clyter was firt adminitred:Clyter. . Rad. Alth. Malv. cum toto, fol. Violar. Parietar. fl. Chamomel. Melilot. Sambuc. an. M. j. em. Fenugraec. Lin. contu. an. . em. Ani. Foenicnl. Caru. Cumin. an. j. incidantur & contundantur omnia, potea indantur in acculo ejus magnitudinis quâ totum Scrotum cooperiri poit: the which being own up, boil it in twelve pounds of Water. Take of this Decoction lbj. in which diolve of Electuar. Diacatholic. j. Vitel. Ovor. n. ij. Butyr.
recent. ol. commun. an. iij. mice. fiat Enema. After the Bag being preed out, apply it to the Scrotum, and this repeat very often by dipping it into the Decoction, and o preing it out, and applying it warm. Within half an hour after the Clyter was injected, there was adminitred the ame Decoction, by which the Scrotum began to grow lax, and the Patient being put into his Bed, with his Head placcd upinely or downwards, and his Feet upwards, his Intetine was reduced; and for keeping it in its place he applied to the Scrotum this following Retringent Bag;A Restringent Bag. . Roar. rubr. Abynth. vulgar. prunor. ylvetr. Caud. equin. fol. alv. Moc. Quercin. an. M. Cort. Querc. ij. em. Foenicul. Ani. an. j. incidantur & contundantur, potea indantur in acculo; which is to be owed up, and boiled in red Wine, and afterwards applied. The day following he precribed this Purge:Purge. . Rad. Foenicul. Petroelin. Gramin. Polypod. Querc. an. . herb. Agrimon. Veronic. Cucuth. an. M. . em. Ani. Foenicul. an. ij. fol. Senn. mundat. . coquantur ut colatura redeat ad iiij. in quibus olve Electuar. Diacatharm. Diaphaenic. an. iij. aqu. Cinamom. Hordeat. . mice. After this was applied Emplatrum
ad Herniam, and a convenient Trus: and by thee Helps and Remedies he was perfectly cured.

div.head: CHAP. LVII.
Of Epiplocele or Hernia Omentalis.
div.p:
THis < in non-Latin alphabet > o called by the Greeks from Epiploon or Omentum may happen in either ide of the Scrotum, and may not very eaily be reduced. This Rupture is occaioned by the Dilatation of the middle Coat onely, not becaue of the Peritonaeum being rent, by reaon no great part of the Omentum decendeth, it being annexed to the bottom of the Ventricle, Colon, and Spine. This therefore is chiefly generated by the Coats Dilatation, epecially the Omentum being armed with Fat, which gives a more eaie caue to this Relaxation and Dilatation, although not to its Ruption.Signs. Signs of an Omental Rupture are thee; the Tumour is always the ame, unequal to touch, oft, and lippery in repect of its Fat, it lieth more in the Os pubis than in the Scrotum, and is mall in Tumour. Its Curative Scopes are two, to reduce the Omentum inwards,
which is performed by the Hand, and to hinder its exition; and this is done by Pharmacy. And becaue this Dilatation generally is occaioned by Moiture, or the Fat relaxing this Rupture; therefore Retrictives are the mot proper Medicines in this place required; and here take Aquapendens his Emplater: . Alo. Malicor. in vino autero elixat. ucc. Hypocytid. Thur. glutin. fabror. an. partes aequales, gluten pao incoquatur ad integram diolutionem, post teratur in mortario, & cae • era addautur. As touching the ret, this Cure diereth not much from an Intetinal Rupture, and therefore Trues, Cautick, or Inciion may upon occaion be ued, oberving Celus Rule, lib. 7. cap. 25. If a mall part of the Omentum decend, this may properly be repoed; but if a great part, this is to be burnt, or dealt with o that it falleth off: yet this is not to be attempted very readily, becaue this Rupture is een very often beyond expectation cured. I hall hut up this Dicoure with two or three pleaant Hitories, very convenient for this purpoe and matter.Hitory. Hollerius relates of a pious youug man, who died Ileous, from a Prolapion of the Ileon with the Omentum into the Scrotum; the which Body being diffected, the Ileon was wholly
found gangrenated by reaon of Inflammation, which was conceived to be by this Prolapion.Another. Columbus lib. 15. Anatom. writes, he aw above a pound of Omentum in the Scrotum. Another. Jacobus Oetheus lib. Obervat. propr. writes of a young Gentleman, who having been troubled with an Inguinal Rupture, and the Intetines oft times falling into the Scrotum, he at length found omewhat ele fall into it alo, it being no part of the Intetines, but the Omentum which welled the Scrotum at this rate; and the Signs hereof were, he had neither Cholical Pains, nor Motions, nor Fever, nor Obtructions of the vicera. That part of the Omentum which was laped, by application of convenient Fomentations, Emplaters, and Ligature to the part affected, they were well repoed, the Patient oon felt eae, and in proces of time received a perfect Cure.

div.head: CHAP. LVIII.
Of Exomphalos or Hernia mbilicalis.
div.p:
EXomphalos is made by the Peritonaeum being either relaxed or rent; and hence oft times happens that the Omentum and the Intetines do fall into its place. If it happeneth by the Omentum, it retains the colour of the Cutis; and there will appear a oft and almot indolent Tumour, and is repoed without any noie; but happening by the Intetines, it appears unequal, and upon its Reduction it maketh a Murmuration. If it happens from Fleh, it appears hard; if from Wind, oft: and this by the Learned called Exomphalos, by us a Navel Rupture, proceeds from the ame Caue as the former, and may be treated with the ame Curative Method; ave onely in this place you are to mind, that you cover the whole Rupture with hard, and thick, and large Bolters, that hereby it may ufficiently be kept in. If it happens that it proves a flatuous Tumour of the Navel, cure it as you do Phyocele; if a waterih Tumour, this is to be thus treated, by making a mall Inciion, and keeping it open o long as untill you have
dicharged the whole Water. Hildanus in his Centur. 3. Oberv. 64. relates of a pleaant tory to this purpoe; o does Benivenius tell us of a trange one: the lat I will produce firt, becaue that of Hildanus I intend to give according to the Author himelf, with his Figures and Method how to make and apply the outward Dreings and Ligatures.Hitory. Benivenius chap. 6. Abditis, relateth a trange tory of John Binus, who had a Son whoe Navel grew out like a Mans penis, four fingers in length, and as it were had a Coat of the Teticles joyned to it, out of which ometimes Spirits did fly, the which many Phyicians aw; whereupon ome of them judged, ome of the Intetines had thrut themelves out; others, the Omentum; others attributed it to Wind and Humours; but at length it was concluded, that it was a Flehy Excrecency, and for the taking this off there was a trict Bandage made, the which was every day contracted or bound cloer, untill the whole was eradicated; the which being removed, the Patient recovered his perfect Cure and Health.Hitory.

This of Fabritius Hildanus is of a noble and pious Martron in Germany, in whom not onely the Navel it elf, but a little above the Peritonaeum, and ome
part of the Abomen, it hung down dilated into a great Bag; in this Bag alo not onely the Omentum, but omewhat of the Intetine was contained. Sometimes a murmuring was there perceived; and then pain was preent, ometimes proving very vehement, otherwhile more remis, according to the quantity of Winds then preent. She affirmed to him, he got this Affect in the time of her Childbearing. Of the ret, becaue Prolapes of this ort, of the Navel or Abdomen, can be eldom reduced into the Belly; or if they might be, they are not there retained without great difficulty; they produce wonderful troubles to the Patients that are therewith vexed, when they by reaon of the weight do draw their upper parts downwards. For this purpoe he hath invented a new Bag, by which this Extuberance may as well as poibly be drawn upwards, and o elevated, that the grieved Patient may bear the burthen with much les trouble and incommodiounes. This is to be made of a trong doubled Cloth fitted to the Thorax, o as that it decends no lower than the firt Batard Rib, and o backwards to the Thorax from the Region of the Omoplates, making a Ligature on either ide placed two fingers breadth,
and perforated in everal places, to fit it the better to the Thorax. To this Ligature is to be annexed this large one with the Bag, o as it may be lifted up or taken down, according to the will and pleaure of the Patient; by the benefit of which holes this may be done. This Figure you may ee very fairly decribed in this following Leaf, together with the Bandage, with Figures directing how to make and ue it.

div.head: CHAP. LIX.
Of Hydrocele or Hernia Aquoa.
div.p:
HYdrocele or Hernia Aquoa do either poes the whole Scrotum, or part thereof. This Aqueous Humour is not collected in the Scrotum, but in the Membrana Erythrois, containing the Teticle, for into this a thin fluid Humour does make its influx, being much of the conitence of Urine, ditending this Erythroidal Membrane; and the ubitance of the Teticle in proces of time is alo corrupted by its acrimony. By Aetius Leonidas this Aqueous Tumour is aid to be looe, and without pain, the which is not to be eaed by any Cataplams, Fomentations, Emplaters, or Unguents. There's one onely Remedy which mut dicharge it, and that is Section or Inciion: and this is very manifet and apparent, becaue the Seminal Vein of this part arieth not from the Cava, as do the right, but from the left Emulgent. The Kidney being by this evilly affected, not performing its proper function, part of the Urine, the which the Emulgent protracts to it elf, whenas it cannot decend to the Bladder from the
ill-affected Kidney, it falleth into the Membrance Elythrois, and here breeds Hydrocele; and this being ublated with the Teticle, this Humour can no longer remain here, as Dodonaeus oberves, cap. 39.Caues. Oberv. The Caues hereof may be many, ome being occult, others manifet; occult, as this waterih Humour being gathered from the repleted Veels. Guido adds a Vice of the Liver herein or Spleen, by reaon of which there is a Liquor collected in the Hypocondries, which with eae does make its decent manifet, as Percuion, Colliion, Fraction of Veels which are in the Teticles; for the Blood which flows into the Veels is changed and turned, by reaon of the weaknes of parts, into an aqueous ubtance. Percuion and Colliion,Signs. and the like, are its Signs; the Tumour vaniheth if Hunger hath preceded. If the Habit of the Body be ill, this Hernia proceeds from the ill accident of ome Bowel; if not hence, it may from too much Liquor, for Repletion is made by too much Potation. Aetius taketh the Caues from the Humour it elf, the which if it be yellowih and pale, the Hernia will appear from the Repletion of the Veels; if feculent, from Percuion; if white, from a Vice of the Liver or Spleen; the Veins of the Scrotum
are tumefied; if it be compreed, the Humour floweth into the Veels which formerly were empty. It hineth and appears very bright, and is oft, light, and clear, by viewing it, and applying a Candle on the oppoite part. It is a particular Dropie; and as a general Dropie is bred by a collection of Matter, as in a Critical Abces, by drinking more freely of Water than can be dicharged by Vomit, by Generation, by interception, or alleviation of a Sanguiick Faculty. So a Hernia aquoa & flatuoa do either come by a primogene affection, or by ucceion of ome other Ditemper: and for this reaon Hollerius does precribe here uch things as are to be given in either kind of Dropie, this ometimes happening between this and the Erythrois, ometimes between the Erythrois and Dartos. As touching the Cure,Cure. all Caues are to be removed, the ill Habit of the Body corrected, from too much Drink the Patient ought to be precribed, the plenty of this watery Humour to be dicharged and evacuated, and the whole Habit of the Body amended. And for the performance of thee, Purgatives, Diaphoreticks and Diureticks are very proper intrumental Weapons to dicharge this invaive companion, of which
I have already preented you with many in my Tract of Aqueous Tumours.Topicks. As touching outward Applications, thee ought to contain in them a power to dicharge this Water contained in the Teticles, this to be performed either by Repellers driving it back, or by educing it by the part affected,Empl. or by Scarrification. Hollerius does offer this as an excellent Plater, being made of freh Cows Dung, adding thereto a third part of Bol. Armen. Fomentation. and Dragons Blood. A Fomentation for the ame may be this: . Lixiv. Barbito • or. iiij. in his coquantur Cumin. iiij. Rut. Abynth. Puleg. Petroelin. Apii an. . Sal. j. with this let the part affected be fomented. Or this:Another. . Cumin. Bac. Laur. em. Seel. Rut. an. j. fiat Decoctum in vino rubro, & fiat Fomentum. Or for this ue take this Cataplam;Catapl. . Stercor. Vaccin. ij. Sulphur. Cumin. an. ij. Empl. de Bacc. Laur. pulv. Juniper. Ani. an. ij. mice, & cum pauco mellis fiat Cataplama. Or thee; . Cumin. Baccar. Laur. fimi Columbin. Cator. an. part. aequal. coquantur cum oleo Roarum & pauc. Cerae. Firt apply your Baths, then anoint the part affected, and afterwards apply your Caplams. If thee fail, we are to come to Apertion, which may be ued two ways,
either by Inciion or Cautick; if by Cautick, the place is to be cauterized in the place where the Water is, and then after it is once dicharged, a new Collection is to be prevented. And here Galen does order the part to be kept open for a long while, by placing in a Silver Pipe into the affected part. Guido maketh a Seton, and keeps it a long while. Celus teacheth the place of Inciion, aying, If it be a Child that is herewith troubled, it is to be laid open in the Inguen, and the water to be drawn upwards.
