If in one of a greater age, this is to be opened in the bottom of the Scrotum, and that way the water to be let out; taking this as Advice, that water is not to be left long in the Scrotum, let by its delay there it does the Teticle injury; or hereby there grows a Hernia carnoa. The Body being well prepared for your Operation of Inciion, and a good order of Diet precribed, let the Patient be well placed, then in the upper part even to the Tunica Erythrois is the Scrotum to be incied; this is omewhat to be eparated in its outward part from the Membrane it elf. And becaue the Water wholly is contained in this Coat, o the Teticle wims therein; and let this Water hould decend, with a crooked Needle and double
Thread the whole Coat is to be apprehended (beides the Seminal Veels) and then to be moderately bound and tied; after this divide the Membrane in the lower part of the Ligature lengthways, and draw out the water or liquor contained within; then with a long Tent, it being of a moderate thicknes, being dipt in the White of an Egge, to which ome retrictive Powders have been added, apply it to the ide of the Teticle, and about the lower part of the Scrotum, anointing the Inguens and Abdomen with Oyl of Roes: the day following let this Digetive be applied; . Terchinth. lot. ij. Cer. nov. . Gum. Elem. j. ol. Roar. & Amygdal. dulc. . ol. de vitell. Ovor. ij. diolve Gummi lento igne cum ol. Terebinth. & Cerâ cum pauxillo Oleorum liquefactis, fiat nguentum, fine addendo Croc. j. With this let the Tents be armed, which are to be put into the Orifice; afterwards apply a mundefying Powder to cleane the Ulcer, and keep it open for near two moneths; and then cloe up the Wound with a Cicatrice. I conclude with a Hitory of Hildanus, Hitory. who writes of a Commiary 40 years of age, a man trong and of a good Habit of Body, vexed for many years with a watery Rupture, unto whom both many inward
and outward Medicines were precribed and applied without any ucces; and it growing to a great bulk, that it occaioned a large Tumour in the Scrotum, and proved o painful that the Patient would rather yield to any Method which could give appearance of eae; his Body being prepared, and a good order of Diet ordered him, with adminitring Purgings, and their reiterations, with Bleeding, &c. he being conveniently placed, the Scrotum was opened in the upper part of the Coat Erythrois, and this on the fore part omewhat eparated; and becaue the whole Teticle did wim in water, which was contained in that Coat, that the water might make no further decent, with a crooked Needle and double Thread, the whole Coat and Seminary Veels were moderately taken up and bound; after this in the lower part of the Ligature the Membrane was divided lengthways, and by degrees was drawn forth ome pounds of Water, after which was applied a Pledget long and thick enough, dipped in the White of an Egge, Bol. Armen. and the like, then was applied the ame Digetive I formerly have decribed, and with this were armed the Tents and Pledgets, and over thee nguentum Bailicon; and with all care the Ulcer being mundefied,
digeted, and filled with Fleh, it was skinned, and the Patient perfectly recovered. Riverius relates another tory of a Child of 15 moneths old, who was troubled with a watery Rupture in his right ide of his Teticle, with Matter contained in the Dartos, equalling the bignes of a mall Egge; and this he had almot from his firt coming into the world: how he received his Cure I will commit you to the Author himelf.

div.head: CHAP. LX.
Of Pneumatocele or Hernia ventoa.
div.p:
THis windy Rupture does happen with and without a Dropie; if with a Dropie, cure the Dropie, and the Rupture will be dimied; if without a Dropie, we are to ue Topical Medicines, and thee ought to be Digetives, and purge the Body from the flegmatick and windy Humours, and if poibly gain a digetive faculty in the Stomach, and thee you have already precribed in Tumours ariing from wind. This Tumour is known from the former, becaue it is more lucid and red than it; the Veins are puffed up, and the plendour appears more bright than the former, and is uddenly framed, and as peedily dicharged. And having already furnihed you with Medicines for dicharging the Antecedent Caue, we now arrive at the Conjunct Caue, which is this flatuous Spirit got into the Scrotum, or its Coats; the which we hall thus endeavour to dicharge by outward Medicines, as Fomentations, Oyls, Unguents, Emplaters, Cataplams, and the like, neither here uing Cautick or Inciion
For Fomentations you may ue thee:Foment. . Origan. Calamenth. Puleg. an. M. . em. 4 Calid. major. em. Vitic. Bacc. Laur. Juniper. em. Cumin. an. ij. fl. Melilot. Chamomel. an. pug. ij. Sal. ij. coquantur in . q. vini albi ad 3 partis conumptionem. Another. Or this: . Lixiv. Barbitonor. iij. Cumin. Bacc. Laur. an. ij. fol. Laur. Rorimarin. Roar. rubr. Meli. Menth. Majoran. an. M. j. Sal commun. iiij. with this bathe the part affected with a Sponge.Another. Or this: . Acet. fortiim. ij. in quibus coquantur rad. Pyreth. Staphi. ac. Bacc. Juniper. Laur. Cumin. an. . fol. Laur. Haeder. terretr. Salv. Thym. Rorimarin. an. pug. j. bathe alo with this the affected part; or with this:Another. . em. Cumin. Bacc. Laur. Rut. Chamomel. Bacc. Juniper. Abynth. an. i. mice, fiat Fomentum, cum aqua & vino mixta. Oyls. Oyls for the ame are thee: . ol. Rut. Laurin. an. i. ol. Petrol. i. ol. Spic. Terebinth. an. . mice. Or, ol. Chamomel. Rut. an. i. ol. Aneth. Nard. an. iij. pirit. vin. ij. Cer. q. . fiat nguentum. Unguent. Or, . ol. Cator. Rut. Euphorb. an. vj. nguent. Martial. . mice. Catapl. Or for Cataplams take thee: . em. Cumin. Bacc. Laur. em. Seel. Rut. an. i. tercor. Bovin. j. Sulphur. viv. Cumin. an. ij. mel. q. . fiat Cataplama.
Or this;Another. . Farin. Fabar. iiij. em. Danc. Cumin. an. . Bacc. Laur. Juniper. an. ij. fl. Chamomel. Melilot. Roar. rubr. & Lavendul. an. pug. j. Salpug. i. cum vini albi q. . fiat Cataplama. Or,Another. . Farin. Fabar. . em. ••
nugraec. cumin. an. ij. em. Apii Rui. an. j. fl. Chamomel. pug. ij. pulv. Rui. Abynth. Scord. Roar. rubr. ad. . c •
quantur omnia in vino albo q. . fine addendo Oximelit. Scillitic. q. . fiat Cataplama. Empl. Empl. de Bacc. Laur. is here alo very good; or this mixt Emplater: . Empl. de Melilot. de Bacc. Laur. de Ran. cum Merc. an. iij. nitr. Cumin. Sulphur. Calc. viv. Sal. an. j. ol. Laur. & Cerae q. Hitory. . fiat Empl. Benivenius cap. 81. Abditor. writes of a Peron of Quality, who having his vicera and Stomach o filled with Wind, that it proved very troubleome to him; and when the part was compreed, there was perceived no exition: and hence not onely the Bowels and the Bret, but the Scapulaes alo were extended with incredible pain, and the Spirits very narrowly con • ined; all convenient and proper Medicines being precribed and ued without any effect, the third day the Gentleman dieth; the dead Body being diected, the Intetines and the other vicera were een to be much
welled and puffed up with wind, and in the left Ventricle of the Heart was found a hard Calloity equalling the largenes of a Nut, and thee two were generally held to be the onely Caues of his Death.

div.head: CHAP. LXI.
Of Sarcocele or Hernia carnoa.
div.p:
THis is a Tumour contra naturam, which is generated about the Teticles out of a Scirrhous Fleh; or it is a Tumour bred out of the defluxion of thick Humours, which are collected between the Coats of the Teticles, and they there not aimulating, there oft times grows as it were a Hypoarcois, oft times Varices accompany the Tumour, and thee are very troubleom; and thee Humours being thick and vicid, bred from Flegm and Melancholy, as they breed Scirrhous Tumours in other parts, o alo do they generate a hardnes in thee.Signs. It is known by its Hardnes, Aperity, Inequality, and Indolency. It arieth from Melancholy, it having a ublucid colour. If it arieth from Flegm, it does not differ from the colour of the Cutis.
If it arieth from burnt Melancholy, it hath a pricking pain, and the Tumour is inequal, in ome places oft, in others hard. If the Tumour be not confirmed, cure it as you do a Scirrhus, by uing Emollients, then Dicuives; but the lat eldom does any good here. But if thee fail, you are to come to Section; but if it be Cancerous attempt nothing. Matthiolus affirmeth, that he hath abumed a Sarcocele by the onely uing of Pulvis Radicis Anonidis being taken for many moneths. But if it yields not to Medicine, Inciion is the next remedy; and this way or method is not void of danger, the Teticle being either left in or taken out. And by the way we are to conider, that if any flehy ubtance grows about the Coats or Teticles, this is wholly and abolutely to be taken away in this cae for more afety; the Veels are therefore to be drawn out and tied, and afterwards incied and cauterized: for to leave any part hereof, does more repreent the ignorance of a Quack, than knowledge of an Artit; for no Son of Art will give the advantage of a new growth, whenas he may well prevent any appearance of the ame by a careful managing of his Operation, and taking care of preventing all accidents; for a mall
quantity, but left remaining, will oon run up (like a rank Weed) to a great bulk, and this in a hort time grows wore and wore. If the Tumour be not very hard, the Chirurgion comprehending the whole Tumour, that is the whole tumefied Subtance in the Teticle, every way encompaing it, let him make his Inciion even to the Tumour above the Scrotum; then abduce the Teticle from the Scrotum, drawing a trong Needle and Thread through the middle Proces above the Region of the tumefied Teticle, and then drawing it back again through the ame part of the Proces; then tie both of them; thee being performed cut off the whole Proces, the Teticle being concluded with it. It being ablated, apply a Repercuive Medicine, and trengthen the neighbouring parts with convenient rollings and bolterings, and heal up your Ulcer as you do others. Fabritius Hildanus tells a very pleaant tory of a young man,Hitory. who embracing his Mitres in Veneral Ceremony, he being near ready to eject his Spermatick uccus, was prevented of his intended purpoe by a Meenger which ruhed in unawares, by opening the Chamber door, and diturbing him in his puruit, on which his Sperm receded, and was retained.
Upon which a pain eized on his Groin, his Teticles tumefied, and the pain began to be remis in his left Teticle, and the Tumour vanihed, and returned to its former tate; but about the right the Tumour continued, the which in proces of time turned into a great flehy Rupture; and he being called to the Patient amongt other Phyicians in conultation, aw not onely Fleh about the Teticle concreted, but found it alo extended with erous Humours, o that it equalled near the largenes of a Childs Head.

div.head: CHAP. LXII.
Of Circocele or Hernia Varicoa.
div.p:
THis is nothing ele than a Dilatation of the Veins in the Teticles, conglomerated in manner of Varices: and thee (as Celus and Paulus write) are either the Veins of the Scrotum, or thoe in the Membranes of the Dartos, or thoe which do nourih the Teticle: and therefore Celus advieth, if the Rupture be in the Scrotum, you are to apply thin and harp Intruments to the Veins, and with thee the Veins are to be cauterized, and there to be mot cauterized where mot variced or twited. The general Curative Method here is the ame to that precribed in curing of a Scirrhus; Intentions. the Intentions here are three, to repell the flowing Humour, to dicharge and dry up that which hath already lowed, and to atringe the dilated Veels. Now Atringents do atisfie thee two copes; for as being cold and retringent, they repell the fluent Humour; as being drying, they dry it up; and by its Atriction do alo bind up the dilated Veels. And for this Affect, Balautians, Red Roes, Pomgranate Rinds, Juice of Hypocytus,
Bol. Armen. Dragons Blood, Matich, Olibanum, Glue, Amber, and the like; thee, or any, or ome of thee mixed with the White of an Egge and a little Vinegar, may very well be ued here: but if thee do no good, come to the ue of Inciion or Cautick, and here are we to be very careful in onely cauterizing the parts where they are thus twined or twited together; after which done remove the Echar, then deterge and diget it. But if the Veins of the Dartos be tumefied, you are to make your Inciion in the Groin, and the Membrane is to be drawn through there with the Teticle, and after this eparate the dilated Veels from the Coat either with your Fingers or a convenient Intrument; then tie up the Veels, and cut them off under your Ligature; then repoe or reduce your Coat and Teticle. And if the Rupture be in the Erythrois or Tunica vaginalis, and either two be dilated, proceed in the ame Method as in the Dartos; but if it be between the inward Coat and the Teticle it elf, make your Inciion in the Inguen, draw out the Veels, amputate the Teticle, and cauterize the parts. And this is Paulus his Method and Ditinction. As touching Hernia Humoralis, take this brief Decription of it:
It is framed out of a Confuion of many Humours in the Scrotum, Hernia Humoralis. or between the Coats which enwrap the Teticle. Oft times alo it is een to be bred in the proper Subtance of the Teticles. You are to cure this as you do the former. And thus much of Ruptures.

div.head: CHAP. LXIII.
Of a Venereal Bubo.
div.p:
WE arrive now at the Inguens, where we may meet with thee four following Tumours, Bubo Venereus, Petiferus, Phyma, Phygethlon; of each of thee in their order. Thee Glandules have their proper names as well as others, and hence is it that they are called Bubones, by us in England called the Popes eye, in veal and mutton. They are held to be eight in number and very large. There is held to be a great commerce between the Nerves and thee Glandules: for it is very credible that the Nerves do conveigh omewhat hither, as their excrementitious uccus, and alo do end hither any nerveous quality that at any time doth perplex them; but they do not unload themelves into thee as into their excretory ports, but into their adjoyning veels; and hence it is that they are placed at the greater diviion of the veels: neither is it les probable, that they take omewhat from hence as a nutritive juice, the which being allured by a imilar attraction of the Glandulous ubtance, the
Lymphaducts to pour out their Lympha here, and by the benefit hereof thee Glandules do eparate one and leave the other: And this is confirmed by their weetnes and delicacy, they having a familiarity with the nutrive Succus. And the reaon they are o large and numerous is, becaue the Crural Nerves had need to have uch large Organes for dicharging their uperfluities. We come now to their Dieaes with the Affects; thee being either imple or not malign Tumours, or petilential or venereal Tumours. The Caues of all which may be reduced to two. The firt being the hindrance of the Circulation of the Blood, and hence arieth a Tumour by reaon of the continuity and impetuous afflux of the Blood from the heart through the Arteries, and by reaon of its making no reflux from thee through the Veins: An evident example we have hereof in Contuions of the Glandules and in their Obtructions. A econd common Caue arieth generally from the Nerves themelves, pitting forth their uperfluous Humidities being either here vitious in Quantity or Quality: now thee are 2 common caues. Every pecial Tumour hath its pecifick caues & differences: and thus if thee uperfluities only err in quantity or quality, as in vicidity, thicknes, or the like, it frameth a
imple Tumour: If from a malign quality, there arieth a Tumour being of the ame nature (as malign;) and thus being either venereal or petilential it occaioneth a venereal or petilential Tumour.Caues. We are now to enquire of the efficient caues of this venreal Bubo: and this poyon oftimes is communicated to the Liver, and hence is ent into the Inguens, as its proper Emunctuories, and hence arieth thee venereal Buboes. The cheif matter of which they are bred is of a part of thick, cold and vicid Humours, which may wel be perceived by the hardnes, whitenes, ilnes of pain, and colour of the Tumour. Sometimes they arie from a hot, harp, & cholerick Humour with a great pain, and a conjunct heat, and thee make them o oft to run into Ulcers, being both virulent & corroding.Cure. As to the cure, never-ue digetives, let the thinner part being reolved, the thicker excrement lyes and encreaeth inwards; much les Repellers, for thee do drive the virulent matter inward; and therefore Attractives and Suppuratives here only do take bet place. The Tumour being made ripe, open it with a potential Cautery. As touching the cure of the whole body, neither purge, bleed, or keep any order of dyet. Make your orifice not very large, but o as you may lodge in it a pretty handome large Tent for dicharge of this
peccant Matter, you may keep it open for 20 or 30 dayes according to the greater or leer quantity of Matter. This being dicharged, we may both precribe purging, bleeding, and a good order of dyet. It being dicharged, cleane it well, fill up with fleh, and kin it. And thus may you cure the kinder ort of a Venereal Bubo: but if it proves more rebellious, then intead of Suppurating Medicines we hould come to the ue of Cupping Glaes every other day, and after thee to apply Diachylon cum gummi mixed with black Soap, and thee will maturate the mot rebellious Buboes; and having brought it thus, deterge the Ulcer by keeping it a long while open, and freed of its peccant Matter; then fill up with fleh,Hit. and kin it. Hildanus tels us of one, who in an impure coition with a Strumpet had all his genital parts o dilated, that a malign Vapour paed to the next immediate Veines, and afterwards coured through the greater to the Liver, and o infected the whole mas of Blood, hence were generated many crudities intead of Blood. And as nature is alwaies careful to defend her noble parts, and to vindicate them from blemih and injury, he generally ends thee Humours to the Ing • ens, as to its Emunct • ories: and
here they breed thee Tumours we call Buboes, which were made of a hot and anguinolent matter, the which with eae came to uppuration; others there be which being generated of could and thick Humours do require a longer time to uppur ate, and a greater diligency to cure, the Matter was harp and malign, and many Medicines being ued both inwards and outwards with mall ucces. The Tumour appeared but mall, and was very hard, and after having applied many attractive Cataplams and Emplaters, by the benefit of a Cautick it did break, out of which for ix or even dayes pace it did run near ten pound of Matter. About the Rotator of the Thigh broke out everal Abcees, out of which did alo run uch a great Quantity of Matter for ome months, that many thought him carce curable, but by care and convenient Medicines he recovered.Hitory. Schenkius relates of a noble man about 30. years of age, who having recreated himelf in Venereal embraces with a young noble woman being filled well both with wine and venery had oon after his fulnes of pleaure an implacable pain about his Hips, and in his left Groyn did grow a large and red Tumour, the which after wards turned it elf into an Ulcer to which applying
Diachylon cum gummi and uch like Medicines it was peedily brought to uppuration; the which being opened a great quantity of Purulent Matter came out much like to that of Pultice; his Spirits almot being exhauted, he fell into a conumption, accompanied with a Hectick, and afterwards within a little while leaves the world with his pain. I write this as a Caution to young Chirurgions, that they do not upres uch Venereal Buboes, or leave any Venenate or Virulent matter to lodge in uch Tumours or Abceses, they at lat turning to Fitulaes, if not bring a Conumption with them, and o Death.

div.head: CHAP. LXIV.
Of a Petilential Bubo.
div.p:
THis Tumor by the Arabians is cal-Althois. It is a Tumour long, and moveable, in its Vigour harp with a mucronated Turbination, immoveable and deeply fixed in the Glandules, in which the Brain exonerates it elf into thee Glandules omewhat of its venenate and petiferous Matter, as to thoe which are in the Throat and Ears, the Heart to thoe which are under the Axillaries, and the Liver to the Inguens. It coniteth of a thick and vicid ubtance, as a harp Anthrax
• ixing an Echar in the part. Of thee are two conjunct Caues, the Efficient is trength and vivacity of the expulive Faculty of thee principal parts, which expulion is made by thee to the Emunctuories. The material Caue is corrupt Blood deprived of its proper Nature, Effence and benign Quality, and altogether altered and changed from its pritine Subtance, that it turneth an enemy to its nature. And here ought we to enquire into the caue of this Corruption. It is to be noted in an Inflammation and Eryipelas the fluent Blood
is good, becaue it is not expelled, only aggravated in Quantity: This is expelled in repect of its ill Quality.Caues. Galen giveth this as a Caue, as Corruption, when that be received be of an evil juice, they being of the wort Nutriment. Another Caue is corruption of Air, the which being attracted doth force it elf into the Spirits, and o corrupt the whole Mas of Blood. we do own a Petiferous Bubo to be an Inflammation of the Glandulous parts: and here therefore we are to mind the whole colour of the Body; For in a Petiferous Bubo this is ometimes changed.Signs. Another ign is a dry and black Tongue; another is a thin and waterih Urine, his Excrements very fetid, becaue this putrid Heat doth corrupt them. In a Petiferous Flux there is oft times a Cholerick Flux adjoyned, and the Excrements are of various colours, frequent Vomiting and tinking Sweats, a general Itch over all the Body, pains of the Head, oftimes Delirium, great pain and griping in the Stomach, by reaon of the putrid Humours ent thither from the Guts; then Syncope and at lat Death.Preage. In this cae Death is generally to be preaged, the dieae being o potent and forcibly aailing the natural Fort, that it cannot long hold out. As
to the Cure;Cure. Firt cure his Air, this being as a main Actor in this Tragedy, and therefore prinkle his room with Vinegar, or burnt Tarr, &c. let his Dyet be thin, becaue his Humour is thick; all Paions are to be hunned; Venery • led from as the greatet enemy, becaue it is a great dieae. Galen ordereth Venae Sectio; and in every putrid Fever you may ee him ordering Phlebotomy as you may ee it in 11. Meth. cap. 14. And in a Petilential Bubo there is concomitant a putrid Fever; and therefore Bleeding is very requiite. Beides thee, the common igns of the Bloods offending in Quality requires Bleeding: But this is to be done and performed both warily and judiciouly; for in ome caes it is by no means to be admitted, as in the Small Pox appearing, or Buboes; for by Veneection here we end the peccant Matter inwards to ome noble part, and o intead of quenching we rather add Fuel to the Fire. And in purging be ure you oberve to mix omewhat of an Alexipharmick to trengthen the Parts. As to the outward Applications, Epipaticks, Cupping Glaes and the like Medicines, are the only proper Intruments to abate the Fury and fetch forth the Malignity. Somtimes Cauticks alo do take goop place
here, anointing the Skin firt with Oyl of Lilies, that the more looe the Skin be made, the deeper the impres the Cupping Glas may make. And being thus brought to Suppuration apply Venice Treacle or Mithridate plater-wie. Or for this ue you may ue this Unguent. .Unguent.
nguent. Dialth. i. Ol. Scorpion. . Mithridat. Solut. in • q. vitae . this hah in it a dicuing Quality. Or this,Another. . nguent. Bailicon. iij. Ferment. acr. ij. Ol. Lilior. alb. Chamomel. an. . Theriac. Andromach. cum vitellor. Ovor. n•. ij. mice fiat nguentum. A Veicatory applied under the Bubo is very proper: As if it were in the Throat apply a Veicatory to the Scapulaes; and after they have performed their work, cut them open, and dicharge the Matter, and keep them open for ome time, by applying Beets, or Ivy-leaves, or Melilot-plater to them. Thee may be ufed if your Patient lives to ue them: But this is very rare, for they eldome are cured, they dying the firt day, and very few living beyond the fourth. I hall conclude this Chapter with this Hitory related by Petrus Bayrus lib. 20. cap. 8. of a Woman which had a Petilential Tumour bred behind her Ear, and he being ent for
about eight hours after it was perceived, it grew into a large Bulke in that time with much pain, the pain afterwards began to ceae, but the Venome decended to the Heart, and did horribly trouble and vex it; neither could he beleive herelf to live an hour: being by his directions ordered to mell to Vinegar and Roe-water; after this he was bled on each Cephalick, firt Breathing a Vein on the contrary Side, then on the ditempered Side. Then was there applyed a large Ventoe to the Part affected with a deep Scarrification, reiterating its application: And when there was drawn near half a pound of Blood by this Ventoe, the Patient began to find her elf omewhat better and to have ome hopes, and found manifetly that the Venome receded from her Heart by thee Frictions, Odours, Cordial Powders, and Potions and the like; that by Divine Bleing and help of thee Remedies he perfectly recovered. Hollerius aith live Oyters being applied to Petilential Buboes do attract all the Venome from them.

div.head: CHAP. LXV.
Of Phyma and Phygethlon.
div.p:
IN cap. 1. lib. 2. ad Glauc. Phyma is aid to be a Tumour in a Glandule, which encreaeth with ome Vehemency, and hateth to Suppuration; for < in non-Latin alphabet > agrees with all orts of Tumours ariing out of the Earth: and thee happen not only in the Inguens, but very oft in the Axillaries; for thee Glandulous Bodies being very looe are the mot apt to give Entertainment to all trange Appearances, Fluxions and Tumours, particularly in the Groins, becaue of their depending Site, trong Motion, and humid Redundancy. After here having precribed a convenient Dyet, and the general Method, which we have already hown you in a Bubo, we are to apply Digetives to the place affected, and then Suppuratives; and the Tumour being by thee made ripe, we are to dicharge the Matter either by Cautick or Intrument; and the ret of Cure perform, as you have already directions in curing of a Bubo. What Phygethlon is. Phygethlon is an In • lammation and part of Eryipelas, or an inflamed Eryipelas; and
this you are to cure by Phlebotomy, Purging, and Diet. As touching the affected part, you had better apply Digetives than Suppuratives, becaue this Tumour hath a mixture of Choler: and hence it is that Galen. lib. 6. Simpl. doth praie Atriplex, and the Leaves of Garden Mallows, and a cold Cerate, and is at length to be cured with mild Dicuives. Luitanus Cent. Hitory. 6. Curat. 82. telleth of a young Gentleman troubled with a Phygethlon under his Axillary, the which did pread to a very large bignes, in proces of time it grew oft and livid, and o proceeded with Pulation, that both Phyician and Chirurgion conjectured Matter to be lodged in it; and therefore by a general conent it was opened; but the Succes was mierable, for it was carce opened but the Blood flew out impetuouly, with a great noie of Spirit, upon which the Patient preently dieth with his inclining downwards, and he peedily departed this mierable Life.

div.head: CHAP. LXVI.
Of the Hemorrhoides.
div.p:
HEmorrhoid is a Compounded word
< in non-Latin alphabet > , which ignifies Sanguis, and < in non-Latin alphabet > , fluo; and this is a Flux of Blood. The Veins of the Anus onely gain the place of their dwelling and being: or they are Tumours encompaing the Veins of the Anus, excited by the great in • lux of Melancholy Blood, reembling omewhat of a pecies of a Varix. Some of thee at certain times do open themelves, and o do dicharge and exonerate the Blood: others there are that onely tumefie. Some are hidden, others more manifet. Such as flow, they pour out almot all Blood mixed with a yellowih Serum, which is as a Vehicle to make its more peedy exit, and by its acrimony does make a more peedy opening of the Veels. Such as do not flow, do either lodge in ome mall Bladders, and by ome called Veicales; and thee are made by the influx of Flegm and Serum, reembling Grapes, from whence they are called vales, from the efflux of Bloud, being laudable in quality, but bred by a copious Redundancy. They
are different in their Magnitude, ome being large, others mall; in their multitude, ome having many Orifices, others few; in their Figure ome narrow, ome broad; in their Colour, ome being of a blackih colour, others more red; in their Place, ome being in the Anus, others in the Sphyncter, others bordering upon the right Gut; in their Contitution, ome being mild, others more cruel and painful.Their Origination. Thee Hemorrhoides arie (as both the ancient and modern Anatomits allow) from the Splenetick branch, deducing its iue from the Porta produced downwards towards the Rectum, and then carrid backwards to the Coccix, and there to be inerted and propagated. But from the Vena cava there are two Branches produced from the Os acrum or Coxendix, and ent to the Anus; the one from the right, the other from the left part, the which are dieminated through the Mucles of the right Gut and Anus, and do there contitute thee Hemorrhoidal Veins, here pouring forth their Blood: and this is confirmed with good reaon, for the rectitude of the Veels, the Blood flowing downwards by its weight mut necearily fill its Veels, and being girt up or contringed, being thus filled by the Mucles, does make way for this
Apertion. And to give a better light to the well ordering and curing of both orts, let us make an exact Anatomical Inquiry about thee parts. Thee Hemorrhoidal Veins again have an Artery belonging to them to feed them, this Blood firt coming from the Porta to the Anus; for from the great Branch of the Porta is this carried to the Spleen, and thence through the Meentery is it ent to the right Gut. Thee Veins are onely two, ariing from the Cava and the Porta for this caue, becaue thee erve, as do the other Veins of the Body, for nourihing the parts with Blood: and thus are the parts of the Anus nourihed therewith (This was a thing unknown to the Ancients;) and therefore it is neceary that the Melancholy Blood hould this way be dicued; for by this Paage onely is Melancholy bet dicued, and the Schirrus of the Spleen cured. Beides thee, thee alo are by nature as Scavingers to cleane the feculent Blood, and make a ound Body; and when therefore he cannot perform thee, we make our peedy addres to Phlebotomy: and the Evacuations thus made we daily find to yield great comfort and eae to the troubled Patient. Beides, thee not being kept open, a man having a great quantity
of Melancholy Humour lodged in him, the whole Body will hereby be les capable to undergo any other Method which may be precribed. And latly, in Malign Fevers, being lodged in the larger Veels, and there putrefying the Blood, thee mot properly ought to be opened, being nearer related to the affected part, where more good may be expected than from the Arm. Should thee be topped, they breed a Conumption in the Lungs, a Dropie in the Liver, by uffocating the Liver as it were in its native heat; and if they flow immoderately, the Blood being evacuated the Liver is cooled, thereby is excited a Dropie, and a decay of the whole Body. For this immoderate Flux take thee: .Unguent. pulv. Alo. Thur. Balaust. Sangu. Dracon. an s. mice cum albumine Ovi, fiat nguentum. Or this: . ol. Roar. Cer. alb. nov. an. j. Axung. Porcin. ij. pulv. Plumb. alb. i. liquefiant praedicta, & upra marmoream injiciantur, tunc adde plumbum. Another. Or this: . Axung. Porcin. ol. Lin. an. ij. ucc. Tap. Barbat. Cynoglo. an. ij. coquantur ad uccorum conumptionem, potea adde Sacchar. Saturn. . & cum pulv. em. Lin. q. . fiat nguentum. Another. Or this: . Tuth. praeparat. Coral. rubr. Plumb. an. iij. Lap.
Calaminar. Lithargyr. aur. an. . ol. Roar. i. ucc. Tap. Barbat. i. mice, fiat nguentum. Or if Pain, Heat, or Acrimony be urgent, you may ue ome ot thee:Another. . ol. Roar. ij. Ceru. . Lithargyr. aur. ij. Cer. nov. iij. Opii . vel j. mice, fiat nguentum. Or this: .Another. Thur. Myrrh. Croc. an. j. Opii j. fiat nguentum cum ol. Roar. & Mucilag. em. Pyl. addendo vitellor. Ovor. no. j. Or this:Another. . ol. Roar. Olivar. Myrtin. an. ij. ucc. Plantag. Milii an. ij. Acet. j. coquantur ad uccorum conumptionem, tunc adde Bol. Armen. Sangu. Dracon. Thur. Chalyb. praeparat. & pulv. an. j. Cer. flav. q. . fiat nguentum. Or this: . Vitellor. Ovor. no. j. ol. Roar. Violar. an. q. . fiat nguentum, addendo nguent. Roat. Popul. an iij. mice. Amatius Luitanus Cura. Hitory. 3. Cent. 5. writeth of a man about 45 years of age, who was formerly vexed with a Venereous Dieae, from whence came from him every moneth Blood through his Hemorrhoids, as the Mentrues in Women elewhere. He had uch a plentiful Evacuation of Blood, the which when he failed of his accompanied time performing its duty by thee Veins, he vomited much Blood out of his mouth, being of a yellowih red, without Cough or Fever: and for the preventing
of which evil he comes to advie with Luitanus, who advied him to be chearful, and to the parts he orders 4 Leeches to be applied, the which extracted ix Ounces of Bloud; after this precribed him a good Diet, and cooling Syrups, as Syrups of Endive, Fumitory, Woodorrel, and the like, for ome days together; and taking a purging Potion of Manna, Rhubarb, with Diaphoenicon, &c. with this order the Blood followed its former coure, and the Patient grew well. Oethius writes alo of one, who, when his Flux was obtructed below, he did every moneth pit Blood at the mouth, as you may have it lib. Obervat.

div.head: CHAP. LXVII.
Of an Aneurim.
div.p:
THis is a oft Tumour yielding to the Touch, made by Dilatation or Relaxation of an Artery: Every Artery, except thoe which are dipered through the Brain, have allowed them a double Coat, the inward of which being either corroded or rent, the outward may extend o much as to caue an Aneurim. Aneurims may be made by Anatomais, Diapedeis, Ruption, Eroion, or Wound of the Arteries. It happeneth in mot parts of the Body, but chiely in the Throat. It is a Swelling encreaing by degrees, and hath the ame colour with that of the Skin, a continual Pulation. If it be mall,Its Caues. it eaily yieldeth to the Touch. It is difficult in Cure. If it be large, and in the Axillaries or Inguens, in which the Veels are large, here expect no cure. Inciion very oft times caueth uch a Flux of Blood and Spirits, that it both dichargeth Art and Life very peedily. This too often happens by the imprudence of an ignorant Chirurgion, by pricking of an Artery intead of a Vein, and o occaioning this Pulation,
Pain, and Tumour. Some allow inward Caues, as Intenion of the Spirits, Contuions, Concuions, Obtructions, thee being accounted as the chief of the inward Caues. Some alo do adde Melancholy Blood to be a Caue hereof lodged in the Veins and Arteries; but the mot uual ign of its Caues is drawn from the ignorant Chirurgion, who by pricking too deep does wound the inward Artery, the which is not eaily to be cured by reaon of its Spermatick Subtance and Motion; and thus the Blood by degrees is percolated out of the Arteries, and making a Cavity for it elf formeth this Aneurim, the Matter hereof being a Spirituous Blood made by Dilatation, the outward Matter is made by Grumous Blood thus raied together. It generally receives thee two Methodical Scopes in its Cure, viz. Pharmacy and Chirurgery; and where the one takes not, the other mut be attempted. The firt are Repellers and Retringents, and convenient Ligatures, or Lead trictly bound over the part; or uch an Atringent as this may erve the turn,A retri •
gent <> . as, . Pulv. Bol. Armen. Terr. igillat. an. ij. Pulv. Roar. rub. Sang. Dracon. an. ij. Gallar. immatur. nuc. Cupre. an. i. mice, & cum Albumine Ovi, parum Aceti & Oleo Roarum fiat
Retrictivum. Let this remain on for two or three days. Thee are to be ued in mal Aneurims, but in large Aneurims not happening in the Head or in the Groins, they are accounted Mortal, according to Aetius, lib. 15. cap. 10. Some Artits do tie up the Artery both above and below, and then divide between thee two Ligatures; but this Operation is dangerous, painful, and troubleom, and eldom bringeth any benefit. But to preerve Life I would rather, if it happen in a place where it may lawfully be performed and exercied, have Amputation made; and before you begin this, be ure to purge the body with Caia, Manna, and the like; and order cooling Juleps, Emulions, and Hordeate Decoctions, and keep the Body open by Purging and Clyters. Hildanus in his 44 Obervat.Hitory. relateth of a young Gentleman, who being troubled with the Itch, upon which ending for a Barber to breathe a Vein for him, he pricked the Artery intead of the Bailick Vein; whence did arie an Aneurim. For the ablating of which above a moneth was ued variety of Medicines to little or no purpoe; the Tumour equalled the bignes of a Gooe Egge; it was pale and hard, in which was o perfect a Pulation, that it elevated the Dreings
and Rollers, as they might with eae be perceived. He could not extend his Arm; his pain was not great, but onely when he would extend it. Seeing how deperate it was, he was very unwilling to undertake its Cure; but being perwaded by the Prayers, Deires, and Requets of the Patients Friends to take it in hand, he ued this Method, a good Order of Diet being precribed, to the part affected was applied Emplatrum de Cicuta, and this Clyter was adminitred; . Rad. Alth. cum Tot. fol. Violar. Malv. Parietar. Mercurial. an. M. j. fl. Chamomel. Melilot. an. M. i. coquantur in aqua . q. ad tertiae partis conumptionem, in j. colaturae olve Benedict. Laxativ. j. Mel. Mercurial. ij. ol. commun. iij. Sal. pug. j. mice, fiat Enema. The next day was ordered this Apozeme for digeting of this Melancholy Humour;Apozem • . . Herb. Lapath. acut. Rad. Polypod. Q. Petroelin. an. j. Herb. Agrimon. Veronic. Cucuth. Fumoterr. ummitat. Lupul. a. M. j. fl. 3 Cordial. an. pug. j. Liquirit. var. paar. Rhaharb. Rapontic. an. j. em. Faenicul. Ani. an. . coquantur in aqua fontana . q. ad tertiae partis conumptionem: hujus colaturae accipe j. yrup. de Fumoterr. Epithym. an. ij. Aqu. Cinamom. i. mice, fiat Apozema, pro tribus
doibus, to be taken for three mornings. Afterwards was precribed this Purging Potion; . Decoct. praecript. viij. in quibus infundantur & macerentur Rhabarb. optim. ij. Senn. mundat. j. in dimidia parte hujus Decocti olve Diaturbith. cum Rhabarb. j. yrup. Roar. Solutivar. j. mice, fiat Potio. Empl. de Cicuta was every day renewed, and afterwards he took this Purge; . Confect. Hamech. i. Extr. Cort. Eul. . aqu. Cinamom. . mice fiat Potio. After this the Tumour began to leen, and then was applied this Emplater; . Empl. Diapalm. ij. Empl. pulv. Mastich. Roar. rubr. Myrtilor. Radic. Symphyt. major. an. j. cum q. . ol. Roar. fiat Emplatrum. After this he applied a mall Knot oft times doubled, and this was joyned to the Ligature, and this was for repreing the Tumour, and for dilating or throwing out of the coagulated Blood: and by thee Remedies, and by Gods bleing, he perfectly recovered the ue of his Arm.

div.head: CHAP. LXVIII.
Of a Paronychia and Pterygion.
div.p:
ITs place and eat is generally at the Fingers ends; here it fixeth it elf, and from hence does it end forth its pains.Its Figure. Its Figure is longih, omewhat Oval.what it is. It is a Preternatural Tumour apotemated, mall and carce perceivable, beginning at the Fingers ends, ariing from a hot, venenate, and nitrous Blood, and oft times places it elf between the Bone and the Periotium. At its firt appearance it is mild and gentle; but afterwards grows fierce and troubleom, cauing pains, Fevers, ometimes a Caries and Putrefaction of the Bones. It's called Paronychia, becaue it is a Ditemper
< in non-Latin alphabet > , marching to the roots of the Nails.Its differences from Pterygion. Fabritius de Aqua Pendente maketh no difference between Paronychia and Pterygion. Pterygion is a Hypoarcois or Excrecence of the Skin, and this does not immediately reach the Nail. Aeginetta cap. 81. lib. 3. hews the difference, where he calls Panaritium an Abces fixing it elf about the roots of the Nail; Pterygion to be an Increment of Fleh preading out of another part of
the Nail.Its Signs. The Blood of its nature is hot here, being kept in and denied a Difflation, Rednes ariing from this great Heat, Pain from this Intemperancy, and Solution of Continuity by this violent Matter, ditending and aggravating the nerveous, tendonous,Its Caues and manner of breeding. and membranous parts. Thee are ometimes aid to be bred by an inward caue, occaioned by a nitrous, harp, cholerick, venenate, fervid, and mot thin Blood or Humour; the which is infixed in the affected part. External Caues may be Contuions, after which followeth an Ecchymiis of Blood under the Cutis, or between it and the tendonous parts, or between the Bone and Periostium; this Blood being putrefied, large Inflammations increae, and Pain and other Symptoms appear. The Generation of this nitrous Blood is to be hindered, and that it may not flow is to be intercepted and revelled; and that which hath already flown is to be weakened by Repercuives or Suppuratives; but of thee in their order.Revulives. Revulive Medicines are uch as are to be applied to the oppoite part, and thee are hot and attracting; amongt which may be reckoned Scarrification, Friction, Veication, and the like.Interceptives Interceptives, commonly called Defenatives, have a Stiptick Faculty,
hutting the Mouths of the Veels and by the Coldnes and Stipticity they thicken, coagulate and hinder the Flux of Blood:Repellers. Of either of thee you may find various in my former Tracts Of Repellers thee are Cold, Moit and Retringent, and do repell the in •• uent Blood, and hinder its coming to the part affected. So long as you have any hopes of repelling an Humour, follow this freely; where this is not to be done, come to the ue of Suppuratives. Take this one for all,Catapl. in this place mot proper. . Pulv. rad. Bimalv. Conolid. Major an. . em. Lin. Foenugraec. an. iij. Malv. Alth. an. mj. Plantag. Hyociam. an. m. ngul. Roar. rubr. mj. Farin. Hord. Lol. an. i. fl. Melilot. Chamomel. au. pug. ij. pulv. Gallar. Melicor. an. ij. Bulliant imul in lacte vaccino vel aqua fontana Caepar. Sub. cinerib. coct. . fine addendo Ol. Roar Myrtin. an. . Lilior. albor. Chamomel. an. i. Vitellor. Ovor. Hitory. n • . Croc. . mice, fiat Cataplama. Fabritius Hildanus ueth a decoction of Cows milk here, wherein were boiled Mellilot flowers, Chamomel flowers, Quinch-eed and Lin-eed, and o Fomented the part: after which he opened the Skin, the which being opened dropped one or two drops of a reddih
thin Subtance; this being dicharged, he applies a little Venice Treacle which was diolved in Aqua vitae, and with this the pain oon vanihed. The Inciion being made, we are to Mundify the part with Mel roarum, unguentum ex Apio, or Aegyptiacum. For this ue alo Precipitate is very good. Glandorp is fearful of uing thee harp Medicines, thee being very ubject to caue Pain; and o he precribeth Anodyne Mundifiers, as Oyl of St. John's Wort, affirming that this doth both Diget and Mundify the compact Matter, lenify the Pains, deterge and incarn. Very oft a Caries of the Bone follows a Paronychia: and here mot drying Medicines are mot proper, as Falloppius his Powder. . Pulv. Rad. Peucedan. Irid. an. i. Euphorb. i. mice. As curing a Pterygion;
•• Pterygian. Having already acquainted you that it is nothing ele but a Hypoarcois about the Nail, and this heweth its own Indication, which is to ablate the uperfluous Fleh: and for this caue nguent. Egyptiacum or Alumen utum or Praecipitatum is excellent good. Or this.Unguent. . nguent. Populeon. i. Alumin. ut. ij. mice. Or this . nguent. Diapompholig. ij. Alum. ut. i. or the like. And thus much of thoe.

div.head: CHAP. LXIX.
Of Nodes of the Legs.
div.p:
THee very often happen after a long continued venereal Dieae, the which do not hew themelves very peedily, but in what plaes o ever the lurk in, they creat very great and Nocturnal Pains, being and having in them a contrary quality to mot of other Tumors to bereave the Patient of his ret by perplexing him more in the Night than in the Day. Thee Tumours are hard, bred from a hard, Flegmatick, thick and vicid Flegm, which are not to be dicued but by hot Medicines, and uch as have a Faculty of making the Nerves pit forth this Matter contained in them, thee carrying with them an Emollient and lenifying quality; and hence may you confidently make ue of uch Medicines here as I have et you down in my Tract of a Scirrhus, adding thereto Argentum vivum: Empl. de Ranis cum Merc. is very proper here alo. In the whole time your Patient lyes under your hands take care that he be ordered a ober Lie, hunning Venery as the greatet enemy imaginable.
It proves much better, if it have not touched the Bone, than if it had: but uppoe it hould get thither, and foul it; this is to be Scaled either by actual or potential Cautery, the which being removed, apply uch convenient Sarcotick drying Medicines, as may produce a new Skin over this: And for this affect, Powder of Myrrh. Aloes, Ireos, Euphorbium, Gentian, Aritolochia rotunda and the like are proper. I have een thee very frequent in St. Thomas Hopital in Southwarke, and ometimes here in Norwich, where I have met with the Signs very exact, painting out Pains and Aches, and nocturnal vexations as continually, as the Day leaves it elf to be hut up by the Clouds of the Night.

div.head: CHAP. LXX.
Of Tumours and Apotems of the Knee.
div.p:
AFter long and difficult Dieaes Tumours are oft een to breed in the Knees; and by how much the longer they are in breeding, by o much the longer expect will be the getting of them extirpated. They bring harp and bitter pains with them, becaue thee Humours are crept into very enible parts, as Membranes, the which do both ditend and rack them. The Cure hereof is difficult, becaue this Humour is eldom een bred but in Cacochymick Bodies, and uch as are of an evil habit of body; and then becaue the part affected is cold and weak, being far from the Fountain of Heat. Sometimes it is made by Flatuencies, crude and erous Humours; the which do flow and mix themelves betwixt the nervous parts and Membranes. As to the Cure, if it proceed from Blood, order a thin and cold Diet; and for Revulion Veneection is good; and here oberve your 4 times in its Cure. But if it cometh from a waterih Matter, the Body is to be purged by Phlegmagogicks; and for your Topicks apply uch Medicines as
have in them an inciive, attenuating, rarifying, and a powerfully drying quality, as thee:Catapl. . Farin. Orob. & Hord. Lent. & Lol. an. j. furfur. . fl. Chamomel. Melilot. Sambucin. ummitat. Abynth. Scabio. Veronic. an. pug. Stercor. Caprin. lb. Sapae ij. ol. Rut. Chamomel. Aneth. an. i. coquantur in Lixivio vel in aqua Abynth. compoit. cui addere pois Oximelit. Scillitic. q. . fiat Cataplama For this Affect this Emplater is alo held. to be good: . Diachylon cum Gummi Paracel. an. . Oxicroc. ij. Melilot. . Empl. de Ran. cum vel ine Merc. iij. mice, fiat Emplastrum. A Maid of 18 years of age falling on the Ground hurt her Knee,Hitory. out of which did arie a large In • lammation, accompanied with many pains; by applying Empl. ex Argilla, Bol. Armen. Bran, the White of an Egge, and a little Vinegar, the pain omewhat abated, and the Inflammation grew remis. About the Rotula a very large Tumour did arie, which was alo very hard, in o much that without great pain to the Patient it was not to be contracted. Hence was collected, that there was Matter gathered about the Rotula, and a very large Tumour did arie, which was alo very hard, in o much that without great pain to the Patient it was not to be contracted:
And for the Cure hereof this Method was ued, that the Blood and Humours might be leened, and their Afflux to the part affected prohibited; a drying and thin Diet was precribed, and the Patient afterwards thus purged;Potio purgans. . Herb. & flor. Betonic. Scabio. Cucuth. Agrimon. Veronic. an. M. . em. Ani. j. fiat Decoctum in . q. aquae fontanae, in iiij. olve Diacatholic. vj. Electuar. e ucc. Roar. ij. mice, fiat Potio. After this a Vein was breathed in the Arm, out of which was drawn 10 Ounces of Blood; then was precribed a purging Apozem made of opening Roots; Agrimony, Veronica, Majoram, Roemary, and the like, being made into a Cataplam, was afterwards applied to her Knee; then was applied this Cataplam;Catapl. . Farinae Hord. farinae Fabar. an. iiij. pulv. Roar. rub. Bacc. Laur. Myrtillor. an. j. pulv. fl. Chamomel. Melilot. Sambuc. Inae. Arthritic. an. . fim. Caprin. ij. cum vino rubro q. . fiat Cataplama, fine addendo Sapae iiij. apply it warm twice in a day. This was ued for 3 weeks, and the Apozem precribed and taken; and by thee and a good order of Diet the pain ceaed, and the whole Tumefication vanihed. But in the lower part of the Rotula there was perceived a manifet Hardnes, for the
emolliating of which all care was taken, but in vain; at length was applied a potential Cautery to this lower part, the breadth of the Tendon, then was the Echar removed by this Liniment:Unguent. . nguent. Bailicon. Butyr. recent. ine Sal. an. j. ol. Amygdal. dulc. & de vitell. Ovor. an. s. ol. Roar. j. mice, fiat nguentum, fine addendo vitell. Ovor. no. j. Croc. . This being removed, there was found a thick vicid Matter lodging in the lower part of the Rotula, and by applying of Pulvis Aluminis uti cum pauxillo Praecipitati, taking great care that the Tendon might come by no injury or detriment, the Ulcer was mundified, and afterwards was induced a perfect Cicatrice: and by thee means the Patient perfectly recovered.

div.head: CHAP. LXXI.
Of an Abces of the Foot.
div.p:
THe Foot as well as the Hand is troubled and perplexed with vicous and trumatous Tumours, oft times planting themelves in the Joynts, ometimes making the Bones bare and foul. The onely way to cure this Evil is to dicharge the Matter by Reolution, and if poible not to open it. At the end of the Toe there oft times falleth a harp pain, ariing without any manifet caue, not without ome inward occult Malignity, without Tumour or Rednes, depriving it of ene or motion; and hence oft times the end of the Foot being detitute of its native heat and colour, is affected with a Lividnes and Blacknes, and in proces of time does terminate into a Gangrene and Sphacelus; this more frequently happening more in aged people than in youth; becaue as the parts themelves are a great way from the Fountain of Heat, o alo are aged people les capable to help towards the producing of this Heat into thoe parts; and therefore in uch caes let it be your firt Intention to apply warm and comfortable.
Medicines here. If they run into a Gangrene, treat it as I have already directed you in the cure of a Gangrene.Hit. Hildanus writeth of a young Gentleman, who upon too much walking had a Tumour occaioned in his Foot, and for want of convenient Medicines thereto applied, there peedily happened an Inflammation, and within a very few days a very large Phlegmon accompanied with great pain and Fever; yet by this following Method his Patient was eaed and recovered. To him firt was precribed a thin Diet, then was ordered this Purging Potion: .Potion. Electuar. è ucc. Roar. ij. pulv. Rhabarb. . cum yrup. Roar. olutivar. j. & Decoct. Agrimon. Veronic. Rad. Lapath. acut. Cort. interior, rad. Frangul. & em. Ani. fiat Potio. The day following he breathed a Vein in the Arm: the Hip, Knee, and all the inflamed parts, were freed from Inflammation by this following Unguent;Unguen. . ol. Roar. ij. ol. Lumbricor. Axung. Human. an. ij. mice; and afterwards was applied this Cataplam:Catapl. . em. Cydonior. Foenugraec. Alth. an. ij. pulverizentur & macerentur in aqua calida, tunc adde farin. Hord. iij. pulv. Roar. rubr. . coquantur . q. aquae fontanae ad Cataplamatis formam, fine addendo vitella ovorum no. ij. cum albumine.
Apply this, and renew it as often as occaion requireth. By thee the Pain abated, the Matter began to hew it elf, and by Bailicon being applied to the part it was dicharged, and by the ue of the Cataplam the Patient was perfectly recovered. Thus have I carried you through the whole Dicoure of Preternatural Tumours, both in General and Particular; in which I have with all care and indutry endeavoured to hew you their Definitions, Differences, Caues, Signs, Preages, and Cures.
Si quid novisti rectius itis, Candidus imperti; i non, his utere mecum.
